description: This course introduces the concepts of programming and computational problem solving, and is the first and foremost introductory course to computing. Starting from a small core of fundamental abstractions, the course introduces programming as a method for communicating computational processes. The course begins with purely functional programming based on a simple substitution-based execution model, and ends with a powerful modern imperative language based on a realistic environment-based execution model. Topics covered include: functional abstraction, recursion, higher-order functions, data abstraction, algorithmic strategies, state mutation, loops and arrays, evaluation strategies, sorting and searching, debugging and testing.
comments: âˆ’+mario lorenzo 6 years agotaken in ay 18/19 sem 2 lecturer: dr. low kok-limgrading scheme: 4% studio attendance, 2% studio participation, 4% reflection attendance, 20% mission, 15% midterm, 15% practical assessment, 40% finalthis is the first time cs 1101 s is offered in sem 2 and even though no contest and sumobot events at this semester, i have to say that this mod is one of the cool mods in soc. for non-soc students, this module can be taken only in sem 2 (unless if you submit an appeal) if offered again next year. this module requires high level of consistency since the proportions of module are equally spreaded between cas and exams. this module's contents are based from structure and interpretation of computer programs book by abelson and sussman that can be found online, and this mod is divided into 3 sections (functions (simple, higher-order, substitution model), data (pairs, lists, trees), and state (mutable data, envrionment model, loops and arrays) this semester, instead of 4 sections since the concepts of metacircular evaluator and streams are not introduced in the mod this semester. another thing to point out is that unlike other cs 1010 equivalents, cs 1101 s introduces loops after midterm (that sometimes makes students with little programming experiences found that it's a bit tricky) in order to sharpen the recursive way of thinking. the content of this module is slightly (or maybe significantly) harder than other cs 1010 equivalent. so for non-soc students, you may want to reconsider this option to fulfill your cs 1010 requirement. this mod is not bell-curved (according to what they said which i sometimes doubt lol).dr. low kok-lim is a great lecturer that is able to deliver the concepts in simple packs so that the concepts are very easy to be digested. he is responsive to queries and patiently explains the doubts to the students. even though the lectures are webcasted, it is strongly encouraged to come to the lectures if you feel that you are lost since it will be helpful and you can ask any queries to dr. kok-lim.there are weekly studios (equivalent to tutorials) and reflections (equivalent to recitations) where attendances are taken. additionally, there are 2% proportion of studio participation in order to make the class active. you also may be required to submit the studio works to your avenger before coming to the studios and the submissions are counted for participation marks, despite the correctness of the answers. also, there are missions that are accounted for 20% of total marks. missions may be very hard sometimes and require a while to get into the solutions. if you are diligent enough, you may also want to do the side quests. side-quests are not counted for cs 1101 s' marks. instead, doing side-quests giving additional xps (the system for cs 1101 s is gamified). sufficient xps can obtain additional 1 mc in form of cs 1010 r in the next semester and you have the option to drop or keep the grades.do the past year papers for the exams, and you will be fine. the concept tested in the exams are similar between papers, with exception of this year's final since this year's final is somewhat easier than the past year papers. the principles for the exams: grab as much points as you can by doing all the easy questions in your pov, spam the hard questions. cs 1101 s' graders are pretty lenient in giving partial marks.last but not least, cs 1101 s rocks! no regret of taking cs 1101 s instead of taking other cs 1010 equivalent as a chemical engineering all quests - very highbare minimum 24 k - very high at the start, medium after midtermspersonally attempted all the early missions and quests, skipped 75% of the later ones. later missions are generally harder and more time consuming than even early quests (except for the lambda/functional programming quest, that one is honestly absurd). also, attempting the tedious ones may not necessarily be worthwhile when developing programming skills.content:important (transferable):recursion - getting comfy with implementing recursive functions, setting base cases, thinking recursively when approaching problems.lambda expressions - the essence of functional programming. hard to get used to at first, starts to make sense later on.lists - the 'lists' used in this course is a data structure formally known as a linked list, which may be unfamiliar to some.data structures -  pairs, lists, trees, streams, arrays. know their definition well, how to traverse and modify them.streams - hard and confusing topic to master imo. easy to develop misconceptions when dealing with more complicated streams.scoping and the environment model - deal with env models for the duration of this course, drawing them can be particularly tricky (especially unbounded lambdas, nullary functions, empty blocks).not (that) importantðŸš®:cse machine - you are expected to know how it works, and the terms used to describe the cse machine (control, stash, env, closure, etc..)metacircular evaluator - not worth the time and effort, massive info dump for something that did not even consist 10% of the final exam (subject to change!). even if you do study there's hardly a guarantee that you'll get the question correct anyway.my advice:this course heavily rewards curiosity and creativity. play around with source code. come up with random functions to surprise your studio in your missions/quests/studios, then share your creations in a playground link. if you find something weird, or unconventionally written code that works, share them too - random aspects of source are likely to come out in the written exams.before ra 1, learn to translate lambda expressions to their named function equivalent. learn to simplify lambda expressions, this will be crucial in scoring well. (fun fact: a lot of people still do not know how to simplify the lambda implementations of - pair, head, tail - even towards the end of the course!)before midterms:1. play around with abstractions like accumulate, map, filter. alongside recursive functions, those will be your 'loops' (since loops have not been taught yet). also venture into 2 d list territory, be comfortable when dealing with them.2. read up and discuss with your studio about master theorem (not covered in syllabus). isn't too hard + provides you with a standard way of solving the time complexity questions efficiently. if you're still not sure, write down the 3 cases on your cheatsheet.before ra 2, master drawing environment models. read up on the other topics tested, cuz most people were caught off guard this year by cse + stream qns.before pa, at least attempt the harder past year papers/questions. 23/24 final qn was notably hard. (this may be a little extreme) if insufficient, search leetcode for easy difficulty qns, and 'linked list' qns, then attempt to solve them in source playground while making use of the available abstractions.before finals, just revise everything. prioritize all content except metacircular evaluator (honestly just study for some other subject instead of this nonsense). metacircular evaluator is hard to grasp, since you're essentially reading hundreds of lines of abstractions made by someone else. tens of hours of understanding is (probably) not worth the <10% that comes out in the exam. when revising pyps, do be aware of the implementation of certain abstractions since they may change over the years. for example, the implementation of eval_stream changed in 24/25, causing great confusion when doing pyps.note that the majority of people will be putting in a disproportionate amount of time and effort into this 4 mc course. if you aren't performing well, might as well grind was where i first experienced being victim to the bell curve. difficulty of paper was artificially inflated by having a few hard qns in a relatively easier paper. i felt midterms was harder than previous years too, but the median says otherwise; it just keeps going up over the years although difficulty is higher too. practical felt especially catered to distinguish within the cs gods themselves while us in below median get completely destroyed. the only test that was actually easier than pyp was ra 2. by finals, i completely gave up on 1101 since it was on the same day as ma 1522 anyways (i would say that 1101 finals was pretty hard, but take it with a pinch of salt since i didn't bother to do any pyp for finals). assessments just feel harder year on year, and most of the time, you have to take extra effort to learn stuff outside of lecture since assessments test stuff beyond what is taught (especially ra 1). that being said, turnover rate for marking is very fast for 1101.essentially almost 30% is free via 24 k xp, mastery checks etc. however, the 24 k xp was very hard to get. i recommend grinding quests(quests are optional) at the start to farm more xp as missions(compulsory) get harder and harder over the weeks go. i found myself spending hours on each individual mission that only opens for like 4-6 days usually, and they just keep coming and coming like a never-ending barrage of bullets. i was so glad when i finally hit 24 k xp and didnt have to check source academy once every alternate day for any new mission i didn't know about. plus there are way too many tests that its like once every few weeks.regarding teaching, i think my ta was alright, a y 2 student just like most tas. boyd was a pretty great recitation tutor, shout out to him. btw, recitation is like a mini lecture where new content gets taught, so it is important. abt lecturers, the general sentiment among my batch was that ppl didn't like kok lim's lectures (ppl rated his lectures 1 and 2 stars on canvas), and that martin henz's slides were pretty lacklustre for a very important chapter (cse machine). i don't think they are bad, its just relative performance to boyd and sankar.overall, i think this course does teach certain important concepts e.g. recursion, higher order functions, streams, mutable data, memoization, but my opinion is that it was taught in a sub-optimal manner. there was absolutely no need to be using source, and the documentation pales in comparison to actual documentation. i can barely google anything to help with my coding, unlike in real world where i can actually find people facing same issues on coding forums.should you take 1010 x for the exemption? imo, definitely if you do not want to be frustrated over source. h/w, thats my personal opinion, others may disagree and say concepts in 1101 are too valuable to be passed. what would i know, i'm just a below median cs student. ras are closed book, midterms and finals allow one diploma graduates, the concepts taught in here are not necessarily new, but they are genuinely so vital to shaping how you think as a programmer. i would recommend 9/10 of poly students to revoke their exemption, as the things covered in 1101 s are not truly covered in any part of your curriculum in poly.workloadthe workload can get extremely heavy. generally, the best way to approach this mod is to truly grind it at the start of the semester. without experience, you will definitely lose a lot of time to this mod, but having completed the 24000 xp requirement at midterms allowed me much more time to focus on other mods after it. you should be hitting 18 k by midterms at the very least.curriculumextremely steep learning curve, especially for those without experience. honestly, the mod gives you an impetus to effectively change your way of approaching problems if you're used to just hacking something together to get an end result, which is pretty interesting and fun, but super challenging at the start.as you will come to learn as a cs student, your mods will be the same as adjacent mods under different codes. you won't be learning python, instead a javascript-esque language made for the module called source. my opinion is that realistically this wouldn't matter, because a good programmer should be able to switch languages, but learning programming through a single language may have introduced bad coding habits, so come in with an open mind.teachingi was under prof boyd for reflections, and found him to be extremely passionate in what he taught, and very clear in his explanations. in general, i didn't follow lectures after the first unit because my zoom kept crashing on my desktop. lectures seemed fine, but i tended to just attempt to learn everything from the slides on my own (probably not the best approach).the tas are the lifeblood of this course, and i salute them for the effort they put in into the studios, and the constant help that they give outside and inside studios.advicethe mod can be extremely discouraging. you will see people with no experience pick it up extremely fast, and there is a lot of instances where you will feel inferior. the truth is you cannot grind this module in the same ways you are used to. come in with an open mind, and be prepared to change how you approach problems.expected grade: a (87.7%)actual grade:tbcsee 20/21 sem 1 lecturer: martin henz, low kok lim, boyd andersonthere was 1 midterm, 2 reading assessments, 1 practical assessment and 1 final exam.programming assessments in the form of missions, paths, quests are given out on a weekly basis on source academy, the online platform the module uses. there are also a few contests where students get to express their creativity. these assessments provide exp, which constituted 18% of the module grade. however, the threshold for getting the full 18% is only about ~63% of the total exp, so doing only the missions + some quests should suffice. doing more, however, is rewarded through the 1 mc mod cs 1010 r, which is offered in semester 2. extra exp attained beyond the threshold will determine one's grade in cs 1010 r, so if one does almost all the missions, paths, etc, an a/a+ for cs 1010 r should be guaranteed.the module places more emphasis on functional programming and recursive thinking at the beginning (source 1 and source 2 don't even have loops!), and teaches the iterative approach at the second half of the module. i feel that this is quite different from other programming courses, that usually teaches iterative thinking and dive into loops early on. having had some prior experience programming before this module, i think that this approach is actually rather helpful as it "forces" students to understand the philosophy of functional, effect-free programming better, and generally programs in the functional programming paradigm tend to be more understandable and easier to debug in the long run.this mod was held during covid period, so tutorial slots were split into face-to-face and zoom sessions. i took the zoom tutorial slot. apart from the usual weekly tutorial, we did mastery checks (as pairs) and the ev 3 programming (as a tutorial group).there were two mastery checks, where tutorial mates pair up and explain to our avenger (tutor) the content we learnt so far, which helped to correct any misconceptions we may have had, before moving on with the module. despite it having been the covid period, we still had the robot programming section with the lego ev 3 s, which was done through zoom + source academy.due to covid, tests were held online through luminus and invigilated through zoom proctoring. screen recordings also had to be captured and uploaded. it was more tedious to set up compared to a physical exam, but has the advantage in the sense that answers could be edited easily (as we entered code through a text box in luminus), compared to writing code down on paper.overall, cs 1101 s was quite thought-provoking and enjoyable.see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+xxo 6 years agoeditedbest mod i've ever taken? ay 15/16 under prof. martin henz and prof. low kok-limso my peers have already written really substantial reviews but i thought i'll try to write one without all the jargons to better appeal to matriculating students with no experience in nus nor experience in anything remotely related to programming.// the dummy's guide to cs 1101 sif i were tasked with training a child to write an essay in 3 months, there are at least two ways i can go about doing it:1) i could start by introducing her to grammar, vocabulary and the like, and then getting her to write some essays (and she'll have to write a lot of essays just so i am sure she's got her basics down). my goal here would be to make sure she is familiar enough with the language to actually form sentences on her own.2) i could bombard her with classics. she will be made to read shakespeare in week 1, vonnegut in week 2, js mills in week 3, etc. and write essays immediately after for practice. oh, she's swahili and have never heard of the english language before? i'm sure she'll understand english after reading a few books. learning the language is trivial; what matters here is that she learns how a good essay is written.in both scenarios, the sentences "write properly cn alr", "the ability to compose a sentence, within reasonable bounds of competence, is adequate for our purposes", and "writing a simple sentence is good enough" are all functionally equivalent. at this point, they are all fine with me as long as the child is able to communicate her ideas. in the second scenario, however, the child is more likely to write in a more elegant manner now and in the future because that's the only form of writing she has been exposed to.i'm sure you've guessed it by now: the second scenario represents cs 1101 s.// prerequisitesyeah, the workload is immense (people take about 6-8 hours on average a week to finish their homework) and intellectually demanding, but don't be scared off by the naysayers who say you need prior programming experience!i didn't have experience and i did fine. all you need to succeed in this module is love <3 when you sleep at night and your crush appears in your dream, you need to slap yourself awake and dream of cs 1101 s instead.when you're waiting in line for food and instinctively look at your phone because you have nothing better to do, take a second to appreciate technology... then proceed to do cs 1101 s on your phone.if you shower cs 1101 s with lots of love, it will reciprocate accordingly.// pre-cs 1101 s adviceokay, seriously if you're worried about being able to cope, take a look at the first few chapters of structure and interpretation of computer programs (sicp) textbook or watch some of the associated 1986 mit lectures (both freely available online). being able to follow the syllabus in sicp without difficulty should net you a decent grade in cs 1101 s.i would advise against taking cs 1101 s alongside modules (or hall cca) with heavy workloads. keep 3-10 hours of your weekly schedule open. cs 1101 s is only fun if you have the time to fully immerse yourself in it! from anecdotal evidence, you'll probably only get good grades if you have fun.// gradesyou really shouldn't be reading this section because grades shouldn't matter as much as the fun you get out of the module. but if you're reeeeeeeally looking for some credentials to back up this module review :( i got an a+.see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+cchurley 9 years agomodule taken in ay 15/16 sem 1 by martin henz and low kok-lim.recursion is the way of are put into real shit and will help you a lot. go bug them a lot shamelessly. it's for your good.module is taught in jediscript which is pretty much javascript. the platform is gamified - you earn xp by doing the missions (assignments) and you level up after getting a certain amount of xp. there are sidequests and contests as well that serve as time sinks (but everyone does them anyways because kiasuness).you'll start by learning programming basics; in week 2 you'll learn recursion and in week 3 you'll learn higher order functions already. by week 5 you'll start doing list processing with even more higher order functions (filter, map, accumulate/fold). then comes the midterms, and after that you'll be exposed to many concepts. you'll learn: mutating data, object-oriented programming, assessment: 15% (week 7)reading assessment 2: 8% (held on saturday in week 10)practical assessment: 12% (held on saturday in week 12)final examination: 30% (week 15)programming is done on a web browser called source academy. there will be "paths" (lecture content revision exercises), "missions" (homework), and "quests" (optional additional practices) to complete. each of these assignments award xp upon completion. a minimum of 300 xp is also given after attending each studio session. reaching 24000 xp in source academy would award the full 14% for the "sa achievements" component. anything lower would be pro-rated accordingly. students can easily exceed the threshold of 24000 as long as you consistently complete your paths and missions, and attend studios.lectures are solely held online and recorded, 2 hours twice a week. you have around 36 hours to complete the path for that lecture once it is finished. there are usually 2 paths and 3 missions a week. missions usually take around 4 to 5 hours for the average student, and are the basis for understanding lecture content. i took a few days to complete some of them with the help of my ta.studios are tutorial sessions held in groups of 8 with a ta, who is most likely a y 2 student. there are studio sheets, which are homework assignments to be completed before each studio. the ta will go through the studio sheet during lesson, and move on to an in-class worksheet after that. make good use of your ta by asking questions and clarifying doubts.reflections are weekly 1-hour sessions conducted by more senior students (undergraduates and postgraduates), and the profs themselves.  there will be a reflection sheet to be completed before class. the teacher will go through the reflection sheet and reinforce key concepts for that week's lectures. reflection tutors are the best source of help you can find, so do consult them regularly.mastery checks are verbal presentations where students must convince their studio ta of their understanding of topics taught up to that point. the mastery checks are not graded and you will be awarded the full 3% for that component once your ta is satisfied with your presentation. you can attempt this as many times as you want.the key concepts in cs 1101 s are: recursion, lambda functions, lists, streams, arrays, loops, orders of growth, environment model. these topics weigh over 80% of the marks for finals so it is important to understand them well. the first step after each lecture is to be aware of what you understand and don't, before being able to ask your tutors about it.the practical assessment is the only exam where students are allowed to code on a computer.please make sure your code compilesby hard coding the base cases if you have to. (my code could not compile in 4 out of 6 questions and i got 22/60 for this exam.)the workload is very heavy, and you can expect to spend up to 20 hours a week on this course's content and assignments. some saturdays will be used for exams. this can be very stressful for many students, especially those with no coding experience (like me).finals will be difficult with many tricky questions. your tutors will go through some of the more challenging questions in past-year papers during lessons. ask for more examples if you need.overall advice: coding experience isn't all that important in this course, so don't be too freaked out by it. the main issue that students will face is the inability to solve exam problems and understand abstract programming functions. practice is key to avoid doing badly for these exams. complete all the given missions and practice papers before each exam, get a full understanding of the abovementioned key concepts and you should be fine.p.s. the last topic (metalinguistic abstraction) is a ridiculously abstract and redundant topic that took up a mere 8/100 marks for finals. feel free to skip it completely as i did since it won't be of by other reviewers, but here are some of my personal thoughts and details that might be useful.overviewi went into this course with a decent amount of programming experience. this course definitely used to relying upon, and instead have to use recursion and higher-order functions to complete your tasks (at least, until after midterms). i actually quite appreciate this design, as it allowed me to material (especially if you know javascript and its quirks), but definitely donâ€™t get complacent as a good portion of the course is still likely to be conceptually new to you. you will need to keep up with the lectures and not fall behind, as the earlier topics are important in understanding later ones. if you do not have prior experience, i do think the learning curve is significantly steeper, but there are many resources available to you, so itâ€™s definitely very possible to do well if you put in the effort. so donâ€™t be too afraid if you see people in chat yapping about random concepts in the first lecture.weekly schedulemon or tue: 2 h studio session. these are in-person 6-8 person small group tutorials led by an avenger (ta), who will typically be a y 2/3 student. attendance is pace, but i strongly recommend at least viewing the lecture recording within 1-2 days of it being released for a couple of reasons, both to make sure you donâ€™t fall behind, but also because the following reflection / studio will very quickly follow and will be using the lectureâ€™s content. if you are planning to watch the recording immediately after the lecture, do note that the recording might not release immediately and sometimes takes a couple of hours to process.for studios, there will usually be a studio sheet of around 2-4 questions that you should attempt before the session. it quite doable. note that there will also generally be an in-class question that you will do and discuss during the session.similarly for reflections, there will also be a reflection sheet. itâ€™s good to attempt, but i think not as important as studios because 1. the session is more a traditional classroom style rather than a discussion, so you can follow just fine if you just pay attention and 2. thereâ€™s no class participation score. so if your schedule is tight between the previous lecture and this session, no need to be too concerned.source academythis is a free 14% of the grade that you get from attaining 24000 xp. sounds like a lot, but i think itâ€™s very hard not to hit this threshold if youâ€™re just moderately disciplined. even if youâ€™ve passed the threshold, though, i think itâ€™s good to keep doing if you have the time, as itâ€™s good to gauge your understanding of the material. the number after the + is the bonus xp that you get for submitting early (within 24 h for paths (+25) and within 72 h for missions / quests (+75), it scales down linearly with time after that).18 paths (+1 first one which doesnâ€™t count) - 2650 + 450 xp: typically one after each lecture, consists of both mcq questions (if youâ€™re desperate, you can just keep hitting buttons until it goes green) as well as coding questions (just pass the test cases).20 missions - 19870 + 1500 xp: your main source of homework, anywhere from 1-3 missions per week. there are 3 robot missions that you will be doing together with your studio group.10 quests - 6020 + 750 xp: tougher questions, no need to do if you donâ€™t have the time, but itâ€™s a good challenge.12 studios - 5800 xp: 300 per studio if you show up, any more is based on participation, except for the first one which is 300 max. (i believe this is separate from the 3+2% grade for studios but not certain)other miscellaneous: 200 xp for voting in the course survey after unit 1, 3 x 50 xp for voting in competitions, and some amount for participating in the competitions (i didnâ€™t so i donâ€™t know, but if youâ€™re musically or artistically inclined it could be quite fun).so the absolute maximum you can get aside from the competitions is (if my calculations arenâ€™t wrong) 37390 xp for my year. this does change year-to-year though, as the previous run had at least 1 more quest. iâ€™d recommend starting off strong at the beginning while you still have plenty of time (getting the early bonus xp, attempting quests etc) so you can worry about it less later if you are really short on time.assessmentsweek 4 - reading emphasis on the cse machine which is a more detailed version of the environment model. however, i felt as if the prof could have covered the cse machine in more detail as we were only taught the basics and were left to explore the cse machine on source playground ourselves.practical assessmentyou will be given 2 hours to solve 6-8 "leetcode easy"-esque questions. the people with experience in programming tend to do better for this component. just make sure to complete the practice pas under time constraint and understand your mistakes well.finalsjust like midterms but harder, and you will be given 2 hours. the environment model, tombstone diagram, cse machine and metacircular evaluator will be tested. the last question might be a code excerpt from the actual metacircular evaluator and you have to make modifications to it. there tends to be more coding questions than midterms from what i noticed, but the format is mostly similar.pathsusually mcq questions and you have multiple tries. there are some coding questions and you need to pass the testcases. paths will contribute a small percentage to your source academy xp.missions and questsone or two missions will be released every week. the time taken to complete might range anywhere from 1 hour to 1 day. i remember struggling a bit at the start with the concept of recursion but towards midterms, i was able to complete difficult. i attempted all the quests before midterms, and i remember finding some of them very difficult.the xp awarded is based on difficulty. completing all my quests and missions got me to 24 k xp by midterms, and i stopped attempting missions and quests after that. i would not recommend this as i was quite clueless for the cse machine and the metacircular evaluator. just be consistent till finals.mastery checksyou have to explain concepts to your avenger and convince them that you understand the concepts well. it is a pass or fail component, so almost everyone passes.overalli found this mod fun, but some parts of it were quite challenging. also it doesn't help that the exams are back to back (ra 2, practical and finals were 2 weeks apart from each other). finals are over, and i still replies âˆ’+iisland of wantuutrewana year agotaken in ay 23/24 s 1 underboyd anderson (unit 1)sanka rasnayaka (unit 2)martin henz and low kok lim (units 3 & 4)darius foo (reflection tutor)workloadlectures/briefs: 3-4 h/weektutorials (studios/reflections): 3 h/weeklecture quizzes (paths): 2/weekhomework (missions): 2/weekoptional homework (quests): 2/weekthe workload is very heavy, but it gives you a lot of practice and helps you identify gaps in your understanding from week 1 (instead of waiting until halfway through the course like cs 1231 s), and you'll be well prepared when it's time for exams.course contentthe first half of the course covers functional programming, consisting of unit 1 - functions and unit 2 - data. instead of writing a sequence of instructions, you compose functions to obtain the result you want, similar to math. unit 3 - state introduces the messy world of state, giving you a lot more things to keep track of, which makes things more prone to errors/bugs. finally, unit 4 - beyond wraps things up with streams, metalinguistic abstraction (writing an interpreter for the language in the language itself) and some optional topics. missions cover the main content of the course, and quests stretch your mind further and are really fun, especially functional expressionism. overall, the course content is the best out of every course i have ever taken in my life, and i thoroughly enjoyed it.assessmentssource academy xp: 14%most people should get the full 14%. unfortunately, there is no cs 1010 r this year.studio attendance: 3%studio effort: 2%note that grading can be quite inconsistent among tutorial groups, with some counting from 0% and giving 25% most of the time and 50% when you put in a lot of effort, and some counting from 100% and giving you 50% just for attending.reflection attendance: 5%mastery check 1: 3%mastery check 2: 3%graded on a pass/fail basis and you can try as many times as you want, so most people should get the full 6%.reading assessment 1: 5%midterm assessment: 15%reading assessment 2: 8%practical assessment: 12%final assessment: 30%gradesas someone with below 10 th percentile igp and no projects, i had no expectations and just wanted to learn as much as possible.ra 1: 17/19 midterm: 93/100 ra 2: 57/60 pa: 80/80 final: 98/100 overall: 96/100 tipsfor ra 2, i didn't use any fancy methods and just diligently drew all the environment diagrams.expected grade: a+see more 00 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+iisland of wantuutrewanisland of wantuutrewana year agoactual grade: a+see more 00 agoeditedtaken in ay 23/24 sem 1 lecturers: profs martin henz, low kok lim, boyd anderson, sanka rasnayakareflection tutor: eldric liewassessment componentssource academy: 14% (full grade awarded upon hitting 24,000 xp)studios (tutorials): 5% (attendance 3%, effort 2%)reflection attendance (recitation): 5%reading assessment 1: 5%reading assessment 2: 8%mastery check 1: 3%mastery check 2: 3%midterm assessment: 15%practical assessment: 12%final assessment: 30%backgroundi must declare that i did take cs 1010 x before matriculating officially and cs 1101 s, however, these two courses are radically different with not much overlap. as can be seen from the outrageous assessment components, this is definitely not the average 4 mc mod.workloadthe mod is done in source, a subset of javascript developed specifically for cs 1101 s and can be done on a website called "source academy".there are 2 online lectures per week, one "main" lecture on wednesday (the start of the "cs 1101 s week") covering the broad concepts and one "brief" lecture (on friday) where they elaborate more about the mission specifics (purportedly).each week on source academy, a mission, quest and path is released. paths are more of refreshers to the lectures and briefs, missions are the main assignments to test your understanding and quests challenge your higher-level understanding and coding skills. paths and missions with some quests should be enough to get you the full 14% for the source academy grade.studios are once a week, 1.5 hour 8 man group tutorials, manned by the student tas. there will be a studio sheet for you to complete before that so try to do it.reflections are once a week, 1 hour recitations where the tutor will go over the concepts covered in lecture. again there will be a reflection sheet to be done before, but i didn't do it.reading assessments 1 and 2 are more like ca 1 and ca 2 in secondary school. they are mcqs and test specific topics, but have low weightage. my year ra 2 was very scuffed so manage expectations.mastery checks 1 and 2 are essentially small unofficial presentations on 3 to 4 concepts (format may differ) over zoom in pairs. you present slides/code snippets/notes to your studio ta to check your understanding. i just wrote some basic code and screenshared it to the ta while explaining.for practical, they allowed unlimited testing with public test case, but grading was done with private test cases automatically, so in theory no prof/ta will ever be involved in the marking. practical was okcontent(in no particular order)1. elements of programming (variables vs constants, etc)2. substitution model 3. recursion 4. orders of growth (time and space complexity, big theta/o/omega)5. iterative and recursive processes 6. higher-order functions 7. scope of names 8. data abstraction 9. lists and trees (pairs and immutable list representations, etc)10. searching and sorting on list and arrays (binary search/sort, mergesort, selection sort, etc)11. mutable data (arrays and variables)12. environment model (oof)13. loops (for, while, etc)14. memoization 15. streams 16. meta-circular evaluator (evaluate-apply)major roadblock concepts were recursion and wishful thinking, functional expressionism (iykyk) and environment diagrams (ra 2 massacre ahem). for me it was a case of "if i stare at it long enough i'll maybe get it" kinda thing, so try to keep practicing and applying these concepts.also learn how to (barely) read confusing af code.cs 1101 s likes to teach confusing and seemingly pointless ideas and thinking strategies, but they all make sense in the end and are robust enough to get by. it has to be said that, definitely, most concepts and ideas taught here pertaining to source are not at all transferrable to the outside world.final thoughts and advicei loved this mod because it was frankly fun, i managed to understand recursion and use it more effectively (which i detested and avoided in cs 1010 x) and it served as a good primer to programmatic thinking, but i also hated it because it was so convoluted and over-complicated at times that writing code and understanding documentation was painfully painful.i advice new cadets to have an open mind, but also don't be afraid to voice out your concerns. this course may be rife with smurfs but the community here is helpful, patient and the fact that you suffer and slog through 13 weeks with your 8-man army in tutorial can make it almost enjoyable.resultssource academy: 24,000/24,000 (xp)studios: 3/3 + [effort not released] (full attendance)reflection attendance: 9/9 reading assessment 1: 17/19 reading assessment 2: 30/60 mastery check 1: 3/3 mastery check 2: 3/3 midterm assessment: 89/100 (median ~74)practical assessment: 80/80 (median ~51)final assessment: 86/100 (median 74.5 supposedly)expected grade: a (87.6%)final grade: ???*edited for results, topics and formattingsee more 00 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+yyoinkysploinky 1 âˆ’+spergie_mc_sperglord 3 years agoeditedmodule: cs 1101 staken: 2021/22 semester 1 (covid semester - face-to-face tutorials but online lectures)instructors: martin henz, low kok lim, boyd anderson (will probably stay the same for a while)mcs: 4 + 1 (if you tryhard)assessment: 18% xp, 12% reading assessments, 6% mastery checks, 5% studio attendance and effort, 5% reflection attendance, 12% midterms, 12% practical assessment, 30% finalsdifficulty: 8.5/10 enjoyment: 9/10 description: this module introduces the concepts of programming and computational problem solving, and is the first and foremost introductory module to computing. starting from a small core of fundamental abstractions, the module introduces programming as a method for communicating computational processes. the module begins with purely functional programming based on a simple substitution-based execution model, and ends with a powerful modern imperative language based on a realistic environment-based execution model. topics covered include: functional abstraction, rec*rsion, higher-order functions, data abstraction, algorithmic strategies, state mutation, loops and arrays, evaluation strategies, sorting and searching, debugging and testing.expected grade: b+actual grade: b+this is where it all begins! it's a very unusual module due to how much effort they put into making this. there's an entire full stack application with a video player, game, art, autograder, and ide. the homework sets are called "missions" and "quests" (you can brag about that in front of non-cs students, even though they are really painful to solve) and the tas are called avengers (mostly y 2 and y 3 cs students who have been through the module).the content teaches you programming from the beginning, and by "beginning", it really does start from the very beginning. lecture 1 is on expressions and statements, such as 3 + 2. when i got frustrated doing my missions, i looked back a little at these things and it was a reminder of how far i had come, not that it really helped to quell my frustration. but right afterwards they dump you right into the deep end by introducing rec*rsion and higher-order functions. it was painful doing some of the homework at the start, since the coding that i had learnt by myself before the module started had given me a few bad habits. they adapted the course from mit, except that in mit you have to say "+ 3 2" instead of "3 + 2", so the module would not be easy by any measure except that the programming language is less convoluted. nevertheless, it's a very solid introduction since the course covers a really wide range of topics, such as computer graphics, sound processing, algorithms and a bit of programming language theory. the original course at mit feels a little like doing toy problems, but here you get to see concrete results of your code, so that you might like coding more by taking this module.the components of the course were semi-cryptically called missions, assignments also kind of expose us to different kind of application of programming like in music, graphic transformation, robotics, etc.personally, one thing that i think it's the most important and was introduced at the start of the module is wishful thinking. it's really important to understand this concept cuz it will save you a lot of time when writing recursions or iterations. my personal interpretation on this is you wish that the smaller problem can be solved by a certain tool, which in most case is the function which you are currently building a recursion inside, then by calling the function on the smaller size problem you would have solve all the smaller problems. then just use the result, which is the function call on the problem which its problem size is smaller by 1 step, to complete your entire recursion. you just wish that the smaller problem can be solved by a certain tool (which has to exist, if not, make one) and you don't have to understand how it exactly solve your entire problem which its problem size may be quite big. you can first start off with a small problem size and then build a recursion to deal with it. it's easier to understand how your recursion work when dealing with a smaller problem size. try to google to really comprehend what it means. i personally think that the article on wishful thinking by c 2 wiki is not bad.another thing is abstraction. personally i have two interpretations on this. one is when doing the missions, tutorials or any form of assessments, you just have to know what does the given functions can do and don't have to know how it works cuz trying to understand how it works exactly can take up a lot of time. another take is when doing programming, if you find that you are repeating a piece of code for quite a number of times, try to 'abstract' it away, meaning that to put it in a function which you can easily use the functionality again by calling the function or build a recursion or iteration.there is no fixed way in solving a problem, so just use the one that you are comfortable with. also, start off by building a solution that works first, then improve from there.to conclude, even if this mod is challenging, programming experience.martin will tell you that he prefers people without prior programming experience, as they are clean slates. heck, even the prerequisites section states "no programming or computer science experience is required". but all this means is that you will be learning a new style of programming (functional programming) that you may not have seen before. and if you have prior experience with languages like ruby/js, you have probably seen a bit of it before.coming in fresh means that you will have to pick up knowledge of syntax from the bnf definitions in the jedscript week n definition instead of in a more natural manner. i have seen students struggling with basic concepts like writing if-statements, only to have recursion and iterative vs recursive processes thrust into their face in the second week of the semester.however, the thing about cs 1101 s is that it is an excellent exposure module. the workload is heavy (seriously, you will be cursing at the 3 missions that are due on consecutive days which conveniently happen to fall on the midterms week; you will wonder why you ever signed up for cs 1101 s when your friends in cs 1010 are having it easy), but it is all worth it. you wil be exposed to fractal and curve generation, rsa encryption, robotics and ai while learning the concepts of functional programming.the module is taught in jediscript, a restricted subset of javascript. variables will initially be immutable, while you learn about recursion and iterative and recursive processes. you will learn tail-recursion and deferred operations. you will learn Î¸-notation and the notion of time and space complexity. you will learn the substitution model of execution. you will learn about pairs and how they are used to recursively construct lists. you will learn the map, accumulate and filter functions. suddenly, variables will become mutable. you will learn the environment model of execution, as the substitution model breaks down. you will learn how to construct circular lists using the set_tail function, as well as other esoteric data structures. you will learn a little bit of oop and then be exposed to lazy evaluation and stream processing. after that, the hardest part of the module comes, which is digging into the interpreter. you will learn how to modify and extend the jediscript interpreter such that it accepts a slightly different language or processes it in a different way. to cap off the module, you will learn familiar-looking constructs (if you have prior programming experience) like while and for loops, and finally html 5!somewhere in the midst of all that, there will be the legendary sumobot contest, where you build a robot using whatever skills you have learnt. the sumobot event itself is a fun evening full of jokes and laughter, and is an experience to remember. martin henz showed up in a darth vader consume that day. xdthe missions are hard, but fun and eye-opening, so i recommend taking them seriously.grade: a<tl;dr> i strongly recommend this module for all cs freshmen, but please please please learn some basic programming (preferably in js, but it doesn't really matter) before coming in. also, ideally, get some experience in functional programming by learning a language like scheme (it's really easy to learn!!!) before coming in, so that you don't freak out when you find out how lists are defined in jediscript. </tl;dr>see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+aaikendueet 2 years agoediteday 23/24 sem 1 lecturers: martin henz, boyd anderson, low kok lim, sanka rasnayakaassessment componentssource xp: 14%studios: 5%reflection attendance: 5%reading assessment 1: 5%mastery check 1: 3%midterm assessment: 15%reading assessment 2: 8%practical assessment: 12%mastery check 2: 3%final assessment: 30%module terminologytutorial: studiorecitation: reflectionta: avengeryou: cadet(yes, this module is space-themed)overvieweven though the first piece of homework is to write a comment, do not be fooled as the difficulty scales exponentially. cs 1101 s dives deep into functional programming in the first few weeks using a substitution model in a programming language called source. you're not allowed to use mutable variables and there is a deep emphasis on recursive methods to solve problems. you will also be exposed to new data structures such as pairs (which are similar to linked lists). after midterms, the module introduces mutable variables using a newly learnt environment model. you will also be using arrays and streams in addition to lists. you get a taste of leetcode by learning basic searching and sorting algorithms. the module concludes with a really really useless topic called metalinguistic abstraction and some bonus lectures.workloadextremely high (felt like 8-12 mc module).lectures are completely virtual, 2 hours, twice a week. the wednesday lecture is the main session while friday's "brief" is meant to teach concepts in greater detail. all lectures are recorded.studio sessions are 2 hours per week and in groups of 8. they are run by avengers, who are undergraduates who have taken the course before. there is a usually a studio sheet to be filled up before class. your avenger will usually recap the past week's worth of lectures, followed by go through the homework solutions. thereafter, there are in-class studio sheets to be completed. they can be quite challenging. after every studio session, your tutor will award xp online based on how well you performed during the session.reflection sessions are 1 hour per week, conducted by a more experienced avenger or a professor. there is also a reflection sheet to be done, and it will be gone through in class. the reflection sessions really helped to solidify concepts for me. my avenger, eldric liew, is highly knowledgeable in the field. he often stays back to answer my queries and he is great at explaining difficult concepts intuitively for me to understand them better.as for homework, there are 3 categories of work to be submitted, all on the online source academy platform. paths were simple questions (usually mcq or short code snippets) for you to recap lecture content. missions were the main homework, and it can get really tough at times. the missions often involve a few successive programming questions which build on one another. depending on your competency, you may take either 10 minutes or a weekend to complete it. after submission, your avenger will mark it and xp will be granted to you accordingly. note that you can get more xp if you submit paths and missions early. finally, for the braver cadets, quests are designed to really push the limits of your understanding (the most famous quest being functional expressionism). do not be too alarmed if you cannot do some of them. the professors have reassured us that if you complete all paths and missions adequately, you will achieve the required 24000 xp needed to obtain full marks for the 14% source academy component.examinationsreading assessments (ra) are fully mcq. ra 1 will introduce you to the most cancerous of code snippets where you must code-trace and generate an output. the answers are often very tricky. ra 2 focuses on the environment model and you will have to draw the corresponding model yourself before you can answer the subsequent mcq questions. i did poorly for ra 2 because i drew some of my environment models wrongly and that led to the downfall of multiple questions thereafter.the practical assessment (pa) is a 1 hour 40 min online paper where you code solutions to a few problem sets. the questions often scale in difficulty. a good thing about the pa is that you can run your code on a few public test cases provided. however, do ensure your code compiles as you will be graded fully on the private test cases.midterms and finals are pen-and-paper closed-book exams but allow one double-sided a 4 cheat sheet. the questions can be pretty challenging and new data structures (building on the ones you learn in lectures) are often implemented. however, the professors will upload the suggested solutions for the past few years so you can practise and get a sensing of the paper's difficulty.there are also 2 mastery checks which are recorded zoom sessions with your avenger for you to summarise what you have learnt. your avenger will ask you some follow-up questions too to check your understanding of the concepts. everyone gets full marks for these.tipsthe amount of resources put in by the teaching team is insane for this module. hence, do seek help by attending consultations or messaging your avenger if you have any doubts. do not skip lectures and ensure you do not fall behind in terms of content, as it can pile up really quickly. i would advise you to make a cheat sheet as you go along so you can reference it during exams.most importantly, enjoy yourself! the missions and quests often utilise interesting packages like runes, sounds and curves. you will be able to see or hear the results of your code. furthermore, you get to use a unique ide all from the comfort of your browser (unlike other cs 1010 variants). side note: safari is not supported as of now.overall gradesra 1: 18/19 (median: 15/19)midterms: 96/100 (median: 73/100)ra 2: 37/60 (median: 35/60)pa: 80/80 (median: 51/80)finals: 91/100 (median: ???)everything else: full marksexpected grade: a+ (93.37%)actual grade: ???see more 01 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+aaikendueetaikendueeta year agoactual grade: a+see more 00 description: This course is a follow up to CS1010. It explores two modern programming paradigms, object-oriented programming and functional programming. Through a series of integrated assignments, students will learn to develop medium-scale software programs in the order of thousands of lines of code and tens of classes using object-oriented design principles and advanced programming constructs available in the two paradigms. Topics include objects and classes, composition, association, inheritance, interface, polymorphism, abstract classes, dynamic binding, lambda expression, effect-free programming, first class functions, closures, continuations, monad, etc.

programmingstreamsparallelism/concurrencytl,dr: thereâ€™s are many good reasons that a fair number of reviews on this site warn against taking this course in sem 1. prof adi is overworked and it shows. he is nice and makes an effort to teach, but honestly i find that the resources he provides (notes, qna, etc) do better for me than actually listening to his lectures. the rest of the teaching team (especially adhy, but also the tas) are enthusiastic, approachable and very willing to help. the content does have a learning curve to it, not unlike cs 1010/1101 and variants, so if thatâ€™s what youâ€™re coming from prepare for another round of it. earlier topics might be more painful initially, but most people do get the hang of things later on, and i found that i could get away with a less thorough (conceptually) but broader (in terms of application) understanding of later topics. labs have to be a priority, if not youâ€™ll really struggle later on, while recitation/problem sets are great for revision.thoughts on parts of the course:lectures (2 h/week, recorded): prof adi is enthusiastic but ultimately not a great teacher. he puts in effort into his lecture slides to make them somewhat engaging, and tries to explain things, but i felt that he just was not good at breaking down the more abstract concepts. he moved too fast in general, but particularly for the later parts of the course (post-oop). the lectures i learnt most from were the oop lectures, after that i started to get lost and had to rely more and more on re-reading the lecture notes after the lecture to actually understand what went on. in particular for the later lectures on functional programming and streams, it made more sense for me to sit in the lecture, read the notes while he was teaching instead of listening to him, and then ask questions when i got the opportunity. it is good however that he uses piazza and answers questions on it very quickly and frequently.weekly quizzes were a good way to test understanding of the lecture content, and the github lecture notes were excellent in helping with my understanding and doing of the quiz.recitations (1 h/week): the problem sets are not easy, coming from just the lecture content and github notes. expect to spend anywhere from 1-4 hours attempting it before the recitation if you so choose to.adhy is a great tutor. he makes an effort to go slowly so that we can understand how to approach all the problem set questions, which are typically from past year papers. he is both knowledgeable and makes an effort to clarify everyoneâ€™s doubts every stop of the way. he is also very friendly and approachable. he probably made cs 2030 s less painful too.labs (2 h/week) + lab assignment (1 - 12 h/week): the actual lab sessions arenâ€™t always the most useful. the tas first start with a mini lab problem, related to the lecture or the lab (or sometimes both), breaking down how to approach it and solve the problem. the mini labs range from somewhat useful for understanding to not even related to that weekâ€™s lab assignment, but my tas did put in particular effort to explain them anyway. after that, the tas went through the weekâ€™s lab assignment, explaining what the question was and giving a hint or 2, but not the answers or directly spelling out the approaches (obviously). that being said, when i asked questions they were certainly helpful in answering them. the lab assignments on the other hand were a pain and the bane of my existence. there were many difficulties encountered and often it was hard to solve the problem alone. prof adi made it clear from the start that while discussion was allowed, discussion of the exact implementations and showing peers your code directly is strongly advised against and if there is any plagiarism detected it could result in an immediate failure. it was possible to get stuck on many different parts of the lab assignments and resultantly spend multiple hours for a few days in a row to solve it and pass test cases (or sometimes even compile). thankfully, if you can compile and pass the test cases and follow the design specifications, it generally guaranteed full marks or close to full marks. in the later part of the semester, i often found it useful to first try starting on the lab assignment in the morning after it was released by myself first, then going to the lab session to get help from the tas for troubleshooting, compiling and passing test cases. another major complaint was the programming environment. the process of obtaining and submitting assignments involves the soc servers and github classroom, and thus ubuntu and cli were also involved. learning the cli was not too difficult, and while it was possible to copy the lab assignment files to your local machine, do it on your desired ide and then copy them back to the soc servers and submit, it was not advisable as the practical exams had to be done on the soc servers in vim anyway. for those unfamiliar, vim is a silly, backwards and unproductive development environment (is it even an environment?) designed for people who have too much time to learn shortcuts, commands and believe itâ€™s faster to not use a mouse and not move your hands on the keyboard. iâ€™m not one of those people. vim lacks much of the functionality you would expect from a modern development environment such as vscode (or even idle), and is more in line with notepad on windows. i would strongly encourage enabling mouse support and line numbers the moment you start using vim. the process of using the school servers can sometimes be a bit inconvenient too - you need to use a vpn even in the terrace, the connection can crash and the server can freeze. needless to say, it was not an enjoyable or efficient experience learning to program in vim and i personally will be avoiding it as much as i can after this course.ps: try to get close to full marks in the first 6 lab assignments. then you can choose to not finish lab 7 (itâ€™s extremely long and where people get caught for plagiarism allegedly) and not touch lab 8 (itâ€™s due right before pe 2 but not tested for pe 2).midterms: prof adi themed it with one piece (the anime). it wasnâ€™t easy but also wasnâ€™t too difficult, and the past year practices did somewhat help with preparation for the assessment. it did feel tough while doing the paper, but my results were in line with what i had gotten from the past year papers, and the class average was also about the same as previous semesters. not a whole lot to say here, except for an annoying number of typos, the fact that it was conducted in the mpsh and the clocks not visible to everyone easily, and the surprising fact that the marking scheme was not finalised till more than a week after the paper.pe 1: this felt a bit lazy, mainly because the format of the paper was identical to that of the previous semesterâ€™s pe 1. that also meant that the past year papers did prepare me well for pe 1, and i was able to do pretty much everything i needed to other than pass the test cases (but design was still 10 out of 15 marks). that being said, it was mostly manageable albeit with a lack of time and the fact that the penalty for non-compilation of code was only 75% instead of the 100% in previous semesters probably provided some with consolation. however, the pe took far too long to be graded, only being returned about a week or so before pe 2.pe 2: this was a bloodbath. while again it was somewhat similar in format on first glance to the previous semesterâ€™s pe, so much to the point that prof had forgotten to change some of the mentions of the file names on the question paper, it felt substantially harder. the requirements to create immutable classes were silly and overly restrictive in a nonsensical way that contradicted what had been taught before and the answer scheme for the past year paper (where the suggested answer shown of creating immutable classes would not be accepted for this sem). the use of streams was not complicated in theory, but it seemed to be assessing more the ability to traverse and navigate data structures and encapsulation than the use of streams, monads/functors, lazy/maybe, infinite list or nested classes which were also supposed to be tested. it seemed like a huge waste of time, with the difficulty being in how tedious it was to navigate said data structures, rather than any of the other topics. is this still cs 2030 s?finals: this was perhaps more balanced, though some small elements of the â€˜executionâ€™ of the exam could be better. it was different in format from previous years, 2 semester before being almost all mcq, and the semester before being mostly mcq and mrq with a little of bit of open ended. this year, there were 6 mcq questions (some of them being rather obscure however), and 6 mrq questions (where there were 6 options but at least the question paper stated that partial marks would still be given for partially correct answers, unlike courses like cs 1231 s). there were a few open-ended questions (mostly short answer, except at the end where justification was required for whether code would compile or a given class was a monad) were somewhat manageable and predictable in what they ask (given previous yearsâ€™ papers), and overall the paper was doable. it tested topics from start to end of the course, with some earlier topics (that were already tested in midterms) taken up a notch in complexity, obscurity or difficulty. others, like monads or infinitelist, were thankfully not any more complex than previous yearsâ€™ papers or the problem sets gone through during recitations. overall, the paper was doable without too many surprises, though i could not be certain of many of my answers.see more 30 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ccs dog 24 days agotough mod but learned a lotpe 0:1%(bonus if u didnt get 100% on pe 1 and pe 2)pe 1:15%pe diagnostic quizzes: 5%weekly programming exercises (pes): 5%practical assessment 0: 1%practical assessment 1: 15%practical assessment 2: 25%midterms exam: 20%finals exam: 30%prefacemake no mistake, this module is tough. i feel the need to get this message across right now. it is tough. period. even more so if taken during semester 1. you will know just by looking at the past year papers (pyps). please do keep my name (opâ€™s name) in mind when reading the review as it is a very big contextual clue on my abilities as someone with some form of computing background. i understand that i am going against the grain here with my review so do take my review and others with a healthy pinch of salt. ymmv if you take this course.module workload (weekly)- the weekly quizzes is usually doable because of the unlimited attempts given. if you know the content for the week, you can often finish it in an hour. if not then expect to spend about 2 - 3 hours trying different combinations of answers for the questions since they are mcqs and mrqs (multiple response questions).- the weekly pes are a killer. the time required to complete it can span from a few hours to a few days, depending on your proficiency in the concepts (and also chatgpt skills), as it can be long, unclear and frustrating to complete it. the longest time that i spent was honestly the whole week. sounds absurd but i really did spend that long on it because i just could not figure it out.- i did not attempt the tutorials before recitations so i cannot give an accurate estimate of the time required but they are usually questions from pyps or specific questions created for your understanding. depending on your ta, you may or may not understand the content, based on my experience attending all recitations.lecture- it can be extremely engaging to dozing off boring kind. prof adi is passionate at times but the passion do not translate into good explanation skills. it may be because he knows the subject matter well so itâ€™s hard to explain things. hereâ€™s an example to illustrate my point. try to explain why 1 + 1 = 2. itâ€™s tough right? because youâ€™re so used to it that you find it difficult to explain. in this case, sometimes prof adiâ€™s simple explanation isnâ€™t really simple or easy to follow. it requires certain knowledge to understand and when you do not know what you do not know, it can become a problem. this issue appears multiple times during lectures. sometimes it is better to just read the notes given on github pages instead of listening to the lecture. however, the downside to that is you will miss the live coding examples. the helpfulness of it is questionable because it is very easy to get overwhelmed and side tracked. you lose focus for a sec and you will be lost, rendering the whole thing more confusing. in my opinion, the time used for it will be better off used in breaking down the concepts because you need to understand the concept to code, not understand the code to know the concepts. the slides are bare bones i.e there are more graphics than words. it is honestly not useful at all to me but you may find it useful?recitation- my ta was a new phd student teaching, not prof adi. at times, the ta can be unclear, perhaps because it is his first time teaching recitations, but he does try his best to explain since he was a student before. recitations are only an hour long and sometimes i leave with more doubts than answers. google is your best friend!practicals- i have to say that practicals are done counter-intuitively? the practical session is 2 hours long and has a review of the past weekâ€™s pe and some mini lab exercises to be done before the weekâ€™s pe is introduced to us. there is nothing much to say about the mini labs because they are easy and do not represent the difficulty of the weekly pes. during the review of the past weekâ€™s pe, the explanation of the code given is extremely surface level and this is an issue especially since the focus shifts to functional programming in the second half of the semester. for my session, my lab tas simply showed us the sample code and explained the abstract idea of it, probably because of instructions given to them. it does not go into why a particular line of code is used over another. you are expected to figure out why yourself. hence the counter-intuitiveness of it, you made a mistake but youâ€™re not told why it is a mistake. you have to figure out why yourself but if you knew why it is a mistake then you would not have done it that way right? as other reviewers have mentioned, negative marking is used so you need to know why to not repeat the mistake / progress to the next pe. the feedback given is extremely disappointing because learning requires good feedback. you need to know what and where you went wrong to learn and improve. practicals should be a good way for students to learn since it is hands on coding but the lack of good feedback on your progress hampers the usefulness of it. it becomes a mundane chore to do because you do not know why youâ€™re even there since youâ€™re not really learning much anyway. again, google / chatgpt is your friend.exams / practical assessments- expect them to be more difficult than semester 2. i imagine the increased difficulty is because they can afford to do so. picture failing 450 out of 900 cs year 1 students in semester 2. this will become an infinitelist of backlogs. since semester 1 has lesser students (~ 250 - 300) , the impact will not be as big. time is a really big issue for the assessments. you do not have time to think which is strange given that semester 1 questions require more thinking than semester 2 questions. you need to know the concepts extremely well. it would be best if you could be the java compiler + java virtual machine combo! no kidding.my general review- this module is very messy in terms of content. the object oriented programming part in the first half of the semester is easy to understand but the functional programming part in the second half is just downright confusing because the core ideas are not taught well. examples are map, flatmap, monads and functors etc. ironically, the not well explained topics / concepts are the ones that come out in exams. since things move like a bullet train in university, not understanding your current lecture will impact your learning. unfortunately, this module just does not give good feedback / explanantion to assist you in your learning. youâ€™re better off on the internet asking strangers for help than the teaching team (that you pay for with your tuition fees). the teaching methods of this module should be revamped since it is a core module that students will rely on. the methods of testing knowledge should be changed to be more comprehensive and cumulative. these weightages for assessments and exams though cumulative do not serve students well given the poor teaching done. they merely compound stress on the student. prof adi mention that the weekly pes are a way to push students to understand. i disagree. yes, i can see the potential of it but once again the teaching just does not do it any good. at the end of the semester, i am still not quite sure what i was supposed to learn from this module. java? different programming paradigms? good google / chatgpt skills? i will leave it up to you to decide.you will feel angry, disappointment, sadness and maybe joy if the module is taken in semester 1. this module is not a level playing field. it is very much high risk high reward but that is something you have to accept if you decide to take the module in semester 1. smaller cohort numbers mean you can get as easily as compared to semester 2. however that means youâ€™re also cohort, and unfortunately i succumbed to the challenge, presumably scoring below the 25 th percentile for all but one of the assessments. i am not sure about the takeaways from such a class, however important object oriented programming is.prof ooi coordinated the module, and dr anderson taught the lectures, thankfully quite adequately. tas for recitations were graduate tutors, and for labs, undergraduate students who appear to be quite apt for the task.a certain member of cs 1101 s's teaching team refuses to teach this module, telling me that cs 2030(s) has not been revamped in a decade. this left the students with a number of questionable assignments and strange choices in the design of the course. vim was essentially the only permitted text editor; you would have to ssh into the school machines using vim during the two practical exams. understandably, vim has a good reputation in professional circles, and the indispensability of the command line cannot be understated, but the users of stackoverflow seem to prefer intelligent ides, at least for languages with much boilerplate like java.the course also tried to fit in quite a bit of content sometimes taught in separate modules in other universities, including object oriented design, the intricacies of java with its type system, functional programming using functional interfaces in java (i really hope no one does this in real life), and a little bit on parallelism. with so much content, the pace of the module felt as fast as that of cs 1101 s.the first 3 labs were on object oriented design, requiring the creation of a toy system to simulate a shop - exactly the sort of thing you would expect from a course no one bothered to update. the principles of writing code in a readable and refactorable manner were quite confusing at first, as it was extremely tempting to hack the code until it worked. after that, much of the class was on generics and functional programming with toy programs again, which meant that i forcibly tried whatever permutations i could think of to pass the test cases, instead of stepping back and thinking about the right code to write. the penultimate lab was on streams or "infinitelists" as the course preferred to call it, and it was a huge pain even with two weeks to write under 100 lines of code. it did not help that vim does not provide any hints either.as a natural extension to the labs, practical exams required the rapid-fire completion of code similar to that of the lab assignments. these were done online in my semester, delicately crafted so that most students would not be able to finish the entire task. interestingly, uncompilable code would be given a big fat zero, and quite a number of people, including the otherwise high-achieving ones, might fall into this very trap. a certain member of the discord server told the horror story of submitting an otherwise perfect program, but only getting a single mark out of 25 because of a compilation error.right before the second practical exam, the school of computing servers crashed, and everyone went through an arduous two hour wait before seeing the two hour exam shortened to a singular hour. thankfully, the teaching team was able to resolve most of the problems related to grading this exam without much of an uproar.at the same time, quite many theoretical concepts such as dynamic binding, the theory exams were not too similar to that of labs or practical exams, which meant extra worrying about ideas that i had thought i understood well until the exam revealed the gaping holes in my knowledge.2 hour lab sessions and 1 hour recitation sessions were conducted face to face in my semester - labs mostly included going through the previous weeks' errors, as well as sprinkling a microscopic selection of hints for the next lab, usually proving woefully inadequate. recitations taught the theoretical oddities of java, and as the semester progressed, fewer and fewer people attended the sessions in person, as recordings were all put online and no attendance was taken.all in all, the module might need some overhauling, though the content taught are clearly very useful. it
