sem 2 course coordinator: i guess technically enzio kam? i actually have no idea. but the teaching staff included profs ooi wei tsang, boyd anderson, ashish dandekar.context: prior to this course, reviewer has not done proper object oriented programming (and no, python does not count).tl;dr pretty tough course, be consistent and at the end of the day, don't forget to pat yourself on the back. good teaching of object oriented programming in that i learnt quite a bit. the introduction to bread-and-butter tools like the command line and unix bash will certainly prove helpful. flip side is that you will have anabsolutelytedious time throughout this course.things you learn:1. oop theory- principles of oop (abstraction, encapsulation, info hiding, tell don't ask, polymorphism, lsp, pecs)- type systems (primitives, classes, wrapper classes, abstract types, interfaces, lambdas)- inheritance & composition as means to extend programs- method resolution ("dynamic binding")2. bootleg fp (sorry, java is not a pure fp language)- monads & functors (cute little wrapper objects likerust's option type)- java stream operations ("do things with one pipeline only!!!")3. practical coding (mostly java)- how java manages its memory (stack, heap, metaspace)- java's generic types- how oop principles translate to code that's easier to service, extend, and troubleshoot.- lazy evaluation- introduction to non-sequential programming:- concurrent, asynchronous, and parallel programmingsubjective reviewworkload: 7.5/10 (it takes real conscious effort to stay afloat. the exercises need a lot of planning and coding; therefore they can sometimes take a day or two to do. the upside is your friends are all suffering with you!)enjoyability: 2/10 (subject matter is very contrived. i appreciate the value in learning it, but i honestly cannot say i enjoyed it.)difficulty: 7/10-  pen & paper exams are really mind-twisting and easily exhaust you halfway through.- recent sem 2 practical exams (pes) have you really racing against the clock. they are not conceptually difficult, but don't leave (any) room for you to waffle around and think slowly.- this is in contrast to sem 1 pes, which i heard can be cleared quite quickly despite being more difficult.comments:obligatory cheer because vim and bash are used!!!sorry, but the module is otherwise not at all intrinsically enjoyable.let's... talk about some of the positives first...:- as you can see from above, you learn a lot of concepts which, at least by personal experience, arereallynifty things to have in your back pocket.- you get loads of hands-on time with the exercises.- even for the theory there's loads of help (self-diagnostic quizzes, catch-up sessions etc.)- i had great experiences with recitations! (thanks prof boyd.)sadly, i doubt the negatives are easy fixes...- the elephant in the room here is that java is just a headache-inducing language that has precious little practical use outside of legacy systems. we spend like half our time learning about java's little quirks and intricacies, and it becomesveryhard to know what's transferable to other languages, and what's not. loads of wasted brain cells, if i'll be honest.- the coding experience in this language was also terrible. the debug messages are utterly incoherent and it really forces you to be able to think twice, write once. "getting things right the first try" seems to be a running theme of cs courses at this point, but holding yourself to impossible standards like that is probably not going to do you any service... (the rant stops here)- somewhat insignificantly, i felt stuff like generics and dynamic binding were a bit too convoluted to fully internalise, and i don't quite think it's the teaching team's fault either... certainly hurt my enjoyment, but no suggestions from me here...assessment components 1. weekly self-diagnostic quizzes (total 10) - 5%*2. lab sheets (total 5, where you answer questions about the programming exercises, instead of doing them) - 5%*3. pe 0 (warmup, you only get the 1% if you don't score full marks for pe 1 + pe 2) - 1%4. pe 1 (was about applying oop principles. requires inhuman speed to even get close to completion) - 15%5. pe 2 (about streams, generics, and maybe. was considerably easier) - 25%6. midterm (almost full mcq + stack & heap) - 20%7. final (had some short-answer qns.) - 30%* you can get full marks for each of these components by scoring >= 85%see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ssoc_to_fass 5 months agotaken in sem 2 ay 23/24 (late review)how to not do well in this course?- never ask questions when stuck in a particular concept (polymorphism, generics, wildcard etc.)- giving up on lab excercises after being stuck on the first 2 labs- failing to pick up java as soon as the labs start coming in. this is an oop/fp course, not a java course.- stop going to recitations just because you are lost watching lectures repeatedly- not fully understanding the concepts and the reasoning of answers behind pyps- failing to utilise the (fortnightly?) weekend sessions to ask prof any questions you have about the contentthe formative assessments for this course are of low weightage but take them seriously. you will thank yourself when faced with the 2 pes, which have a combined 40% weightage in total.expected brian cheongduring lectures, prof adi goes through a fair share of slides while annotating them, with a decent portion of live coding. he answers questions during lectures as well and rewards you with rubber ducks for spotting mistakes. he is very active on ed, responding to questions in a very timely manner.lectures were on mondays, with weekly self-diagnostic quizzes due on wednesdays, so you could do them after the lecture when you were more comfortable with content. the next weekâ€™s content and programming exercise were uploaded on wednesday night, with the programming exercises usually due on tuesdays, giving slightly less than a week to finish them.the problem sets for recitations usually consisted of a few questions along with some past year questions for practice (which were not gone through). i attended recitations, but the answers are uploaded after so it probably wouldnâ€™t have made much difference. brian was my recitation ta, and he would go through concepts and the problem set, answering any questions we had.labs generally involved tas going through the previous weekâ€™s programming exercises, such as common mistakes and suggested solutions. after that, they would go through the â€œmini labâ€. â€œmini labâ€s were split into 2 small problems, with the tas live coding one of them, and us given time to finish the other. after that, my tas would call people up to show their solution to the other problem, and finish off by going through the next weekâ€™s programming exercise description and giving small hints (no major spoilers ofc). labs sometimes finished earlier than the allocated time, but i wouldnâ€™t count on it.in my opinion the best place to learn from is the lecture notes as the slides are a bit hard to understand without the explanations. the diagnostic quizzes were very useful in checking my understanding, and help to hold yourself accountable. recitations were an accurate representation of questions that could come out during exams. the lab problems were often very simplistic and did not really help my understanding, but the tas going through programming exercises and weekly content did help.i enjoyed this module, with its fair share of theory and practical work to be done. but i did have my fair share of wrestling with java (thank you @override), and there were times it seemed like we were expected to install jdk 21 in our brain.workload / weeklectures: 2 hlab: 2 hrecitation: 1 hself-diagnostic quizprogramming exerciserecitation problem setcontentobject oriented programmingfunctional programmingconcurrency and parallelismthe full content can be found on the course websiteassessmentsquizzes: 5% (best 10 out of 12, 0.5% each)quizzes were based on lecture content for the week, and are very useful for checking your understanding. they were unlimited attempts with feedback, so these are free marks you must get, even if you donâ€™t really know what you are doing.programming exercises: 5% (8 exercises, 1% each, capped at 5%)the programming exercises were usually given on a weekly basis, with some of them building on previous weekâ€™s work. they can be very time consuming if you arenâ€™t really sure what you are doing, so it might help to discuss with friends. this was explicitly encouraged by prof adi, but you were required to note down who you discussed with in your code. and of course, plagiarism was frowned upon. the exercises are the main source of consistent practice you will get.pa 0: 1% (only used to top up pa 1 and pa 2)we had a mock practical during the labs right before pas, which were a pretty accurate representation of what the actual pa would be like. this is the most realistic warmup you will get, and acted as some sort of last minute indicator of what areas you need to brush up on.pa 1: 15%the focus of this pa was oop, which was tears of the kingdom themed (prof might be having too much fun). we were given 48 hours after the exam to modify code, but only implementation details and not design changes. this basically meant you could only edit method bodies, so the bulk of the work still had to be done during the actual pa. i finished the pa during the allocated time, but unfortunately forgot to write @override on 10 (ten) different methods, dropping my marks quite a bit. familiarity with oop concepts such as inheritance and the java syntax is important, which should be ok if you do the programming exercises.pa 2: 25%the focus of this pa was immutability and streams. the problems are by tasks, each with their own testcases, so they werenâ€™t really interlinked compared to pa 1. do the practice pas to train your functional thinking, and just spam stream methods.midterm: 20%i found the midterms to be pretty tricky, but i feel they were quite lenient in the marking for open ended. prof adi set a jujutsu kaisen themed paper (previous year was one piece), which was quite funny although it meant the class names were a little cancerous to work through (postiveenergy negativeenergy cursedenergy my brain was spinning reading these over and over again). there was a bonus question to reward those who attended lectures.finals: 30%the finals (similar to previous years) had a decent amount of code writing. there was a 9 mark question on implementation with recursivetask, which i think caught many people by surprise (luckily i did the past year paper where this was tested). although i donâ€™t really agree with the suggested answer being like twice the space given i canâ€™t really complain. there were 2 3 x 3 tables of yes and no, with one of them being fully yes, so donâ€™t be like me and question yourself. the mcqs were once again slightly tricky, but there werenâ€™t really any major curveballs. the finals format is usually quite standard, with a bunch of mcqs followed by a monad question, some form of stack and heap, a completablefuture question, and maybe a bit of parallelism.workload: 7/10 enjoyability: 9/10 difficulty: 6/10 gradesquizzes: 5/5 programming exercises: 5/5 pa 0: 1/1 (hopefully, not released)pa 1: 12/15 (@override why)pa 2: 25/25 midterms: 50/60 (curve: ~30/40/50)finals: 78/90 (curve: ~50/65/75)overall: 90.67% (with bonus pa 0 1%)final grade: a+see more 00 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+nngmhngmh 5 months agothe course website is athttps://nus-cs 2030 s.github.io/2425-s 1/index.html, hopefully hopefully this doesn't become a dead linksee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+oong jia cheng 6 months agoediteday 2024/2025 semester 1 syllabus 1) introduction 2) object-oriented programming 3) polymorphism 4) types & exceptions 5) generics 6) wildcards 7) immutability & nested class 8) lambda & lazy 9) infinite list & stream 10) monad & parallel stream 11) asynchronous computation 12) putting things togetherthe aforementioned chapter list is referenced from the titles of the lecture slides. in reality there are 40 chapters, and you can access the notes online.lecturethe lecture is taught by professor adi yoga sidi prabawa, who is the only lecturer for this semester. i personally find it somewhat difficult to understand what he's speaking due to his accent, but he generally cover the notes which you pre-read prior to the lecture pretty closely. it didn't help that he was slightly sick throughout many of the lectures which affected his voice, but i can see his passion in what he is doing, in trying to make this module experience better for his students. for example, he does his best in answering queries posted by students on ed, though sometimes a little more indirectly to cover edge cases. the occasional jokes sprinkled in various lectures made the process more enjoyable.recitationmy recitation slot is also taught by prof adi. due to a timetable planning screwup i often find myself running to the class venue about 20 minutes after class has started, thereby missing out on half the session, but generally the answers provided would give a good view of that was being covered during class.labeach lab comes with a few mini problems to be solved on the spot, followed by a brief of the exercise to be attempted by the following tuesday. 2 of the lab sessions were used for practical assessment 0 and a mock practical assessment 2 practice.assessmentquizzes: 5%programming exercises: 5%practical assessment 0 (week 7): 1%practical assessment 1 (week 7): 15%practical assessment 2 (week 12): 25%midterm assessment (week 7): 20%final assessment: 30%weekly quizzes are released on thursday together with the next week's lecture content, and due on the following wednesday, 2 days after the lecture. you have unlimited attempts for these quizzes and the highest score will be recorded.all programming is done using the terminal with vim, so you must get used to a command line interface very quickly. the early weeks involve building a coffee shop simulation and extending it to incorporate new features, while the later weeks involve building a few monads, which are containers with context: some, maybe, lazy, and infinitelist. i personally found many of the exercises extremely difficult, especially once we reach the part where we are supposed to build these monads, and spent hours on end trying to conjure a code that could make it work, and you should expect to face such an issue as well.pa 0 grades are awarded on the condition that you do not receive full marks for pa 1 & pa 2 combined. the 15-mark, 90 minutes pa 1 aims to test object-oriented programming design by modelling materials within the game, the legend of zelda: tears of the kingdom. it could have been mission impossible, as you have to do a ton of code refactoring within 90 minutes. but thanks to the feedback of previous cohorts, we are allowed to make non-design changes, such as implementing method stubs or adding private methods and fields after the test, which saved the grades of many and put an end to needless hardships.the 25-mark, 120 minutes pa 2 involves candy bags and almost exclusively tests stream processing. since functional programming, and in particular, lambda functions, are involved, it is much less of a typing speed competition, and tests more of your conceptual understanding of how to transform one stream to another. i find it much easier, but because your code must be correct and compilable by the end of the test, i believe many people were penalised.the 60-mark, 60 minutes mid-terms took reference to the jujutsu kaisen manga series, which made the questions and code very wordy and difficult to read compared to past year papers, muddling the subtyping relationships with classes like "sorcerer", "cursedtechnique" and "negativeenergy". in contrast, the 90-mark, 120 minutes finals lacks a storyline and is much easier to read. all 4 aforementioned assessments are closed-book with 1 double-sided a 4 paper allowed as a cheat sheet.conclusioni was a student who took h 2 computing, and exempted myself from cs 1101 s through a placement test. hence, i went into this course without the knowledge that students in cs 1101 s have, which has a rather different way of thinking from how things are done in h 2 computing. i have to admit that halfway through the course, i was almost panicking that i might have made a terrible mistake by proceeding with this move and pitting myself against a high-aptitude cohort filled with computing students from polytechnic who received automatic exemptions, and those who were successful in international competitions. but i managed to be very precise with my code for the practical assessments, which pulled my grades up significantly. it shows the extreme importance of getting your practicals done right for this course.the main reason i was initially struggling was because coming from python back in h 2 computing, i wasn't used to the strong & statically-typed nature of java, and dealing with the typing relationships shenanigans that it has. once the object-oriented programming part of the course comes to an end and we move on to the functional programming part, things became much more intuitive for me. with the benefit of hindsight, i'll say that to do well for the major assessments, it is important that you are clear of the dynamic binding process, type cast checks, the type inference process and stream processing.resultspractical assessment 1: 14/15 practical assessment 2: 24/25 midterm assessment: 36/60 (median: â‰ˆ 39)final exam: 79/90 (median: â‰ˆ 64)estimated total: 87.3%see more 00 classes like "sorcerer", "cursedtechnique" and "negativeenergy". in contrast, the 90-mark, 120 minutes finals lacks a storyline and is much easier to read. all 4 aforementioned assessments are closed-book with 1 double-sided a 4 paper allowed as a cheat sheet.conclusioni was a noi silver medalist who took h 2 computing, and exempted myself from cs 1101 s through a placement test. hence, i went into this course without the knowledge that students in cs 1101 s have, which has a rather different way of thinking from how things are done in h 2 computing. i have to admit that halfway through the course, i was panicking that i might have made a terrible mistake by proceeding with this move and pitting myself against a high-aptitude cohort filled with computing students from polytechnic who received automatic exemptions, and those who were successful in international competitions. but as you can see, i managed to be very precise with my code for the practical assessments, which pulled my grades up significantly above the cohort. it shows the extreme importance of getting your practicals done right for this course.the main reason i was initially struggling was because coming from python back in h 2 computing, i wasn't used to the strong & statically-typed nature of java, and dealing with the typing relationships shenanigans that it has. once the object-oriented programming part of the course comes to an end and we move on to the functional programming part, things became much more intuitive for me. with the benefit of hindsight, i'll say that to do well for the major assessments, it is important that you are clear of the dynamic binding process, type cast checks, the type inference process and stream processing.resultspractical assessment 1: 14/15 animate certain concepts which helps a lot in illustration, especially when it came to the fork-join pool. this makes the slides very useful for revision, as compared to the minimal style in sem 2 though preferences may differ.dr. adi's lectures are also one of the more entertaining ones i've been to. he makes it engaging and often cracks jokes or have memes in his slides to make things less sometimes go slightly off tangent and talk about topics beyond the syllabus. i personally quite enjoyed it as i do think lectures are not meant to ensure you completely understand a topic immediately the same as those in sem 2, with some extra explanation/ code examples added by dr. adi. if you want more details, definitely check out the sem 1 versions. there are some topics like type erasure that improved from those in 23/24 sem 2, as previously (after ex 4) each exercise was based on the previous week's. this meant that if you missed out on 1, catching up is much harder and could easily sem 2 usually feel more robotic and as long as you understand what is going on, it should be quite doable. in sem 1, you would usually have to think further and it is not as straightforward. dr adi take home element this ay which was aimed at making life easisr for us, where we had around 2 days to make non-design changes to our code. this definitely helps with reducing some cases of 0 marks due to compilation error, though if we made any "illegal" changes, the code we submitted at the end of the pe would be used for grading instead. regarding "illegal" changes, there was no clear rule as tested for pe 2, and 0-40 tested for finals- in essence, this course can be broadly split into two parts: object-oriented programming (oop) and functional programming (fp)assessment:- 5% self-diagnostic quizzes: unlimited attempts, 12 quizzes in total, best 10 quizzes counted- 5% programming exercises: 8 exercises in total, 1% per exercise, capped at 5%- 1% pe 0 (1 h): basically just a mock pe 1, only applicable if you don't get full marks for pe 1+pe 2- 15% pe 1 (1.5 h*): new format introduced this year, details below- 25% pe 2 (2 h)- 20% midterms (1 h)- 30% finals (2 h)- starting from 23/24 sem 2, all exams for cs 2030 s are cheatsheet-only.(*) new pe 1 format:- for this semester, we had a new format for pe 1, where were given approximately 48 hoursafter the exam to modify our code. however, we were only allowed to makenon-design changes- to prevent loopholes, prof adi did not give a formal set of guidelines, but in essence, we couldn't modify anything that was public, but could modify anything that was private- if design changes were detected, the changes would be discarded, and grading would be done on the original code archived at the end of pe 1 instead. to my knowledge, these rules wereenforced quite strictly, as i've heard a few friends getting their changes reverted- although i believe this new format was introduced to help prevent students from getting zero for pe 1 due to non-compilation of their code, prof explicitly said that adding missing semi-colons, closing parentheses, etc. would be considered design changes, and thus not allowed, so perhaps it'snot a good idea to rely on thisto make post-exam changesreview:- personally, i found prof adi quite a passionate lecturer, one can definitely sense his enthusiasm for programming languages. he's also very responsive to questions posted on edstem, often replying within 24 hours with detailed responses- however, during lectures, he tends to go into tangents. for example, when were were transitioning from oop to fp, he delved into category theory and class isomorphisms which i found difficult to follow- one nitpick i have with this module is that although the module does fulfill its objective of teaching oop and fp, at times it felt i was just learning how to be thehuman equivalent of a java compiler- many exam questions basically boil down to "does this code compile?" or "what is the output?", which can be very tricky at times (with alternate answers even being found by students and accepted by the prof after the exams)- despite scoring nearly full marks for both midterms and pe 1, i found itimpossibleto finish them both within the time limit. in contrast, pe 2 and finals were significantly easier to finish on time- another thing to note is that the paper formats are different between sem 1 and 2 (main difference is pe 1). for pe 1, in sem 1, you're expected to refactor poorly written code, whereas in sem 2, you're expected to build new code incrementally from scratch- while refactoring sounds easier, i personally found sem 2's format more straightforward, as there's less mental overhead since one can jump into implementing code directly. however, for refactoring, not only do you have to figure out what the optimal implementation is, but you also need time to analyze the messy code provided, and figure out how to modify/use it, as you can't simply delete all classes and start from scratch, because some classes must be retained and used- for sem 1, negative marking was also used, where everyone starts with 15/15, and marks are deducted for each "mistake". theoretically, it was possible to get -15/15 (penalty of -30), though i have to admit in the end prof adi marked extremely leniently for pe 1, as he didn't penalize many things he said he would've penalizedworkload:- as part of the cs trinity, this is a high workload mod. you're basically expected to learn the java programming language, linux terminal commands, and the vim editor within the first 3 weeks- even with prior programming experience, i don't think it'll help a ton, as there are a fair bit of new concepts taught. for instance, did you know that having getters and setters are bad? mindblowing stuff- supposedly, there was an attempt to reduce the workload for the weekly programming exercises, but at least for me, it didn't really feel like that was the case- that said, the workload felt like it got better after pe 1, or maybe fp is just more intuitive to meestimated time spent (tracked throughout the semester):reading notes: 44 hclasses:- description: This course introduces students to the design and implementation of fundamental data structures and algorithms. The course covers basic data structures (linked lists, stacks, queues, hash tables, binary heaps, trees, and graphs), searching and sorting algorithms, and basic analysis of algorithms.
comments: âˆ’+mario lorenzo 5 years agotaken in ay 19/20 sem 1 lecturer: asst prof. harold sohgrading scheme: 5 problem sets (30%), 3 quizzes (20%, pick the highest two scores, 10% each), class participation (10%), final (40%)this is the first time cs 2040 s, as a new version of cs 2040 equivalent, is being offered. cs 2040 s is actually meant for cs students, but as long as there is a slot, you can still bid for one even though you are not a cs student, thus i ended up here :). unlike the other version of cs 2040, cs 2040 s requires one additional prerequisite, which is cs 1231/ma 1100 since students here are expected to be able to do some simple proofs that are being taught. therefore, expect (a lot) faster pace compared to cs 2040 and cs 2040 c. we finished the content of regular cs 2040 by week 11 and did some special non-examinable topics afterwards. some people may also read my cs 1231 module review and wondering why i am able to take cs 1231 and cs 2040 s concurrently. i filed an appeal to the department since i urgently need cs 2040 equivalent this semester to unlock the higher level modules, and the other cs 2040 equivalents clash with my other mods.this module covers basic data structures such as linked lists, heaps, bsts, hash tables and some sorting as well as graph algorithms. the contents are actually pretty shocking and heavy enough to make cs freshmen suffer. brace yourself for mind-twisting problems if you are not getting used to algorithmic problem solving.kudos to prof harold since he is able to make the class entertaining, thus making the module seems slightly easier, and i would like to say that he is one of the best professor in soc for me :). he is also very caring for the students and his explanations are very clear, making the heavy contents more digestible. his tas are also capable, know the contents very well and very responsive when i ask some questions.the five problem sets are released fortnightly and you have 2 weeks to complete each of them. kattis is used as a platform to do the problem sets. the number of compulsory problems from each problem sets range from 3-5 per sets. however, there are many optional problems for practices. the optional problems are crazy and it takes a lot of time to finish, so if you still care about your sanity, please don't attempt it lol since they may use other concepts outside cs 2040 s scopes and you may ended up reading research papers. the 3 quizzes test us on the understanding of the concepts by devising the most "efficient" algorithms to tackle some problems. the final is the nightmare among them. it is a 44 mcqs paper but actually the style of the question is similar to the quizzes, but the format is modified as mcqs. it is very annoying in my opinion since the problem is mostly like "what is the most efficient algorithms that you can think of to solve blablabla?" and there are some big-oh listed as the choices.study hard and lot of effort must be put in to get a fairly decent grade.expected grade: a/a+actual grade: a+see more 50 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+jjasting 98 mario lorenzo 5 years agoi tried to appeal just like you to be able to enter cs 2040 s midterms, finalsmidterms and finals are closed book, with a single 2-sided cheat sheet only.10-ish problem sets released every week-ish on coursemology, making up the bulk of your coursemology xp.lecture review after every lecture that takes about 5 minutes to complete.personal thoughts:seth is a great lecturer, and really fun to have been a student of. this course had a lower workload than i thought, but your mileage may vary. data structures and algorithms felt very intuitive to me.message to others:take this in year 1 semester 2, fellow cs students. this is an important course, probably the most important, as it covers important concepts that will be tested time and time again in your job interviews. if you have the chance to take this under seth gilbert, i highly encourage you to do so. i enjoyed my time thoroughly under him. if you are already comfortable with data structures and algorithms, this course should be a breeze for you. you could take the trinity (cs 2030 s, cs 2040 s, cs 2100) without much trouble in my opinion if cs 2040 s is completely fine for you.workload: very high* - 11 hours / weeki watched every single lecture video (2 + 1 hours), attended every single tutorial class (2 hours). i did every single optional practice, attempted every contest and did every problem set diligently. i prepared for every tutorial class, and prepared for every recitation and some point. this summed up to be an average of about 10 hours per week. in retrospect, i wouldn't have spent this much time. there is no need to prepare for recitations, and tutorials can kind of be skimmed through and "as long as you get the idea, it's fine".  this can be way lower if you skip the (time-consuming) optional practices as well. perhaps, if i could redo this course, â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+mmathguybutnotpurea year agotaken in ay 23/24 sem 1 lecturer: associate professor steven halimcs 2040 s is avery hardcourse and is especially so under prof halim. however, despite the difficulty, the course is extremely rewarding if one manages to survive. prof halim is the best cs professor i've ever come across and his teaching is splendid with strong and distinctive personal charisma. he's able to explain abstract and complicated concepts very clearly with many concrete examples, though his problem sets and exam papers can be very challenging.the tutorials are hybrid sessions of theory and practical. the tutors will make use of the problem sets to reinforce and extend the various concepts taught in lectures, after which there will be a hands-on session during which the students are tasked with a selected programming problem to practise the relevant concepts. prof halim dislikes asking his students to re-invent the wheels, so the main focus of the practical components in this course is to analyse the problems correctly and choose the best design using the ideal data structures, rather than to remember how each data structure or algorithm is implemented.overall, the course is very well structured and paced. recommended even if you are not a cs primary major.expected grade: a-see more 10 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+math-moyu-wangmathguybutnotpurea major? isn't cs 2040 s for computing students only?see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+infiinight 3 years agoay 21/22 sem 2, prof seth gilbert.i did this with the rest of the trinity this sem. if i had to compare with cs 2030 s and cs 2100, i'd say that content wise, cs 2100 has the most content, followed by cs 2030 s and then cs 2040 s. if we're talking about workload, then cs 2030 s would be highest, followed by cs 2100, and then cs 2040 s. difficulty wise will vary, but generally people seem to find cs 2040 s harder than cs 2030 s, with cs 2100 being relatively easy compared to these 2 modules. so looking at it this way, i would say that this mod is not very high workload, and content wise only covers basic concepts in the various topics.i was kind of disappointed by the lack of proofs and rigor in the various algorithms, considering they were expecting us to know how to reason about certain facts about the algorithms while not being rigorous at the same time. i personally think this creates a weak foundation, but for an intro mod, i suppose they're trying to fit as much breadth as possible. nonetheless, prof seth is a great lecturer. i highly recommend taking it under him.i would rate this module as being medium difficulty, with low workload. i can see why people would say this module is high workload, especially if you try to finish all your tutorial questions. i tend to give them a try and just leave it if i can't solve them after awhile, and it worked out for me. this approach made the mod experience much more enjoyable and enriching for me, since i'm just focused on learning rather than clearing the work.if you have to choose 2 out of 3 in the trinity, definitely pick this mod with another mod, as the knowledge here is just way too useful to delay learning it.expected grade: aactual grade: a+see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+xxh 3 years agoay 21/22 sem 2, prof seth gilbertthis is the module with the highest workload i have ever seen. it's really way beyond my expectations. for starters, there are 2 lectures a week (2 hour and 1 hour). content is hard but prof explains it well and in an engaging manner (polls during lectures are fun).the real workload comes from tutorial and recitation questions. tutorial questions are super hard; you spend a long time trying to solve it before tutorial, and if you get a sucky ta, you spend an even longer time trying to digest it after tutorials. recitations introduce whole new data structures sometimes, and for a 1 hour lesson, the number of questions and concepts is frankly insane. my ta is always rushing through and can never quite finish. needless to say, i spend another huge amount of time digesting it after recitations. now for problem sets. there are easier ones and extremely hard ones that i spend sometimes 2 days doing (because i do them on my own with basically no help; but you can always ask your friends for the strategy). i spent basically the whole reading week just to review the tutorial and recitation questions.the biggest problem i had from this module is that you can learn the concepts well and do practice and go through every single tutorial and recitation question, but still be stumped by the exam. it's because there are always questions that require you to be big brain and think out of the box, almost like you need creativity in a sense. it's not just a matter of applying concepts you have learned. and as such, the amount of work you do doesn't always correlate with your grade since those tricky questions you see in your practice will never come out again. yet, it is important to go through the incredibly heavy amount of work and overwhelming content properly because exposure to such questions early will help you with revision for interviews.that being said, i am glad that cs 2040 s is such an incredibly challenging module because it is really important for interviews, and having a good foundation and materials will help you in preparing for interviews in the future. it was pain and suffering to go through it, but just struggle through it and you will definitely not regret trying your best!expected: b+actual: b+see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ddisqus_oj 3 mnqr 4 cp 3 years agoeditedif anyone would like to study for cs 2040 s before hand, here is a public youtube playlist of prof gilbert:playhidesee more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+zhao wei liew 3 years agoeditedtaken in ay 21/22 sem 2 under prof seth gilbert.summary:the content was interesting and the last few questions of each tutorial were usually interesting. the lack of proofs was somewhat disappointing. the workload was quite high due to the many problemsets and the infuriating grader platform. i spent more time on this module than cs 2100 and cs 2106, but less time compared to cs 2030 s.topics:orders of growth, sorting, balanced binary search trees, various other trees, hash tables, simple amortized analysis, graph searching algorithms, shortest path algorithms, topological sorts, minimum spanning trees, heaps, union find data structure, dynamic programming.content:while there may seem like a lot of content, much of it is intuitive and can be derived from a few core definitions and invariants. having a solid grounding in discrete math, especially proofs and combinatorics, helps.i was a bit disappointed at the lack of (rigorous) proofs for many of the claims taught, especially those involving randomization or probability.professors:prof seth is an enthusiastic teacher and i love his teaching.workload:- a 1-hour and a 2-hour lecture per week. negligible exp given as exp.- a 2-hour tutorial every week. level of participation is counted as exp.- a 1-hour recitation every week. negligible exp given.- a quiz after every lecture. exp is awarded.- a problemset after every 1-2 lectures. exp is awarded.- some optional coding practices to farm exp if you need more.- a 2-hour midterm- a 2-hour finalsome percentage of our grades goes to a gamified learning system on coursemology where we have to gain exp to level up. the max level is level 35, which most people should obtain if they are diligent with assignments.the lecture slides were highly understandable which is great if you don't want to watch the lectures.the last few questions of every tutorial were quite insightful and enjoyable to tackle.the problemsets took up a lot of time. what's more infuriating is that coursemology, the grader platform, does not provide meaningful error messages so esoteric bugs are much harder to catch (i.e. using an unsupported java feature or using an incompatible character set).enjoyment: 8/10 difficulty: 5/10 workload: 8/10 importance/usefulness effort into cs 2040 s. sometimes i try to squeeze a 2 hr lecture into 1 hour, and doing the tutorial on the spot. i didn't put in much effort into internalizing the various data structures taught, especially nearing the end when trees and graphs were taught, cuz i was super busy in the second half of the semester.however, there are somethings i would like future students to take away from this review. do not think that cs 1231 s is only useful for proving in this mod.1. ufds is just partitioning a set and hence equivalence relations come strongly into play.2. dag and topological sorting has sheetcontentsearchsortingtreeshashingheapsgraphsdagshortest pathmstdynamic programmingassessmentsweightage was not released for assessments, â€œto prevent min-maxingâ€. what if the module was 100% coursemology? we will never know.coursemology: level 35 for maximum caproblem sets, lecture reviews, and tutorial participation count towards your xp and levels. there are also extra optional exercises you can do for bonus xp. generally, as long as you do your problem sets and lecture reviews mostly correctly, you should be able to hit level 35 without much issue (it was 28650 xp for this semester). there is also an xp leaderboard for the tryhards.problem sets are pretty time consuming at times; some of them have many parts, and many people often fail private testcases which are hard to debug with no information. i hope future iterations do away with this as it just slows down learning and causes stress. lecture reviews are mcq / mrq, pretty short and can be finished in 10 minutes.midtermsfinalshistorically these were notorious for their extremely large mcq weightage (often up to 100%), but this semester they introduced quite a bit of psuedocode writing, which i think is good to test studentâ€™s understanding. midterms had 1 huge avl tree augmentation question, while finals had a mix of dp and graph problems. being able to express your solution clearly is important, i was pretty sure i knew how to solve the problems but ended up rewriting my solution multiple times and it still ended up incorrect because i misread / confused myself. for finals i screwed up quite badly, got like 0 for 2 whole questions, but after appeal managed to get +11 marks. i think there were quite a lot of complaints about the grading, if you think you deserve more marks its worth a shot. heavy dose of copium but i would have preferred a practical exam to test application as having testcases would help with weeding out stupid errors from misreading and off by 1 s but lecturer, professor eldon chung, who was the one heading this course this semester, taught much better and clearer, and mainly attended his lectures for the semester. he starts off every class with "are you ready to learn some algorithms?", regularly pre-empt himself, and teaches very clearly. if i am not wrong, this is his first time heading this course, and i think he has done a great job.recitationmr eldric liew chun tze was my recitation teacher and he does a good job at teaching, though thanks to the sheer amount of content and hundreds of slides that have to be gone through in one hour he sometimes have to skip through a lot of stuff, and you probably have to go back and reread some of the stuff. i also attended 1 recitation with mr muhammad rizki aulia rahman maulana and mr ben leong, and they are good tutors as well, with the former preferring to use the whiteboard, and the latter doing a better job at keeping to the time limit. generally the teaching staff in cs 2040 s are pretty strong and you are in good hands if you take this course.tutorialadmittedly, i often find myself lost when entering or leaving a tutorial session, where you have some theoretical examples where you apply data structures & algorithms to solve problems. similarly i have to go back and reread to understand some of the stuff, and how i can apply what i learnt in lecture for the scenarios.assessmentcoursemology: ??%midterms: ??%finals: ??%the weightage of the assessments are unknown, which according to eldon, is "to avoid people min-maxxing their grades for cs 2040 s or making strategic moves instead of learning as much as they can in this module".for coursemology, there are about 24 lecture reviews to be completed at the end of each lecture, with a pretty tight bonus deadline of as little as 1 day after the lecture ends. since the review is opened sometime after the last lecture slot finishes their class, i recommend that you set a regular reminder to avoid missing out on these lecture reviews. there are also 8 problem sets which are usually due 7 days from their opening. a few optional practices are also available. to get full marks for the coursemology component, your target is to hit level 35 of coursemology. a maximum of level 40 can be attained if you do all mandatory and optional components diligently, which will immortalise yourself in the leaderboard for bragging rights.the 105 minutes, 60 marks midterms cover content up till trees, consisting of 6 questions. the first 2 questions are routine ones about interpreting time complexity and recurrence relations, the next 3 about theoretical sorting, and the last one is a 22 mark question about designing a data structure that could be applied a certain context.the 120 minutes, 70 marks finals focuses on graphs, and consists of 6 questions. the first 2 questions consist of a total of 20 marks of mcqs and short answer questions as is typical in the past. but the next 4 questions involve applying data structures & algorithms, and some heuristics and augmentations taught in the recitation, like super nodes and making graph copies to represent multiple states, to solve novel problems.this makes the midterms and finals questions very different from past semesters, there's less algorithmic analysis of time complexity and invariants, and more practical application of what you have learnt. this is actually much more important for a level-2000 course. however, if you cannot figure out the way to solve a problem correctly and efficiently, you are cooked, so i expect that the grade distribution will be lower this year.conclusionthis is a foundational course mass produced to educate almost a thousand computer science students every year, and i am impressed how well-run it is. it is worth noting that this course is more theoretical than practical. other than the problem sets, we do not actually have to implement anything that we learnt in java. if you can give rough descriptions when applying a solution to a problem, that is good enough. do not be too specific, you will lose marks.speaking as a former h 2 computing student, i found many familiar topics in this course, such as sorting, searching, time complexity, binary search trees, and hashing. i believe this put me at a slight advantage in this course than the typical cs student. however the ideas in h 2 computing are further expanded into in this course, so while it gives you a slight advantage, you still need to put in effort here, especially for the graph topics which were not previously (although, you do use them to write your coursemo problem set solutions, in... j... java....)- how toroughlyanalyze data structures and algorithms (asymptotic time/space complexity, invariants, basics of amortised analysis, expected-time analysis, recursive algorithms)- binary search techniques- sorting algorithms (studied in detail: bubblesort, insertionsort, selectionsort, mergesort, quicksort)- tree data structures (n-ary tree, binary search tree, avl tree (representing balanced bsts), tries, etc.)- hash tables (open addressing, chaining, some funky hash methods)- array-based heaps- graphs assessment: unknown (likely 35% coursemology, 65% midterms and finals. the instructor was unwilling to divulge)this module introduces students to the design and implementation of fundamental data structures and algorithms. the module covers basic data structures (linked lists, stacks, queues, hash tables, binary heaps, trees, and graphs), searching and sorting algorithms, and basic analysis of algorithms.description: this module introduces students to the design and implementation of fundamental data structures and algorithms. the module covers basic data structures (linked lists, stacks, queues, hash tables, binary heaps, trees, and graphs), searching and sorting algorithms, and basic analysis of algorithms.difficulty rating: 6/10 enjoyment rating: 7/10 this was an exciting module that covers a little of everything - mathematics and statistics, algorithm design, data structures, java and object oriented programming. certainly it would be one of the most practically useful classes since algorithms questions are indeed very common in interviews.some mathematics may be taught in this class, especially in the part about hash tables where quite simple statistics is used in a short proof on time complexities. whatever is learnt in cs 1231 s, perhaps except graph searching, may not necessarily be prerequisite knowledge in this course.algorithm design might play second fiddle to theory in this class, which was the focus of the midterms and the finals. much of the course was on time complexities and algorithm analysis, considering the professor's background, for example pivot selection for quicksort, or cuts for graphs. thankfully, prof gilbert made the derivations simple to understand and quite intuitive.programming assignments, i.e. implementing algorithms were done on coursemology in the form of problem sets. these were not too trivial, as the average student may have only touched java as the course started. it also required a good understanding of the theory at first, as coding without having a plan is often not a good idea. instead of toy problems seen perhaps in a number of other classes, the problem sets were part of a larger useful application, such as decoding images or word autocomplete - you had to implement the key procedures to make the application work. certainly they won't be what you would do on leetcode, but it makes learning a fair bit more exciting. there were a number of optional problem sets, but i was too lazy to do them. somehow, there were no problem sets or examinations questions on dynamic programming, however important it may be.quizzes, called lecture trainings, also happened after lectures, and together with problem sets, they contributed to the coursemology grade. to get full marks for this ca component, one would need to hit level 35, but the difficult problem sets meant that it was out of reach to me.tutorials were two hours each week and focused on difficult word problems. since algorithms are not the easiest things to learn, quite a number of people in my tutorial group were quite confused even about the most basic concepts. i heard that even some tas were unable to explain the hardest questions. recitations were even harder than that, and talked about interesting theoretical problems as well - for my session there was basically one person who dominated the entire discussion. i could have learnt a lot more if i had the patience and mental tenacity to really understand what was going on.examinations were two hours each and focused mostly on algorithm correctness and efficiency. about 15 out of 100 marks were dedicated to a slightly tricky design question, similar to the problem sets. you really have to know the tiny details of the algorithms to get the harder questions correct. thankfully, i got around the median score for these two, so it goes to show that the tutorials are way too difficult for the average student.ultimately, this was a very well-designed class, and i really did take home a lot about algorithms though having put a lot less effort into learning than my peers. it was unfortunate that due to my coursemology grade, i incurred a b, which was a little disappointing given that the module did not seem to be bell curved. if it is possible, take this module in semester 2 since seth gilbert will be making algorithms intuitive, and try to learn about applications of algorithms as they guide you. in semester 1, it seems that you may get to do a lot more leetcode style problems.[see my other module reviews athttps://spergiemcsperglord....]see more description: The objective of this course is to familiarise students with the fundamentals of computing devices. Through this course students will understand the basics of data representation, and how the various parts of a computer work, separately and with each other. This allows students to understand the issues in computing devices, and how these issues affect the implementation of solutions. Topics covered include data representation systems, combinational and sequential circuit design techniques, assembly language, processor execution cycles, pipelining, memory hierarchy and input/output systems.

the exam in the allocated time. furthermore is on examplify. imagine typing 32 digits and if u are off by 1 digit u get the whole qn wrong. now imagine doing that 10-20 times in the exam. now imagine that you want to trace the circuit, but guess what, the exam is on examplify so just take your thumb and suck on it cuz ur screwed. now imagine spending the whole exam converting numbers and letters finalworkloadwise, this module has light to moderate workload. unlike other cs modules, it has little to no programming assignments (which i am not particularly strong at) except some simple converting binary to hexadecimal or vice versa, or how quick students can type in 0/1 s for cache especially. this is just... recitation which i didnâ€™t attend, but there was a zoom option. the textbook also isnâ€™t necessary.tutorial attendance is graded, so you probably will go anyway. the ta goes through the tutorial questions. labs on the other hand, can be completed in 15 minutes (or even before going). for the first few you just have to show the ta your code and submit your lab sheet then you can leave. for the later labs you have to build circuits with the logic trainer which i found to be quite fun although a bit annoying at times. so for planning purposes be aware that tutorials usually take the full time while labs generally finish quickly.i suppose this is part of the buildup for cs 2106. learning mips was interesting although having to code in it was not the best. the later chapters on circuit design and concepts such as pipelining and cache were also interesting although being tested on them was a different experience. i enjoyed the lab sessions and finding out about different components such as encoders and multiplexers, with some insight into how to design circuits.workload / weeklecture recitation: 2 hourstutorial: 1 hourlab: 1 hourtutorial sheetlab sheetcontent 1. overview of c programming 2. data representation and number systems 3. pointers and functions 4. arrays, strings, and structures 5. mips 6. instruction set architecture 7. mips datapath 8. mips control 9. boolean algebra 10. logic circuits 11. simplification 12. combinational circuits 13. msi components 14. sequential logic 15. pipelining 16. cacheassessmentstutorial attendance: 5%quizzes: 3%there are weekly canvas quizzes to complete, best of 3 attempts without feedback. as long as you score above 80% overall, you max out this component. they help to check your understanding but are quite easy to forget about.assignments: 12% (3 x 4%)usually you are given about a week to finish it, they are quite straightforward and can be finished in like 1 or 2 hours. submission is done in a canvas quiz so it can be a bit annoying and you need to double check and triple check that you followed the submission format because most questions are autograded.labs: 10%iâ€™ve covered this above, but the lab sheets arenâ€™t very hard to do but you need to do them before going for your lab. i usually just noted down my answers somewhere then took a copy form the lab because printing is troublesome.midterm: 20%half mcq half short answer. content was up to mips control, so the short answers are usually of similar formats to past year papers, such as tracing the inputs / outputs when certain instructions are run, encoding / decoding instructions, counting number of instructions, etc. it is openbook, so you donâ€™t have to worry about having to memorise content. aaron trolled and made the first page of mcq extremely hard (they were the 3 questions with the lowest scores). i felt the short answer was very straightforward on the other hand.finals: 50%if you do the practice papers they are pretty brutal, and the time crunch is real. format is quite straightforward, mcq (in later years) followed by some mips code. they first test that you understand it (how many instructions will run, what is the output, translate it to c) etc., then ask a pipelining question using it (with/without forwarding, early branching, branch prediction) followed by a cache question (hitrate etc.). then thereâ€™s a combinational circuit design question, which is an iq test because some of the solutions are quite hard to come up with. also thereâ€™s a sequential circuit question, which is really just truth table bashing so it is very straightforward. take advantage of the fact that it is open book, and prepare empty truth tables, k-map templates, pipelining tables to make your life easier.the paper is an average prof aaron paper, so thereâ€™s traps everywhere and mcq can be quite troll (there was a question testing logisim symbols). since open ended is short answer, you donâ€™t get to show your working and it is essentially binary marking. if you misread the mips question and get one part wrong it often cascades into the entire question being wrong. the mips code took the branch, and skipped every other element which caught a lot of people off guard. i had to redo my entire pipelining because i realised it took the branch after finishing that part, and had to redo my entire cache because i forgot it skipped elements until the last 5 minutes of the exam.workload: 6/10 enjoyability: 7/10 difficulty: 6/10 gradestutorial attendance: 10/10 (mean: 9.46, 1/10/10/10/10)quizzes: 3/3 (mean:
