(messed up the finals)mr. aaron said that nobody has ever said they liked both parts of the module, so let me be the first to say that, yes, i actually enjoyed both parts of it.the first half of cs 2100 starts with boolean logic and algebra, numerical system and encoding (turning numbers into binary), and tools like k-maps which are used to tackle complex boolean expressions. with this foundation, we learn logic gates (and, or, xor, etc.) and how they can be used to implement basic components such as adders, and from these very basic building blocks create medium and large scale logic and processor units. this is the lowest level you'll go to as part of a cs degree, unless you take an electrical engineering module, and it is very enlightening, because it shows how from fundamental components we can build complex thinking machines - functional abstraction turns up a lot in logic design. boolean algebra is also useful, since binary will come up again in a lot of places in cs, and it pays to be familiar with them.the second half of the module covers mips processor design, architecture and programming. this part starts with learning the mips instruction format and how they correspond to certain high(er) level language constructs - in essence, learning very basic compiler design. then, using a simplified model of the mips processor we are shown how the processor translates mips assembly language into binary which the processor then executes (the datapath). finally pipelining (executing multiple parts of different instructions simultaneously), branch prediction and caching is introduced to speed up the processor. all of these are important concept because they are applicable elsewhere - http pipelining is used by browsers speed up the loading of websites, for instance, and caching reappears as memoization in higher level programming.mr aaron is a good speaker, and though personally i didn't like his style, many of my friends enjoyed attending his lectures. i found them to be a tad slow. i feel that i learned the most from tutorials, which are challenging, but not overly difficult. their difficulty level and format are also similar to the exams, so doing them also helped to prepare for them. pacing throughout the module is fairly even, if (in my opinion) a little slow.assignments and lab reports are easy, and you should score 100% for both. they're a lot of fun to do, and you should prepare for them beforehand. exams are not particularly difficult or unfair, but they are hard to score well for, because there are almost never any method marks, so an incorrect solution to a previous part of a question can derail an entire question. exams have fairly generous time limits, so take your time to check your answers. no calculators were allowed for the mid-terms, and only one handwritten (yes, must be written by hand) single-sided help sheet was allowed. scientific calculators were permitted for the finals, as was one double-sided help sheet.the only negatives of this module is that some of the module content feels a little too tightly focused. i'd rather the module was more about concepts than content. also, mips is not a particularly prevalent cpu architecture, and while it may be more useful pedagogically, it feels that learning about it has limited real life application.ps. i wrote a mips instruction encoder, which you may find useful for the second half of the module:http://meebleforp.com/proje...see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+govind venugopalan 9 years agoeditedtaken in 15/16 sem 1:"ever wondered how do computers work?"granted this module will not teach you that, but it is the foundation of learning more about the lower level hardware and software that makes computers tick. it is compulsory for most computing students and i suggest only taking this as an elective if you are intending to minor in computer science or computer engineering.there are two distinct halves of this module, which are separated by recess week. before recess week, we learn about logic circuits which includes binary arithmetic (and other bases as well), hamming codes, logic and logic gates, logic function expressions, karnaugh maps, msi components, combinational circuits and sequential circuits. very interesting and it is quite important for labs when you are designing your own logic circuits.the second half goes more on the software side, albeit a much much lower level, clsoer to the hardware implementation. here we learn a language which is at a lower level than c, which is assembly. we used the mips architecture in this case, and other topics include performance, instruction set architecture, datapaths, control flow, pipelining (very important) and lastly ending off with learning about the cache.lecturer: aaron tanthis was the first time aaron tan was taking the module alone. usually he would teach the first part, involving logic circuits and then dr. soo would come in after the mid-sem break to teach the second part of the module. the content was always quite heavy in the module so a lot of reading, understanding and memorizing will be involved (memorization will be much less if you have a good cheat sheet :)) the lectures are generally well paced and aaron likes to hold interesting demonstrations using the students to illustrate concepts more clearly. (pay attention to these demonstrations, these demos may be bonus questions!) there are also practice questions which we are meant to do on the spot, and some other which he likes to call "3 second quizzes". again, as i mentioned in another module aaron tan teaches, be sure to take down notes because aaron's slides always leave blanks meant for students to fill on their own. however, these lectures are webcasted so it is not that bad if you missed something. just watch the webcast to catch it again.the lectures are 3 hours per week, with one two hour slot and another one hour slot. generally they are well paced even though sometimes aaron squeezes too much into the friday lecture (and too little into the monday ones). recommended you attend so you can bug him with your numerous questions.continual assessment breakdown:5% tutorial attendancetutor: zhou juntutorials are held weekly with one hour slot. the tutorials are generally quite easy to do, with maybe one or two tricky questions. it is split into two parts. the first part, is meant for discussion on the forums and the rest will be gone through during class. zhou jun is very efficient in covering our tutorials and he expects people to come out write the solutions and asks the class to crtique answers accordingly.it is recommended you attend tutorials for two reasons:1) there are marks allocated for tutorial attendance 2) tutorial solutions which are uploaded are often incomplete. you will only get the full solutions by copying down whatever your tutor goes through during class!15% labslab ta: guo zi hethis is probably the best part of this module. as a physics loving guy, i love to play around with circuits , and making our own logic circuits in this module was a fantastic experience. during the second half of the module, we created circuits using a software called logism, and we also played around with basic assembly programming (seriously quite fun, although you write lines and lines of code). you are advised to do as much of the lab as possible (designing circuits, testing out programs) at home and then do the execution during your lab period. this way you are more than likely to finish your labs on time, and in most cases very early, giving you more free time to catch up on whatever you like. do take note though, don't be careless, as i found out to my cost. it pays to be careful and to bring up your ca mark as much as possible here 10% assignmentswe had a total of three assignments (supposed to be 4 but aaron decided there was no time for the fourth one). the assignments are generally manageable, so yet again do check your answers thoroughly and discuss with friends before handing them in, and try to get close to full marks as possible (it is definitely doable). you normally have about a week to do each assignment, so try and finish as quickly possible.20% mid termsmid-terms were generally ok. a 1 page hand-written cheat sheet is allowed. use it wisely to write down things you normally would need to memorize (e.g. truth tables for various functions, excitation tables for flip flops etc.). the more you squeeze in, the less you need to memorize and are able to focus on the concepts which are key to doing well in this module. do organize your information well as time is of the essence. only downside is no calculators (if i remember correctly). do score highly as well (my batch's mean was about 30 out of maximum of 40 marks). do watch out for the bonus question too :)50%  finalslike the mid-terms, the finals were generally manageable with a few tricky bits here and there. your cheat sheet becomes even more important here especially for assembly language functions, datapath diagrams and pipelining. at this point i would like to reiterate that you should not copy paste your  entire lecture notes into the cheat sheet (you only have one page (both sides) which you are allowed to bring in). put stuff that will make you rely less on memory and more on application of concepts. it greatly aids your studying and will be handy reference in your examinations. calculators are allowed for finals. i only had one regret after the paper of not drawing my own datapath diagram on my cheat sheet despite the ample space avaialbletldr; this module's content is generally easy (given you put in effort), with the exception of pipelining. that stuff, though important to computer science, is bloody confusing and irritating even till now. get as many marks as you can in your ca components and examinations and such consistent performance should guarantee you an a. and most importatntly, prepare your cheat sheet smartly.expected grade: afinal grade: asee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies

description: This twinned course is designed specifically for undergraduate students in the field of software engineering. It aims to equip students with the ability to persuasively communicate technical and non-technical ideas to a diverse audience in spoken and written mediums by utilizing an array of communication elements and frameworks. Students will develop effective communication skills through continuous engagement, reflection, practice and feedback through independent and collaborative learning experiences.
comments: âˆ’+::)4 years agotaken in ay 20/21 sem 2 tutor: noelle catherine wee sok huitwin mod paired with cs 2113 t. there were 2 oral presentations and a few other written assignments along the way.since others have already mentioned what this module entails, i would like to point out some flaws i see in this module and hope that it can be improved for future batches. my personal take on celc modules or any module that has celc embedded in them, is that these "communication" modules does the opposite of teaching stem students to be better presenters and speakers.firstly, they have very strict rules and targets that they want students to meet in presentations or reflections. every assignment is just a case of ticking the checkboxes, despite being a more "artsy" module. even though such presentations would be considered trash, people who managed to tick the checkboxes would get good grades. for example, students are rewarded for speaking at a constant pace, where to me personally, it sounds monotonous and in the context of pitching a product or making a demonstration, would not be ideal. communication skills in this module is often taken out of context and such "skills" and "knowledge" applied in the module is not actually transferable to real life presentations.secondly, professors do not standardize the kind of grades they give their students across classes. in my experience, my class generally had much lower raw scores as compared to other classes when i asked around. however, we are most likely still placed on the same bell-curve, which puts our class at a disadvantage. additionally, despite claims that they try to standardize across different classes, the grading still feels opaque, but i'm in no position to question their grading and effort put into grading.(this is my personal experience and by no means representative of the student who took this mod):since the professors do not have technical knowledge, dr noelle made assumptions about computing and stem students that are uncalled for. for example, things like computing students don't talk, where such things depends on context and mainly because computing mods do not have class participation marks that we need to fight for in class. hence, we are not used to speaking up as much in class, as compared to say business or fass students.secondly, dr noelle has an obvious preference over some of the students in class, and would tend to pick on students she do not like. hence, despite speaking up at every class and trying to pay attention in her class, she still questioned why i did not participate in class, which i am unable to confront her about since my grades were in her hands. another instance of such obvious bias is in feedback sessions for oral presentations, she would be discredit someone who tries to make hand gestures, but praise her favourites for not making any attempt at hand gestures since they are "not comfortable with it". well, i had assumed that a communications module is all about going out of your comfort zone but i guess not when such double standards exist.lastly, i still appreciate the existence of this module, as it had broaden my horizons, allowing me to see how academia is largely out of touch with the real world.this is not my first experience with a celc module/ celc embedded module, neither would it be my last. unfortunately, my experience haven't been the best with the kind of double standards and quality of the modules.see more 30 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+lll 6 years agotaken in ay 18/19 sem 2 tutor: chung shin ping, dianapaired module with cs 2103 t. both modules required us to form a group. previously, there were some requirements needed for each group (must have a female, foreigner, and be different from cs 2103 t group), but the requirements were dropped for the semester i took the module, and we could form any group we want. groups are strictly size 4-5.even before the module started, the cancer of finding groupmates started. instead of choosing groupmates randomly from tutorial groups, many people already pre-formed a group with their friends, and they would all bid for the same tutorial slot. this is very hard to coordinate due to timetable clashes, and this was aggravated by the late announcement of the cs 2103 t and cs 2101â€™s tutorial group pairings. eventually, i found a group of 5. the only common slot available for us was the 8 am slot, unfortunately. as no one likes to wake up at 8 am, the class size was quite small, having only 16 people. note that this number "16" is very special mathematically, that it doesn't allow groups of size 5, because 4*4=16. at the end, our group of 5 had to be split up into 2/3. so, i'd recommend pre-forming groups of size 4, and not 5.the first half of this module was about presentation and communication, while the second half was tied to cs 2103 t.i feel like this module is a waste of time. i spent most of my time at my 8 am class sleeping or doing my own work. in fact, my whole group "prepares" for this class by bringing in other work to do.they taught stuff like how to not offend people by saying "this printer doesn't work this way" over "you shouldn't do this on the printer", the difference being the word "you", because using the word â€œyouâ€ makes it sound like you are accusing the other party or something. to this day, i don't see the difference. they also taught us how to have a meeting, and that our meeting notes must be of exactly some format. in fact, one of the graded components in this module is to hold a fake team meeting, and we would be videoed and graded. i know a group who had a *practice team meeting*. like they met up and held a pre-team meeting to decide exactly what to say during the actual graded meeting.my tutor also wanted every group to wear matching formal attires during presentations. having 1 black shirts 3 white shirts in the group is unacceptable and would probably get some marks penalized. it should either all be same, or 2, 2.since the tutor didn't have technical knowledge on programming, for one of the group reports where we had to jot down problems we faced for the software engineering project, we made up some trash using some technical language. in exact words, we wrote: â€œthe most significant problem encountered was the outage of service of our code collaboration platform from feb 25 to feb 28. we lost some files due to the downtime and had to reschedule some of our milestones. we took 2 days to reproduce the work that we have lost.â€at least the workload for this module is quite low. there is very minimal homework, other than preparing for the presentation (there are only 2 presentations in total).final grade: b (s/u option exercised)see more 20 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ffailing cs student 6 months agotaken in ay 24/25 semester 1 for assessment components, consult other reviews.workloadrelatively light. 3 h tutorial every week. some pre-tutorial preparation to be done (like videos to watch on canvas), and some presentations to prepare for.contentthere are videos to be watched every week that do cover topics like power of voice in presentations, rhetorical devices in pitches, writing of reader-centric user guides, and unessay formats (more on that later).assessmentsca 1: a pair presentation in week 6 about a communication topic. readings/references are provided and typically more than enough content for the presentation, although the quality did vary. communication topics arenâ€™t all exactly about speaking/presenting/pitching, they can involve topics like responding well or active listening. there is a 10 minute individual rehearsal a week or two before the actual presentation, which i thought is a good structure since it does force each person to ensure they have more than sufficient content, and try certain strategies and obtain feedback about them, before condensing the content into just 4 minutes (and as mentioned by another review, that is a strict limit). there is also a q&a section, wherein each presenter is required to answer more than one question.my tutor was very strict when it came to marking of the presentations, with a decent number of my friends obtaining low 60%s in my class and other classes taught my the same tutor, and the class average seeming to be in the mid 60 s, while other classesâ€™ tutors were supposedly a fair bit more lenient. in particular, my tutor seemed to penalise very heavily for not memorising scripts, or not having completely seamless delivery of their lines, which seems a bit unrealistic and rather demanding. additionally, the grading criterion also seemed rather cruel towards presenters who stalled, with a mandatory major deduction in marks. just like cs 2103 t, this seems to be a module designed to tear students down, not build them up.for some reason that is a little beyond me, the module coordinator seems to want peer feedback to feature strongly in ca 1 and ca 2, perhaps even more strongly than feedback from the tutor. iâ€™m not too sure on the rationale for this, but at least my peers all did a good job with peer feedback.ca 2: a pitch in week 13 that seems to be somewhat disconnected from reality, made more difficult by my tutor. the aim is to pitch the significance of the idea for the cs 2103 t tp, which doesnâ€™t seem too bad on first glance, but does get rather annoying. the requirement to create a pitch for a mixed audience, including both technical and non-technical individuals, while addressing various stakeholders, seems unclear. this confusion might arise from the ambiguous requirements in cs 2103 t. early tp decisions in cs 2103 t were guided by user stories, with less emphasis on the pitching requirements of cs 2101. my cs 2101 tutor did not highlight this during early decision-making stages. as a result, my cs 2103 t project prioritized user needs, with other stakeholders, such as managers, industry professionals, and investors, not really being soncidered. this approach lead to unpreparedness for potential criticisms and difficult questions during the pitch. creating a pitch for a diverse audience proved challenging, especially considering real-life examples shared by tutors often target only one or two specific groups. resultantly, the only way i found to engage an audience (just my tutor, honestly) was to make the whole pitch an unskippable 12-15 minute advertisement, rather than a product pitch youâ€™d see in the real world.the same complaints about my tutor from cs 2101 apply here too, in addition to the additional annoyance i had of trying to do a peer evaluation properly only for the presenter i was evaluating to be interrupted by my tutor, while he was answering my tutorâ€™s question.ca 3: this was the user guide that was prepared for cs 2103 t, just submitted again to cs 2101 and graded on things like readability and ease of use. not much to say here, other than to avoid making your user guide too cluttered, and perhaps to provide sufficiently specific setup guidance for the target users (who should be implied in the opening paragraph). additionally, it was slightly funny that ca 3â€™s rubric was poorly formatted, given that it was for an assessment on presentation and visuals.ca 4: an â€˜unessayâ€™ â€˜reflectionâ€™ on what was learnt in the 12 weeks prior, submitted in week 12. it could take on any format other than an essay, which apparently also excludes opinion editorials, but not blogs, according to my tutor. in general, the idea of the â€˜reflectionâ€™ needing to not be an essay and not be too close to an essay resulted in some negotiation with my tutor as to what could be considered one. the formats suggested by the rubric only added to the confusion, as certain formats like blog posts could well resemble essays just like an opinion editorial but were allowed. the variation in what was acceptable seemed a bit wide. some of the suggestions seemed to show a lack of understanding by whoever set the assessment of their formats/audience and perhaps a lack of understanding of media more generally, especially when one takes into account the other requirements, such as the task description and the guiding questions that had to be answered. these requirements included substantiating and providing sufficient evidence, which seemed to be difficult, if not downright contradictory to the format/nature of a comic or infographic, where one expects that there should be fewer words than in a blog post. furthermore, the effort to have a presentable submission varied rather greatly between the different formats, with videos and skits for instance requiring much more effort to storyboard, script, act, film and edit than a simple podcast or blog post.the guiding questions and rubric were also rather long, and i do wonder whether itâ€™s even possible for a single submission to meet all the guiding points and tick all boxes in the rubric while staying within the word/time limit, even in the most essay-like of formats or fastest presentation possible in video form. finally, the demand of defining audience, context and other information (purpose?) seems somewhat strange, since if itâ€™s supposed to be a personal reflection/sharing, then why would one be choosing a medium/form of media that has a natural audience/context that goes far beyond that?closing thoughtsif you dislike talking, presenting or hated those parts of is 1108 or es 2660, you wonâ€™t enjoy this module. in my view, the biggest takeaways from this module were that my tutor, as strict as he is, did appreciate the slides i put a good amount of effort into, and the realisation for myself that pitching isnâ€™t necessarily as hard as i sometimes imagine it to be. other than that, cs 2101 doesnâ€™t seem to teach all that much about communication, isnâ€™t particularly theoretical, and generally is a bit hard to characterise (or maybe, itâ€™s just a time filler because cs 2103 t definitely isnâ€™t 4 units, but also isnâ€™t quite 8 units).see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+kkinggobslayera year agotaken in ay 22/23 sem 1 ca components:team meeting reflections: 10%oral presentation 1: 20%oral presentation 2: 20%user guide: 20%critical reflection: 15%class participation: 15%comments:i noticed that there hasn't been a review for cs 2101 in a while, so i thought i would write one to shed some light on the current iteration of the module. as nus cs students, we are required to take two modules under celc, namely es 2660 and this module cs 2101. having taken es 2660 last semester and cs 2101 this semester, i would say that both modules have their similarities, e.g. both have two 2-hour tutorial slots a week, and both have presentation/speaking components, but ultimately, i feel that they are quite fundamentally different in terms of what they teach.i will not go too in depth but es 2660 focused on developing our critical thinking abilities, learning frameworks to analyse texts, learning how to provide insightful contributions during a panel discussion and even how to craft up a coherent impromptu speech. whereas in cs 2101, we learn how to better communicate (literally). we learn the verbal/non-verbal cues of a presentation, how to resolve conflicts in a group setting, and even how to criticise someone (tactfully).to set some context, tutorials are held in a 20-student physical classroom setting, and there was alot of group discussion and class participation. i had a fantastic tutor that facilitated alot of bantering and chatting within the classroom, and i really enjoyed these interactions alot. honestly speaking, cs 2101 is one of the most fun modules i have taken in nus so far. this is because unlike most other tutorials that i have taken, where the tutor would just be giving a monologue of technical information (cs students can relate), cs 2101's classroom setting really was quite chill and the interactions really reminded me of my secondary school / jc classroom days, where everyone knew each other and there was alot of genuine interactions.for those that are taking this module in the future, please do take it with an open mind! it really is quite a fun module. at the very least, it will be a refreshing break from your heavier workload/content modules. and if you choose to make the most out of it, i really think you can learn some interesting stuff and meet some amazing people!tldr 1 is worst, 5 is bestenjoyment: 5/5 workload: 2/5 difficulty: 2/5 usefulness: 3.5/5 see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+lrock kimberly 7 years agocs 2101 ay 2017/17 sem 1:pretty much an english module for tutor. and really does depend on tutor as different tutors can grade so differently until the average for an assignment for a class can be 10 marks apart. you must attend them as much as possible since participation marks are awarded, which also means a lot of bs-ing in class.this is a purely ca module, so no exams whatsoever. however, there are a lot of graded tasks. there are 2 oral semester 1 assessment componentsca 1 oral presentation: 30%ca 2 oral presentation: 25%ca 3 user guide: 15%ca 4 project comnipresence: 20%participation: 10%workload 1 x 2.5 hourtutorialevery week(shag...)ca 1 oral presentationwas a pair presentation (with an individual "rehearsal") in week 6 about a communication topic. strict 4 mins per person (anything more than that will not be graded).ca 2 oral presentationwas a group (4 - 5 students) product pitch in week 13 for students to pitch and demo their cs 2103 t product. strict 3 mins per person (same as ca 1).ca 3 user guidewas simply submitting your user guide in week 13 (you will have to prepare a user guide for your product in cs 2103 t anyway, so this kinda doesn't require extra effort). this was to grade your user guide on its user-centric-ness, readability and presentation.ca 4 project comnipresencerequired students to submit their individual projects in any format except an essay in week 12. this project had to convey a communication event and a message or lesson learnt from that event through whatever medium students chose to use.thoughtsmany people have been shitting on this mod, but i would like to attempt a neutral take on this mod. i must declare that i absolutely hated this mod.the pros are that firstly, the product pitch and demo helps to prepare you for hackathons and actual product pitches (in an extremely limited capacity, but it still does). this also comes in handy when presenting new features/ideas as a member of a software development team. another pro is that in some way, it does encourage students to develop their communication skills through presentations and class participation.the cons are that the rest of the content in this mod lack substance and are barely useful in your working life. i did enjoy preparing for ca 1 because i like to yap and ca 4 was an interesting submission, but objectively speaking these provide almost no value to you as a cs student or as a software developer.unfortunately we all have to take this mod, so good luck and make the best out of it...ratingsdifficulty: 2/10 enjoyment: 2/10 s/u: 10/10 overall: 3/10 see more 00 replyshare replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+hheadcubea year agotaken in ay 23/24 sem 2 time: 4-6 pmthis module was so unexpectedly fun. after enduring es 2660, you may be wondering whether this compulsory communications module is as boring as that. i beg to differ, so before you decide to burn your precious su on this module, hear me out. this review will mainly cover ca 1 and ca 2. the rest of the components are written assignments and class participation.ca 1 oral presentation 20%this is the first major assessment of this module in which we are allocated in groups of 3. we got to choose a communication topic from the list and created a 9-minute presentation. this was the first time i had to memorise and rehearse for a presentation. balancing both audience engagement and recalling my lines was extremely tough and made me nervous. the good thing about this module was that there were practice presentations where we received amazing feedback to better ourselves for the actual presentation. before the actual presentation, i was breaking out in a cold sweat with my hands shaking. the presentation went well in my perspective but there were things i needed to improve on. my voice projection and engaging tones were my strength, but my pacing was a major issue. my rapid speech made it difficult for the audience to follow along. ca 1 was a defining moment in this module. applying the persuasive techniques taught and conducting a presentation where not only content is graded was a first for me. the skills and feedback received here would help in the next component of this module.ca 2 oral presentation 20%this presentation is on creating a product pitch for the application that was implemented from cs 2103 t. the application would help hiring managers keep track of applicants. we had to create a convincing and enticing pitch to get investors and users to use our product. this presentation was much harder compared to ca 1. we had to decide on how to incorporate some rhetoric devices as well as incorporating a live demonstration of the application. i experienced similar emotions of nervousness and anxiousness. my part was intertwined with another teammate in which he would do a live demonstration of the application. this was nerve-wracking as ensuring both his and my parts go smoothly was a challenge. i was able to demonstrate more confidence and better articulation during this round of presentation. however, some feedback that i received was a specific use of the filler â€œuh likeâ€. i also had a slight recurrence of the same problem of pacing.being able to engage with the audience as well as good team dynamics is crucial in becoming a successful software professional. these skills will be essential in conveying ideas and leading projects successfully. continuous improvement in this communication journey is required by practicing in speech pacing as well as participating in more team projects will indefinitely improve my skills. practice presentations where we received amazing feedback to better ourselves for the actual presentation. before the actual presentation, i was breaking out in a cold sweat with my hands shaking. the presentation went well in my perspective but there were things i needed to improve on. my voice projection and engaging tones were my strength, but my pacing was a major issue. my rapid speech made it difficult for the audience to follow along. ca 1 was a defining moment in this module. applying the persuasive techniques taught and conducting a presentation where not only content is graded was a first for me. the skills and feedback received here would help in the next component of this module.ca 2 oral presentation 20%this presentation is on creating a product pitch for the application that was implemented from cs 2103 t. the application would help hiring managers keep track of applicants. we had to create a convincing and enticing pitch to get investors and users to use our product. this presentation was much harder compared to ca 1. we had to decide on how to incorporate some rhetoric devices as well as incorporating a live demonstration of the application. i experienced similar emotions of nervousness and anxiousness. my part was intertwined with another teammate in which he would do a live demonstration of the application. this was nerve-wracking as ensuring both his and my parts go smoothly was a challenge. i was able to demonstrate more confidence and better articulation during this round of presentation. however, some feedback that i received was a specific use of the filler â€œuh likeâ€. i also had a slight recurrence of the same problem of pacing.being able to engage with the audience as well as good team dynamics is crucial in becoming a successful software 1 oral presentation 20%ca 2 oral presentation 25%ca 3 written user guide 15%ca 4 insightful musings 20%class participation 20%at the start, i was kind of skeptical about what i could gain from a supposed â€œfluffâ€ module. however, after completing the course, i do think that it provided me with some useful soft skills that would be useful to many of us cs students. so read on if you want to learn more. this review will mainly cover on my ca 1 and ca 2 experiences.in ca 1, groups of 3 students were assigned a communication topic (mine was on emotional intelligence) and tasked with demonstrating its value and practical application to your peers (3 min speech + q&a). to be honest, i did not really enjoy presenting on a topic that i wasnâ€™t passionate about. but through this experience, you sort of learn how to tailor any kinds of topic to your audience and presenting ideas clearly and persuasively. my advice for ca 1? start preparing early, practice extensively, and focus on delivering your content naturally. don't rely too heavily on scripts, as they can hinder your ability to connect with your audience. trust me, the more you practice, the more confident and natural your delivery will become.ca 2 felt a lot more meaningful to me, since students get to present on their cs 2103 t product through a product demonstration and pitch to your specific product target audience. personally, this assessment helped to refine my communication skills by compelling me to showcase the technical aspects of my project while effectively communicating its value and potential impact to a non-technical crowd. to excel in ca 2, invest time in crafting a compelling narrative and use visuals to support your message. practice your delivery to ensure a smooth and confident presentation. i found that incorporating personal anecdotes and examples helped me connect with my audience and make my presentation more engaging.throughout the module, i discovered the power of nonverbal communication, a feedback i have often received from my tutor. eye contact, gestures, and vocal variety can significantly impact how your message is received. however, i must emphasize that you need strike a balance and not overdo it, as sometimes i feel that students can come across as forced or unnatural when they overcompensate.take this module with an open mind. itâ€™s important to note that developing communication skills is an ongoing process. don't expect to become a master communicator overnight. it takes practice, self-reflection, and a willingness to take in feedback. embrace the presentations (if you dread them itâ€™s only going to be worse), be open to feedback from both your tutor and your peers, and don't be afraid to experiment with different communication styles. with dedication and practice, you'll be surprised at how much you can grow and improve throughout the semester!expected grade: a-/b+final grade: ?see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow 1.  tutored by ms diana chung; module coordinated by ms anita toh.this module is taken by computer science students together with cs 2103 t to fulfil soc requirements.  it is coordinated and run by staff from the centre for english language communication (celc).  the first half of the semester teaches general communication and workplace interaction skills, while the second half of the semester is heavily linked to the software engineering project from cs 2103 t (such as writing user/developer guides and making presentations for the cs 2103 t project).the module is conducted in a similar style to es 2660 - contact time is via sectional groups of 20 students each, and class participation is expected.  the 20 students in each sectional group will be in the same cs 2103 t tutorial.  there are no midterms or finals, and the s/u option can be exercised on this module.students need to form two sets of groups in this module: in the first half of the semester (for work and assessment not directly related to cs 2103 t), and in the second half of the semester (this will be the grouping for the cs 2103 t software engineering project).  when i took the module, each group was required to contain at least one male, one female, one singaporean, and one non-singaporean student, and no more than two people in the same group for the first half of the semester were allowed to share a group for the second half.  generally, students optimise for their cs 2103 t group (i.e. the second half of the semester) as it would have an impact on their cs 2103 t grade.at the end of the semester, students are required to produce a project portfolio page (ppp) that summarises their contributions to the cs 2103 t project.  this ppp is an extract of relevant sections from the user and developer guides of the cs 2103 t project, and is graded by both cs 2103 t and cs 2101, but to different requirements.  as the length of the ppp is limited to ten pages, there is some contention as to which module's requirements the limited ppp real estate should be allocated to.  since the s/u option can be used for cs 2101 but not cs 2103 t, the choice is clear for many.there are at least three in-class presentations (on content of a non-technical nature) for this module, and some amount of preparation work is required for each of them.see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+jjaycee_disqus 7 years agohi, there are more module reviews here too:https://jiachaonusceg.wordp...cs 2101 effective communication for computing professionalsdifficulty: moderategrade obtained: btutor: ms isabel chewi took cs 2103 t + cs 2101 so i had the same group for cs 2103 t and cs 2101. this module has no lectures and is conducted in tutorials by tutors from celc. most of the tutorials will be for the teaching of the skills and practicing them on the spot so donâ€™t expect to be able to skip them.here is the syllabus:communication skillsapplying communication principles to assignments and in-class discussions (communication process, barriers to communication, listening skills, audience analysis, channels of communication and 7 cs of effective communication)functioning in a team (roles in a team, task facilitation behaviors, conflict resolution)raising intercultural awareness (values, beliefs, and practices, roles and status, language barriers, legal and ethical behavior, non-verbal communication, personal space and time)technical presentation skillspreparing and giving effective presentations on specific topics with emphasis on audience-centeredness, content for delivery with appropriate visual aids, verbal delivery, and nonverbal cuesmaking technical presentations of proposals and software demo (audience analysis, planning the presentation, rehearsing the presentation, making team presentations and handling questions and objections)technical documentation skillscrafting reports that meet the requirements of effective technical communication (audience analysis, purposes, features of technical documents, format and mechanics, logical presentation of information, technical jargon and clear communication, addressing readersâ€™ concerns, editing for completeness and language accuracy)writing a user-friendly developer guide that is clear, concise and accurate (audience-centeredness, guidelines for software documentation, features of a developer guide, integration of text and graphics, editing for completeness and language accuracy)writing critical reflections and responses on issues raised in discussions and project meetingsthis module is graded this way:2 oral presentations (peer teaching and software demo): 30%group oral discussion: 15%project portfolio (containing user and developer guides): 15%reflections: 25%class participation and oral interactions: 15%although attendance for cs 2101 is compulsory, i still enjoyed it. thatâ€™s mostly you are required to discuss the topics with our classmates and much of the content is quite intuitive or even self-explanatory. also, because of the ca grading, there are no finals of this module.other than the slightly higher workload during the semester the only complaint (addressbook and data analytics for teachers) for a general audience (people from diverse backgrounds at the nus roadshows). maybe there is a lesson that iâ€™m not learning here, but it seems to me that the two modules might have conflicting ideas on what we should do for the software.overall, iâ€™m quite disappointed at my b grade which i really donâ€™t know why i deserved. if they could break mostly quite chill except for the 2 oral presentationssee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+govind venugopalan 8 years agotaken in: 16/17 sem 1 if you are cs student, there is no escaping this module (unless you are from usp). in this case, this module is used to equip students with necessary non-technical skills that will help in promoting the product they are trying (or have built). this module is run in conjunction with cs 2103 t (which i believe will be replaced with cs 2113 t for batches after 16/17), where all the documentation and presentations are in relation to the product the team is building in cs 2103 t.the module covers various aspects necessary non-technical aspects in software development, such as establishing a proper work ethic, learning how to work well as a team, and various communication aspects such as producing a user and developer guides, doing a product demonstration and reflecting critically on the entire process. it also teaches how to write proper formal communications such as emails and progress reports. needless to say, a lot of writing and speaking is involved in this module so it is best to be prepared for that.i must emphasize that you "can" choose your groups for this module. it is put in quotes because it depends on the tutor and also on the fact whether all 4 members of your preferred group are able to get the same timeslot for this class. note that the timeslots for cs 2101 must be matched to the corresponding timeslot for 2103 t, which results in much cursing and swearing when planning one's timetable. normally, the composition of an ideal group is that it must have at least one girl and one foreigner. all of this depends on the composition of the class itself, so be prepared to work with someone whom you are not familiar with. in this aspect, i was lucky enough to have a group i was quite familiar with, so i did not face much problems in that aspect.due to the concurrent running of the modules (this and cs 2103 t), there were of course certain problems that came with it. examples include writing a progress report where we had barely started on our projects and some clash in presentation of our user and developer guides (it almost went to the stage when it felt like we needed to produce 2 copies of each , one set for each module, which of course made us very angry). i sincerely hope that our feedback last semester has really had some effect and these concurrency issues are fixed.tutor: ms isabel chewms chew is a great tutor. she keeps the content to the essentials without skimping over the necessary details such that there is ample time for class discussions or group discussions on particular topics. she is always ready to give relevant pointers during our discussions and is always ready to take questions from groups on certain unclear requirements for the portfolio. personally, i enjoyed her lessons very much and i did learn quite a bit from them. she is quite strict on her assessments though, so be sure to always produced your very best work.assessment:oral presentations (two presentations, 15% each)there are two assessed presentations throughout the entire semester (with some other informal ones in between). the first one serves as a "seminar-style" presentation, where your group plays the lecturer on that occasion, telling the class about the topic to be discussed for that week. these include:1) effective listening,2) intercultural communication,3) conflict resolution and negotiation and 4) interview skills.normally each group presents one of these topics (normally 4 groups in a class). there are guiding questions provided, but ultimately the content focus is up to your group to decide. be ready to justify your decisions of your focus in the content so on and so forth.the second presentation, is where you will demonstrate the product you have built for cs 2103 t (i.e. the todo list, for more details, read the 2103 t reviews). you will be given a scenario on where you are doing your demonstration and it pays to have the demonstration be eye-catching as possible (especially to the normal layperson on the street.). so the presentation for this will differ for the 2103 t case, so do as much as possible to make your presentation stand out.for both presentations, you are expected to at least be in smart casual (if not formal), and of course you are expected to be creative and cohesive in your presentations. you can co-ordinate all of this with your group members however you wish to. in addition, there are strict time limits to be adhered to, so it is best to ensure you rehearse your presentations with timing to ensure you don't go overboard and you can streamline your content if required. there will be a q&a segment at the end as well, so you would do well to spot some questions. it is best if your group members all take on the questions in equal measure, so do not hog your questions during q&a (unless you want to risk being marked down big time during peer evaluation).in addition, you will be doing self-evaluations and peer evaluations during presentations as well (i.e. you will be assessing other groups). it pays to provide as much constructive criticism as possible because after all, this is for the betterment of everyone. so make sure you do pay attention to other's people's presentation. a self-evaluation after each presentation is required to be submitted as well. all of these factor into your grades for both presentation and class participation. do note that whatever you provide critique on, people will be looking for those things when you present. so be sure to, as much as possible, not repeat mistakes that were previously made.critical reflections (1 st : 10% , 2 nd: 15%):there are two reflections to be submitted. one is to be submitted online, in the form of a blog post while the other will be done in class. the reflections in both cases have a similar content. they will ask you to reflect on your current experience with your team members and what you have learnt about them and yourself so far. there will be guiding questions involved so there is no need to worry if you feel lost about what to write. for the first reflection, you are required to write responses as well to another person's reflection (comments/observations etc.), within a week of it being posted online (using nus blogs). this is the main reason why you are encouraged to write reflections of substantial length so that the person writing the response at least has something to write about.the second reflection is to be done in class fully, therefore the higher weightage. much of the same content is required, but it is of course made harder under the timed environment. make sure you plan out your points properly, and do not be afraid if you end up finishing slightly earlier than expected (by slightly i mean 20-30 minutes before the end, not 1 hour before the end).  it also does pay to plan out everything properly, as it will lead to a higher chance of the reflection written neater, and hence you will have an easier time doing your word count. there is a soft limit on how much too write so try to hit that benchmark as closely as possible. it does not pay to be concise, neither does it pay for you to ramble on some argument .user guide and developer guide (15%)the user and developer guides are deliverables that relate to the app that you build. the user guide of course acts as a tool to tell the user how to navigate the various features of the app, while the developer guide is used to tell people who wish to build off your app (i.e. people like yourselves), the basic architecture of the app as well as how to contribute and build upon your group's work.it is obvious that the developer guide is technical so cs 2101 will not focus too much on the content of the developer guide, but more on its structure and organisation. the user guide is the one that will come under greater focus. it is important to note that in cs 2101, the presentation of your materials is very important, especially for the user guide. being easy to read and understand is critical in ensuring that the user gets the best experience out of using the app, and that is exactly what graders will be looking for.class participation (15%)this needs little explanation. like most language modules, class participation forms a substantial portion of one's grade. therefore, it is important to not be the silent witness in class, but actively participate in discussions and offer your own points of view/perspectives where required. that being said, don't be a wayang king. letting other people have a say and listening to them is an important communication skill as well. and therefore it too pays a role in good class participation.oral discussion (15%)this is the last assessed component, which basically aims to assess how you play to assist team dynamics. in this particular assessment, you will be put together with 3 other people from other groups, such that each of you is from a different group in the class. following that, you will be given a situation, upon which you need to hold a group meeting/discussion. there is a short period of preparation time and then 15 minutes for the meeting (this is timed so it pays to do proper preparation during the alloted time). again, hogging the limelight and trying to speak as much as possible will again eventually lead to you being penalized for not being an effective listener, which is part of being an effective communicator.tl;dr : a module with a lot of writing and speaking, and it is a necessary skill one will need as a software engineer. hence this module should not be taken lightly. assessments are well spread out, so do your best in each and every one of them. concurrency issues may occur, but hopefully they are ironed out. for those who have an admiring cap to keep, you might want to save an s/u for this module.expected description: This course introduces the necessary conceptual and analytical tools for systematic and rigorous development of software systems. It covers four main areas of software development, namely object-oriented system analysis, object-oriented system modelling and design, implementation, and testing, with emphasis on system modelling and design and implementation of software courses that work cooperatively to fulfill the requirements of the system. Tools and techniques for software development, such as Unified Modelling Language (UML), program specification, and testing methods, will be taught. Major software engineering issues such as modularisation criteria, program correctness, and software quality will also be covered.

(http://www.comp.nus.edu.sg/...to be safe.playhidesee more 20 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+zhiayang 4 years agotaken in ay 20/21 sem 1 (covid -- 100% zoom)prof damithexpected: areceived: a+i can't remember the weightage already, but there's 3 main components: individual project, team project, and final exam. as you'll see below, the assessment is mostly a joke anyway.again, i'll preface this by saying that i don't find prof damith to be a bad lecturer. as is this case with most (most) of the profs in nus, they're good people, but there's just something wrong with the course content or delivery. in this case, it was a mix of both. i can't remember what i wrote for the "official" module feedback, so i'll paraphrase from memory here.in essence, this module should really be called "object oriented software engineering, sponsored by the uml (tm) mafia". java, oop, and uml really go together like flies, rotten fruit, and a bad aftertaste. starting with a high level overview of the problems:(1) objected oriented.-------------------------to put it in short: if i were an average student with not a lot of prior programming experience of *differing paradigms*, what would i walk away from this module with? i'd walk away with the idea that oop is the one true paradigm, because (a) all the tools and environments are already setup to be oop-friendly and everything-else-adverse; (b) the module, the professor, the tutors, they all keep endorsing oop, whether implicitly or explicitly; (c) the starting code given (for the tp) is written in oop, and is even said to be "well-written"; (d) all my friends are writing oop code. i'd graduate with a warped view of programming, with the idea that large software projects invariably end up being oop. in fact, given the structure of the nus compsci curriculum, all you'd graduate with is "oop", and "java streams" (thanks prof henry). tragic.this module completely does not cover any other kinds of programming paradigms. from day 0 and the individual project, it's all objects, classes, oop oop oop. one of the deliverables for the individual project (henceforth ip) was literally "more oop -- implement more oop". this gets worse for the team project (tp). as you might have read from the other, less scathing reviews here, it is a brownfield project, so you start with some existing code. and let me tell you, damn is that field brown. it's not dirt, by the way. let's just say it's... fertiliser.the code you will be given is your typical, enterprise java oop garbage codebase. full of classes pointlessly abstracted out, code that is a sort of "implicit spaghetti", and classes that literally have no state (only methods), and yet are instantiated -- all for a program that doesn't do very much. about that spaghetti -- because of "abstraction" and the "single level of abstraction principle" (abbreviated slap, how fitting), the code *looks* neat, but you'll soon realise that in order to actually grasp the program (addressbook 3 -- ab 3 (https://github.com/se-edu/a..., you end up jumping all over the place. it's bad.in short, this mod pretends to be software engineering, but in reality it is oop engineering. so if i don't write oop code, am i not a software engineer? do i not qualify for the $5 k median starting pay of cs graduates?(2) sponsored by the uml mafia-------------------------------------you better get used to uml, because so much of the finals will be testing uml. guess what -- after this module, i couldn't tell you what the notation for interfaces are any more. does it matter? no. just like the mips mafia (which you will be familiar with if you took/take cs 2100), the uml mafia is another shadowy organisation that somehow manages to get schools all over the world to push uml and treat it like it's the holy grail of program structure/organisation representation. (hint: it's not).here's my personal take:1. for a high level overview, nobody needs such a rigorous, over-specified notation like uml. does it matter what specific methods this specific class has? no -- that's what your ide is for. in fact, the 2103 textbook even states that there isn't a standardised notation for architecture diagrams in uml. god bless.2. for a low level detail, nothing beats reading well-documented code. here's the problem with uml: it's not code. having outdated documentation is already a massive, known problem in the software industry. if programmers can forget (and/or be lazy) to update documentation that's literally right next to the code they're changing (eg. doxygen, javadocs), do you think they'll update a bunch of silly uml diagrams that need to be compiled to silly pictures by a silly tool? probably not. uml will get outdated so much faster than documentation, that the one true source of information is the program source code itself.i won't get into too much detail for the rest of the mod, as the other reviews cover it pretty well. the other thing i want to say is that the mode of assessment frankly sucks. as you might gather, there's 3 main components: the ip, the tp, and the final exam. (i think there might be class participation -- would explain why the tutor keeps name-calling us).here's the thing: literally 90% or more of the class will get full marks for the ip. yes, full marks. as long as you submit a working program that meets the specification (which isn't very hard), there's literally no way you can get below full marks. there's a component where you need to add a gui with javafx, but guess what? there's literally a tutorial that you can copy-and-paste code from, and there you go. all you need to do is change a few pictures and you're done. guess why 80% of the submissions for the ip literally look like reskins of each other?the ip component had weightage of ~20%. what does that mean? it means that it's literally worthless. unless you're a good student, there's no need to put in so much effort into your ip -- just the minimum will get you that 20%. (putting in extra effort, eg. differentiating your program from the rest, probably won't get you any bonuses either).next is the tp, which is ~45% (?) of the grade (more than the final exam). again, given that this was a brownfield project with an existing codebase, from what i could tell, there were 2 kinds of groups -- the kind that basically came up with an entirely new program, and the kind that didn't really change the existing code too much. there was hardly any middle ground, from what i could tell. where does that leave you? it means that even if your team really puts in a lot of effort to make a good submission, there's tens of other teams that are submitting comparable projects. and that means that this bunch will get mostly full marks for the tp component as well.finally, the final exam. so, after getting full marks for the ip, and full or close to full marks for the tp (because you're a good student who put in a lot of effort, and had a good team to carry you, right?), you're still fighting for that a+ with lots of other people on this end of the bell curve. remember how i said you had better dissolve uml paper in water and drink it? in the end, your grade might be determined mostly by the final exam and it's mere ~30% weightage. so what does the final consist of? uml. yes, uml. sure, there's other components like code style, conceptual questions on testing and other stuff, but... uml. seriously, go memorise your uml (or get a good cheatsheet).there's graded components for documentation as well -- on the cs 2103 side, the developer guide. because this isn't 2101, it doesn't need to be *that* polished -- just make sure your uml is correct, and it doesn't look too shabby. it's probably a good idea to designate one person in your team to be in charge of formatting and error-checking, and another to be in charge of polishing the uml.finally, there's the bug-testing part of the assessment, which was... an interesting concept. (not a bad one, mind you). there's 3 parts -- (1) attack other people's tp to find bugs; (2) attack other people's tp documentation to find errors; (3) defend your own tp against attacks by refuting their bogus claims.the problem is that sometimes you might get a group that either (a) is simply too good that there's very few "high-severity" bugs, or (b) the group simply didn't add that much functionality that there are very few new bugs at all. (bugs from ab 3 don't count). when other people file bugs against your project, your team does get to give a rebuttal (including downgrading severity, rejecting it, etc. -- with appropriate justification), and you can counter-rebut a team's justification against your bug reports. the teaching team uses some magical orb of wisdom to decide who wins, and it's not very transparent here. sometimes you get truly stubborn people who insist that your program should work the way they want it, and not the way that you have clearly documented in your user guide. for some reason.of course it's not all bad things; you do learn how to use git+github with a forking workflow, intellij idea (personally i didn't use that piece of bloatware), and how to write tests with junit. the textbook also does *skim through* some code quality fundamentals (like the slap thingy, as well as basic solid stuff from 2030), but not to a great degree. it's not *all* useless.team wise, as others have said, it's better to get together with people you know beforehand, and try to get into the same tutorial group. you get to choose (with caveats), so choose wisely. there's some restrictions that remind me of hdb racial quotas -- can't be all the same gender, needs at least one non-singaporean, etc. -- so either have that token group member already part of your decided group, or form a group of 3-4 people and literally cold call the remaining people (that's what we did -- zoom chat and email "yo you wanna join us") to fill up the 5 people. and don't just pick people you know -- make sure they're competent too. if you end up with a bunch of people who are lackadaisical, the project won't turn out well.tl;dr: uml. it's compulsory, you can't escape this. uml. get good teammates. uml. it's not that hard in a practical sense, but the final exam is important. uml.this review was not sponsored by the uml mafia.see more 21 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ssurvivingcsa year agoeditedthis is by far the "least enjoyable" module i have taken at nus so far.before i type in my review, i would like to first clarify that:1. i love my team and i am really grateful to have teamed up with them.2. prof damith is a very good lecturer that cares about students. he was with us answering questions over the weekends during pe dry run and the actual pe.3. my review is solely on the structure and design of the course, not on any individuals from the teaching team.what went wrong?1. diversity quota: every team must adhere to the diversity guidelines, and factors like gender, race, nationality, etc. will be taken into consideration. this means that minorities like international students or girls do not have a choice to pick their group and will be thrown around by other teams, which sort of sucks because nationality and gender is something that you are born with.2. practical exam: in case you don't know, cs 2103 t pe is when each team will review a project from another team, and report bugs that occur. this resulted in a zero-sum situation where: 1. teams will be desperate to find the bugs of another team that it induces anxiety, and 2. in some cases, the team member who contributed more on the project will more likely produce some bugs unintentionally, and the teammatescan assign the bug reports to themand they will be the only person to tank the mark (otherwise deductions will be split equally among team members). this resulted in some people unwilling to contribute much knowing that it may hurt them in the long run, and i know a couple of teams that have this exact mentality. you see, the pe does not just only create a zero-sum situation among the teams, it also creates a zero-sum situation among the team members within a team!combining the above, this resulted in a few scenarios:1. an international full-time undergraduate got assigned to a group of (existing) friends because theycannot pick their own team for being the minority in the class, ended up doing most of the work, and still got negative peer reviews. i'm not sure if they did well in the finals, but i heard that they ended up getting a b.2. another international full-time undergraduate got assigned to a group of (existing) friends (again) for the same reason. the team agreed to assign bug reports equally. however, toward the very end of pe, the person got more bug reports than they deserved and (again, not sure how they did in finals) ended up getting another low grade.final thoughtsdespite being an international and minority in my class, i am grateful to be assigned to a team of understanding people that are supportive, kind and chill. we ended up working on the project together and solved each others' problems selflessly, not pointing fingers when receiving bug reports and came up with plans together to produce strong counterarguments to those reports. i am really, really grateful to have known them and i really love my team.unfortunately, this is not the case for everyone, although i truly wish everyone in the class could have a similar experience to mine. however, due the rules thatinherently discourage collaboration, certain unfortunate situations may arise inevitably. as an educational institution, i do not think this is how things should be done and i wish things can change for the better. i know some people who would argue that "but that's what happens when you start working in the industry!" you may be right, but do you think an education institution should "encourage" (not sure what is the best word to describe this) this sort of behavior?to be fair, i know that the course have improved over the years because prof. damith always have listened to students' feedbacks and changed things accordingly. however, as of now, i think cs 2103 t is still a wip.see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+dogshitcsstudentstana year agocs 2103 t review. taken in ay 23/24 semester 1 this course killed me. shout-out to my group about 1 day a weeksee more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+bernard 6 years agoeditedtaken in ay 18/19 sem 1 under prof damith chatura rajapakse.this module is the first group software project for computer science students.  for most computer science students, this module is twinned with cs 2101.  some students that are enrolled in special programmes (such as the university scholars programme, or a double degree programme where soc is not their home faculty) often do not need to take cs 2101.  cs 2103 t is the twinned version of this module, while cs 2103 is the non-twinned version.  lectures and exams are combined and they are identical for cs 2103 and cs 2103 t students.  however, cs 2103 t students form project groups with other cs 2103 t students only, because the same project group is required for cs 2101.  project groups are typically formed during the first cs 2101 class.the main reference material for this module is on this website (https://nus-cs 2103-ay 1819 s 1...).  there are two parts to this module - the lectures (which closely follow the reference website) and the group project.for most students, the group project takes up the bulk of time spent on this module.  students were required to either enhance an existing address book application (https://github.com/nus-cs 21...) or morph (i.e. convert) it for a different use case.  the "morph" route is considered the high-risk-high-reward option, because a failure to complete morphing the product is likely to result in an unusable application.  the address book application is written in java, and students will only be graded on the java code that they have written.  this project is graded on a number of aspects, including: product testing by peers and tutors, review of code and coding style, difficulty of your contributions (listed in your project portfolio page), and quality of documentation.the project group must consist of students from the same tutorial group; when i took the module, each group was required to contain at least one male, one female, one singaporean, and one non-singaporean student.  i recommend that you find a group of 3-5 people whom you are comfortable working with before the semester starts, and ballot for the same tutorial group.  this helps to alleviate much of the uncertainty with group work.  despite what cs 2101 tutors might suggest regarding group formation, having more groupmates who are experienced in writing medium-scale software is beneficial to the amount of polish you can give to the product (which results in better project grades).the lectures are about programming practices and design patterns (with a focus on oop in java), as well as working in a software development team.  they are geared towards working with medium- to large-scale software projects, and those intending to work in software engineering in the future.  the content for the final exam comes from the lectures and reference materials.  being sufficiently acquainted with the main reference material (the cs 2103/t website) will allow you to do well for finals.there are no midterms.  finals are closed-book (with help sheet).  the finals come in two parts - the first part is 100 true/false questions to be answered within an hour, and the second part is four open-ended questions to be answered within another hour.see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more heavy. perhaps the teaching team could have reduced the maximum number of bugs that could be reported further, to 4 or 5. and like the complaint about instructions on the feature freeze above, having teaching team (they only have to choose a â€˜more reasonableâ€™ position among bug reports after seeing a two-sided debate, instead of finding bugs, for instance). it makes the whole pe process seem people. note that this number "16" is very special mathematically, that it doesn't allow groups of size 5, because 4*4=16. at the end, our group of 5 had to be split up into 2/3. so, i'd recommend pre-forming groups of size 4, and not 5.unlike cs 2030, we were not forced to use vim, and were actually encouraged to use powerful ides.this module teaches basic software engineering concepts, such as uml, git, ides, unit testing, etc. the concepts would be put into practice in the module project, which is to work on an address book app.  this module has a brown field approach to software engineering, meaning we don't start on a new project from scratch, but instead, take on an existing project (address book) with a very large code base. we could either choose to enhance the address book, or morph it into something else. most people chose to morph it.because the code base is very large, working on the app becomes very tedious. every little change that we did likely had some consequences. for example, just by changing the behaviour of the app a bit to make the queries case insensitive, many of junit testcases start to fail, and we would have to modify/remove the testcases, despite only changing a few lines of code in the logic. tracing the code was also very tedious. after this project, i never want to see another address book.though tedious, being able to work with a large codebase is an extremely useful skill, as we would likely be working on an existing project when we go out for internships. although i did not enjoy working on the project, i felt that it has helped me in my current internship.instead of a midterm, there was a practical, where we tested other group's project, to find bugs. it was held in i 3 using our own laptops, on nus wifi. marks. all the feedback regarding marks were told to us via a bot on github, to the point where we joked that the module is run by a bot.the theory content is not too hard, but there is a lot of description: This course introduces the basic concepts in operating systems and links it with contemporary operating systems (eg. Unix/Linux and Windows). It focuses on OS structuring and architecture, processes, memory management, concurrency and file systems. Topics include kernel architecture, system calls, interrupts, models of processes, process abstraction and services, scheduling, review of physical memory and memory management hardware, kernel memory management, virtual memory and paging, caches, working set, deadlock, mutual exclusion, synchronisation mechanisms, data and metadata in file systems, directories and structure, file system abstraction and operations, OS protection mechanisms, and user authentication.

operating systems is not helpful. moreover, people who study operating systems generally earn more, live longer, and are better looking than those who do not.see more 40 replyshare â€ºshow more â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+homura akemia year agoeditedcs 2106 introduction to operating systemsay 2023/2024 sem 1 profs - dr. colin tan, dr. jialin liweekly classes- 1 x 2 hr recorded lecture- 1 x 1 hr tutorial- 1 x 1 hr labgrading scheme- 50% - final- 20% - midterm- 25% - 4 labs- 5% - tutorial participationestimated time spent (tracked throughout the sem)total ~ 83.5 h- lectures ~ 24.5 h- tutorials ~ 10 h- revision ~ 20 h- lab 1 ~ 8.5 h- lab 2 ~ 5.5 h- lab 3 ~ 7 h- lab 4 ~ 5 h- midterm - 1 h- final - 2 htopics- introduction to os- process abstraction- process scheduling- process alternative - threads- inter- process communication- synchronization- memory management- disjoint memory schemes- virtual memory management- file management introduction- file system implementationsreviewas the title suggests, this course is about operating systems. i feel that this course can be roughly divided into two main parts, processes and threads and related topics, and ram. the 1 st half was tested in midterms, while the 2 nd half  was tested in finals. this mod is quite info dumpy and reminded me of cs 2105 slightly. prof jialin handled lectures for the 1 st half while prof colin handled lectures for the 2 nd half, and all lectures were recorded. there was an extra recorded zoom lecture in week 12 or 13 since we were slightly behind on the content. i think both profs were decent at teaching the topics, personally i like prof colin's lectures, his vibes reminds me of prof aaron a bit.as usual, there are 4 labs in cs 2106. all of the labs are generally quite guided, but i feel they were slightly long, and there are some parts where you have to figure out how to implement it on your own. roughly 2 weeks were given for each lab. you would also have to do a demo for each lab where you run some of the code you wrote. this is the only thing you have to do in the lab slot, you can skip the lab slot if you're already done demoing/plan to demo in a future week. for my semester, lab 1 was about memory allocation in c and building a simple phonebook using malloc. lab 2 was shell scripting and process programming. lab 3 was synchronization mechanisms. lab 4 was contiguous memory allocation and we replaced malloc from the phonebook in lab 1 with our custom malloc. for all labs, we were allowed to work in pairs, and you don't necessarily have to work with the same partner each time. i worked with the same partner for all 4 labs, and for labs 1-3 we would just do the lab individually then compare and fix/combine answers before submitting. for lab 4 i was getting a bit overwhelmed by my other modules, so i ended up mostly just copying my partner's lab, hence the lower time spent.midterm consisted of 20 2 pt mcq items for 1 hour, and one a 4 cheatsheet was allowed. it was kinda annoying how a few of the questions were basically an api check on c memory allocation functions. time felt a bit tight as i only had a few minutes left when i finished. finals format was rather bizarre with a total of 78 marks. it was held via examplify, and we were allowed to access any locally saved or printed materials. there were 5 2 pt mcq questions at the start, then the remaining 68 marks all came from fitb items. there were 5 main items, each of which gave a certain scenario involving memory management, then asked you to compute some values such as the smallest value that causes a segfault or the largest file size that can be stored given an inode specification. they all just asked the final answer, so careless mistakes can be brutal.there was also an issue where the grade for the labs was only recorded for the partner who submitted the lab (only one person had to submit for each pair) due to a miscommunication. this resulted in some people getting 0 for all labs and dropping to cs, ds, and fs. my partner and i happened to submit 2/4 labs each so our grades were fine (originally b+ for me), so i didn't realize something was off. after people started bringing this up, prof colin did eventually admit his mistake with an apology email and tried to fix it asap. the grades finally got fixed on jan 16, 2024.i don't really have any strong feelings for this module. it was conducted alright (aside from the grade issue) and wasn't super heavy. i can see why this class is important though, since it does give a nice overview on how operating systems work (and i finally know what a segfault means when using c++). i personally found the lectures on memory management to be fairly interesting.rating- workload - 7/10- difficulty - 8/10- enjoyment - 5/10 available assessment statsmidterm (/40)- 5 number summary - 0/24/28/32/39- mean - 17.6 expected grade: b+actual grade: a (??? i was below median in midterms)see more 30 in my opinion, to not own a mistake and just accept an additional answer with the expectation that a student would correctly guess the profâ€™s intent (who knows if itâ€™s meant to be a trick question tested, but then proceeded to test none of them. they also mentioned an expectation of the prerequisite knowledge (cs 2100), and indeed caching from that was used. tragically, examplify was used, but at least that allowed for an open-book exam with any sort of digital notes (that could be opened in ms office or a local, non-browser pdf reader of choice). owing to examplifyâ€™s extremely
