elements to many questions that required careful attention, as missing a single detail could cost many marks. by far the most infuriating part of finals, though, was the fact that single final answers to questions were all that determined the marks a question could have, and since there was no way to submit working in examplify, final answers to a long and immensely tedious calculation question could be worth 6 marks at a go (thatâ€™s 6% of the overall grade!). it again seemed lazy or hurried, that such a paper set where such a significant portion of the overall grade was set based on one line answers, and it wasnâ€™t like the paper was without errors (the teaching team did have to make announcements and clarifications during the paper too), without little thought to grade the approach to the question and not just the final answer. a little fun fact: at least 48.25% of the overall grade for this module is on the topic of memoryworkload:not too large, and if anything, slightly less than cs 2100. lectures were 2 h a week and recorded (with the weekly lecture quizzes being available till the end of the week), and the turnout in the lt was strong throughout the semester. i would like to add that both prof jialin and colin are enthusiastic and very knowledgeable, and generally good at explaining concepts in a way that helped me understand the real-world applicability. were somewhat interesting, although storage seems a bit dated since a lot of the abstractions and theories thought there apply to magnetic hard drives that fewer and fewer consumers use daily.that being said, i feel that there is still some room for improvement when it came to the organisation of the module, especially in the way the assessed components were set/conducted. while mistakes in the lab assignments arenâ€™t the end of the world since they only led to me spending more time than i otherwise would have. but as for midterms and finals, i feel that they should have been more thoroughly vetted, or considered allowing students to better showcase their understanding of concepts through more open-ended questions, instead of having only mcq in midterms and only short-response questions in finals where only the final answer was graded. more consistency between semesters, and better availability of pyps and answers, could also have helped me prepare better for finals.see replies âˆ’+yspa year agoediteday 2023/24 semester 2 lecturers: nitya lakshmanan, colin tan keng yanassessmentparticipation (5%)3% from weekly lecture-quizzes (generally 2 attempts allowed with answers revealed after the 1 st).2% from tutorial attendance (allowed to verify just before course ends).labs (25%)labs were more or less biweekly, based on the current lecture topics. lab 1 was a c refresher and labs 2-4 were on bash/ipc, synchronisation (semaphores), and memory allocation (bitmap & linkedlist) respectively.the labs were honestly not as scary/time-consuming as the other reviews made them out to be (albeit the last lab on memory management required some help from a certain intelligent assistant....). they take a bit of tinkering for sure but the test cases should be passable in reasonable time and the accompanying lab reports consist mostly of google-able 1 m/2 m questions. just allocate enough time before the lab demo for debugging and in case the remote unix server (stu/xlog) on which test cases are run has capacity issues.midterm (20%)1 hr closed-book (1 double-sided a 4 cheatsheet allowed) paper worth 40 marks consisting of 20 x 2 m mcqs on the first 5 topics of the course. time management was a bit of an issue for me, but the bigger drama was surrounding the grading of the midterm. many questions were fairly ambiguous, and this combined with arithmetic errors in the official answers led to multiple regrades of the midterm that lasted until week 12/13. additionally, a few questions (particularly 1 on function definitions involving posix threads) may frustrate students who didn't happen to put the relevant info on their cheatsheet.that being said the midterm to me was not itself particularly very difficult or frustrating so if you have the patience to wait for administrative errors to be resolved and you can accept the limitations of your cheatsheet, then its pretty much a straightforward component.final (50%)2 hr closed-book (1 double-sided a 4 cheatsheet allowed) paper worth 80 marks consisting of 10 x 2 m mcqs and 60 m worth of open-ended questions on interleaving, memory, semaphores, and the ext 2 file system.the final was fairly straightforward as well, with an interleaving question straight from tutorial, a semaphores question 90% similar to lab, and a memory question with a very similar template to pyps. there was also more than enough time to do the paper and review it. the catch was that some of the mcqs may be tricky, and most of the answers to the memory questions were single numbers which can be scary since there was no guarantee of partial marks. i just wrote as much working whenever possible to show my thought process. similarly for the semaphores question there was no mention of how syntax errors would be treated so it was mostly estimating as close an answer as possible when handwriting code.overall thoughtsquite an interesting course since it covers a fundamental area of computing. despite being a systems course, it was still a mostly theoretical, high-level overview of how computers abstract and synchronise processes, memory and files in the form of a complex api (the kernel) between applications and the lowest-level devices. i felt quite engaged throughout and although the labs were frustrating at times (c is seriously not it.....), i would say the course was well-administered. profs colin and nitya have different teaching styles (colin is more hyperactive and storyteller-like while nitya is more straightforward to the slides), but they were both clearly comfortable with the subject-matter.if you are traumatised from the million calculations and the boring microscopics of cs 2100, don't fear that from cs 2106. it is much more welcoming as a subject once you get parts of it, the same idea can be reflected throughout. for example, memory management techniques can also be used on file management, so once you understand one, the other is almost the same.through this module, you will gain a lot of insights into what your os is doing while you are surfing the web with your online zoom lecture at the side. basically things like kernel vs user, processes (context switching, storing of processes in ram), virtual memory, resources allocation and management, and secondary storage (file system). on top of that, you will experience some parts of concurrent programming. real fun stuff.workload: 8/10 if you have no experience in c programming, good luck. c being a low level programming language forces you to deal with a lot of weird constraints that are abstracted away in other languages. you will have to deal with your own memory allocation, signal handling and system calling.you will also have to devise some way to synchronise concurrent threads/processes, which is very difficult to come out with a solution quickly. all the labs will take some time to do, try to do them with a friend (if they still allow this), 2 brains are better than 1 (or maybe your brain is better than mine, then can go solo).usefulness: 8/10 this should be basic knowledge for all programmers out there. while the os may handle these load balancing and management for you, i think it is still useful to know what is going on. furthermore, being able to write concurrent programs is quite important. as my internship interviewer once said "why use 1 core when you have 4", while he is explaining to me the importance of concurrency in the current age of technology. inspiring words to live by as a programmer.experience: 8/1010/10 mental torture trying to sem 1 under uncle soo.the syllabus:1. os structure and architecture 2. process management- process abstraction- process scheduling- process alternatives: threads- inter-process communication- synchronization problems 3. memory management- disjoint memory schemes- virtual memory management 4. file management- file system implementations- file system case studies 5. os protection mechanism (um not really for us even though it was in the course outline)1. lecturesi have heard of uncle soo before i took the module, and after taking the module i can see why he has such a great reputation. he attempts to connect with students by drawing memorable analogies for difficult concepts in lecture (e.g. using uncle soo queuing at a western store to illustrate the idea of starvation), and answers questions on the forum promptly. the lecture content is also very stimulating and sometimes mind-boggling (see dining philosophers), and i had fun learning the concepts.2. labsi really enjoyed the labs for this module. they were very interesting, and even though i did not know c before the module we just picked it up quickly along the way (the harder bits were mainly the concepts of semester 1 under dr soon yuen jien.general thoughts: it's an exposure module to operating systems, where you learn to (hopefully) appreciate the design of an operating system. the topics covered can be roughly split into three parts: process, memory and file management, all of which are covered in general detail (not specifics or in-depth), with a few case studies (mostly unix/posix implementations). i really enjoyed the course and the content that is thought would most likely be new /interesting to most cs students (no matter if you have prior programming background).lectures:uncle soo knows how to teach and he knows what he is teaching. he makes use of a lot of analogies while teaching the module (sometimes using himself as the analogy :p).tutorial:held weekly, most of the time there would not be enough time to cover the whole of the week's tutorial sheet. solutions are uploaded online, though it's only limited to content that has not been covered in class. my tutor, marc, is quite a knowledgeable tutor, but he tends to ramble a lot and he is sometimes hard to follow.labs:lab exercises are quite fun, it's mostly emulation of the various os features. all labs are in c (as is the case of any os course). unless you are competent in programming/debugging, i highly recommend that you do not do the labs at the last minute, as due to the nature of the course and c, you may run into unexpected bugs that would only manifest itself every x executions (e.g. timing/race problems).midterms/finals:one handwritten cheatsheet for midterms and two handwritten cheatsheets for finals. since i took it under uncle soo, it's the classic uncle soo-style exam paper. you have to be extremely careful of working out the solution, as there is almost no room for error. his style is such that the answers are the only thing that matters and not your working/method of derivation. in his defense though, the questions are crafted such that it guides you along a certain way of approaching the problem. also, he likes to set extremely tricky questions, which will leave you scratching your head after the exams are over (though it's not of the nitpicking variety).overall, i would say that this module may be difficult to some, but not many people would seriously dread it (especially if uncle soo is the one teaching).expected grade: soo).this module covers the various parts that come together to form an operating system, including process and memory management, file systems, and synchronization (e.g. semaphores, mutexes).  it explains why each process on your computer can execute independently of all the other processes.  some c programming knowledge is assumed - cs 2100's coverage of c is generally sufficient, but more experience with c will make lab assignments easier.this module is rather content-heavy, but logical reasoning might be useful due to the style of exams set by uncle soo (the questions sometimes require creative thinking, and cannot be directly regurgitated from your help sheet).  i would liken this module to cs 2100.uncle soo makes lectures really engaging and easy to follow - amongst all the lecturers whom i have had, he is amongst the best (in terms of teaching ability).  there are weekly tutorials and fortnightly lab sessions, and each lab assignment consists of a in-class demo to the lab ta and a graded homework portion (which requires writing c code).  in general, i've quite enjoyed this module (both the lectures and labs).midterms and finals are closed-book (with help description: This course introduces basic concepts in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML). It adopts the perspective that planning, games, and learning are related types of search problems, and examines the underlying issues, challenges and techniques. Planning/games related topics include tree/graph search, A* search, local search, and adversarial search (e.g., games). Learning related topics include supervised and unsupervised learning, model validation, and neural networks.
comments: âˆ’+luna 2 years agohi mr. ben leong, why was your toxic comment removed?see more 140 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ssoup 2 years agoediteday 23/24 sem 1 prof: rizkikantalopeshared a very insightful and accurate description of the course, and i'm here to provide an alternative take from the perspective of someone who much prefers theory to programming.firstly, everyone gets the 30% coursemology, so it's effectively 50% midterm 50% final. the midterm format is extremely predictable, so if you practice past year papers and learn the handful of techniques well, you'll get a good score and secure 50% of the module just by doing that.the final, on the other hand, is interesting to say the least. to me, it was a messy, frustrating fiasco.i have to give a disclaimer that i'm a theory enjoyer and really don't like coding â€” somewhat of a freak cs major. i loved tutorials when my ta would actually dive into the math that prof rizki chooses to skip in the lecture, and understand the theory behind the brilliance of these ml models we all know and love. i feel that anyone can learn pytorch and create a model in 50 lines of code â€” that part isn't satisfying. and, i really hate looking at code, especially tons of it at once. in the final, when given a spam of data andsomeguidance and left to build an entire model around it, it really feels like that meme:viewhidei can confidently say i spent >18 of that 28 hours on this task, including a proper 5 hours figuring out why nothing works before discovering a small trick, and another many hours debugging a few dimension mismatches in my convnn. it was incredibly painful and stressful, and i felt like giving up at many junctures. it reminded me of cs 2030 s labs, which were some of the darkest experiences of my cs life so far.i understand the profs want to assess practical ml, since ml is so important to everyone, even those not trying to do specifically ml as a career specialisation. however, i personally hated that decision because it isn't a good representation of how much effort we've put into this mod â€” someone with extensive data cleaning/visualisation/sklearn/pytorch experience would crush the assessment. "but that's the case for every mod!" not really, because those things are not the focus of 99% of the semester's content. it's also very much down to luck, as you never know which chosen model design is the best one, at what point it'll overfit, or whether the restrictive test cases accurately reflect the strength of your model.i would've much preferred the introductory cs 2109 s to be foundational and theoretical, including its assessments, rather than being decided by a wild 28-hour war at the end. but keep in mind that this is coming from the perspective of someone who hates code.see more 100 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+ssoupsoupa year agofinal grade: asee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more repliesshow more replies âˆ’+ssoupsoupa year agofinal grade: asee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ian hong yi en 3 years agoeditedtaken in ay 21/22 sem 2, first ever run of this module, "we're building this plane as we fly it"dropped in week 6, received w grade.lecturer: prof ben leong, though his specialisation is not in ai or mllanguage: pythonassessment- coursemology- midterms and finals- closed-book with 1 cheatsheet. prof likes making students make cheatsheets.workload- worse than 2040 s. in ay 23/24 sem 1 lecturer: rizkii think there have been enough criticitisms about this course. if there is a single course which you should avoid as much as possible, it is this one. for those of you who are taking a 2 nd major in cs and thinking of using this course to replace your common core modules (e.g. hs 1501), my suggestion is to take your common core instead because at least those courses are s/u-able.to me, the most ridiculous part of this course is thatnearly 2/3 of the entire syllabus is not tested.sure, you can argue that the machine learning knowledge is "tested" in the final by letting you implement that model, but honestly, let us all admit that you can easily reach the median or upper quartile as long as you know how to smartly do google-oriented programming.the confusing thing in the course structure is that,while claiming that all theories and mathematical contents are not tested, the lecturers still choose to focus overwhelmingly on the theoretical aspects with an absurd level of ignorance on practical skills. every single problem set to me felt like something that i did not learn at all from past lectures, and i have to self-learn all the things from scratch in order to complete it - i mean, what is the point of having this kind of exercises as homework if the techniques used are not taught at all? not to mention the fact that a course with such a strong focus on practical component does not even has a weekly lab session - this means that if you have prior knowledge in implementing machine learning models, you can basically secure the final exam without actually knowing any theory at all.on the other hand, while dr rizki chose to talk about the theory and not the practical during his lectures, he also chose to skip most of the rigorous reasonings behind all theory taught. the so-called "mathematics" he taught during lectures is basically a display of formulae that comes out of nowhere, and he didn't even bother to explain even if you ask him because - quote - "this is very advanced so i fear most of you wouldn't understand" (sure, if you call level 3000 applied maths "very advanced"). so, in short, i don't really understand what they want to teach in this course in the first place - neither the theory nor the practical skills was properly taught and practised.the final was a mess as expected. i spent almost 20 hours on the model until i finally gave up, simply because there are some people with quite advanced practical experience with implementing machine learning and it's nearly impossible to beat them in the bell curve by using what we are able to practise in this course. additionally, i really don't get the rationale behind starting the exam at 8 pm and put the deadline at 2359 the following day. when some students complained, the solution proposed by dr rizki was: sure i can start the exam at the morning, but it will be the morning of the second day, so that means all of you will have much less time to complete the final contest. however, i don't see the reason why the contest can't just start at 8 am and be due at 12 noon the next day. nevertheless, this is another piece of evidence showing how characteristics of the dataset and how your model behaves. up dropping the module as no one realised that the undergraduate office forgot to say that cs 2040 s was a prerequisite. this was the second iteration of the module, and there were unfortunately a great deal of rough edges to be fixed in future semesters. the actual prerequisites for the module are cs 2040 s, ma 1521 and cs 1231 s, but a good understanding of linear algebra is essential.the department decided to make this module compulsory for all cs majors admitted from ay 2021/22 onwards, while removing cs 2105 (computer networks) as a graduation requirement. i am not sure what the department is thinking, but i believe prof ben is also thinking the same way since he keeps saying "due to the infinite wisdom of the department".the class covers more or less the basic topics in ai and machine learning, starting with a refresher on breadth-first and depth-first search, continuing to a* and local search, then to machine learning where regression, classification, neural networks and unsupervised learning were all taught. about 30% of the module was on classical ai, while the rest was on machine learning where there was a lot of mathematics involved.lectures were conducted by prof ben which were quite underwhelming, but that could be because he works with software engineering, not machine learning. i remember going down for one of his lectures, thinking that i understood quite a fair bit after the lecture, but ended up throwing everything away in just one day. thankfully there were other materials on youtube and elsewhere which cleared up some of my doubts.tutorials were conducted weekly for an hour each, where we went through the usual tutorial worksheets. these were a good help to complement what was learnt in lecture, but i couldn't help doing other work during the tutorial since the finals was a practical exam, and the tutorials were theory based. my tutor was very willing to help with my queries and had the patience to type out long form answers to relatively simple questions, so that i could understand the concepts more fully.there were a grand total of 8 problem sets which were done on jupyter notebook and submitted on coursemology, which would be familiar to most readers. problem set 0 was unceremoniously released on the monday of the first week of school, to make life more difficult for us. these were considerably frustrating to complete, partly due to logistical issues. jupyter notebook did not have any debugging functionality, and somethimes a bug triggered seemingly from nowhere would fill up my entire hard disk with an error log if i was particularly unlucky that day. i found pycharm much more useful due to the powerful debugger, but i could not figure out how to use it for the last few problem sets. additionally, coursemology would report my correct answers to be wrong sometimes, and fixing it took me a few consultations with the ta.the mini-project was released in week 4 and due in week 8, but students were advised to work on it during recess week. we had to code an ai to play the game of breakthrough on a 6 by 6 board, and our ais were pit against one another where the winner would gain some xp on coursemology. the task appeared to be quite simple as i only had to implement alpha-beta pruning, but the implementation was much harder to debug than i had expected.the midterms were a 2 hour long theory paper which i performed to my expectations. right after we were released, the answers for the exam were placed on coursemology, so some of us must have checked their answer to great dismay. it was a bit strange to see things like a* search and decision trees tested in the midterms, but never again.the finals, the first time it was held as a practical exam, was conducted in the computer labs where we had to implement breadth-first search, as well as some functions with numpy to perform classification and regression. we were unable to search stackoverflow, which made things quite tricky. the questions were much harder than expected, since the tas overestimated the students' skill level, and the only machine learning questions i could finish were those that were copied verbatim from the mock exam. thankfully, most people looked quite shell-shocked by the end of it all.i believe that most cs students do not like the module, but it is after all a work in progress and i need not be too scathing. another instructor may take over after one or two semesters. perhaps the ai part of the module does not seem too relevant since it is just the graphs part of cs 2040 s with extra steps, but the basics of machine learning could be a useful start if you would like to do more machine learning. if this module is not compulsory, cs 3243 or cs 3244 could be an option since i have heard 5.65, 6.84, 7.66, 9.98 coursemology (30%)5 compulsory and 2 optional problem sets this semester. only one problem set was officially optional which was the first (ps 0) on introduction to python/matrices/numpy. the 2 nd one was optional for those who had already capped at 30% (which is easy due to heavy contributions from psets and tutorials + new in-lecture participation), which was the last one (ps 5) on unsupervised learning.the remaining problem sets from uninformed search to recurrent neural networks were more-or-less compulsory. i spent roughly 2-4 hours on each problem set. they were quite handheld and although some bugs were frustrating, these were figured out eventually with some tinkering/ta help.pretty much everyone in the cohort got 30% (or very close to it) except for some edge cases.midterm (30%)1.5 hr examplify paper worth 80 marks comprising ~50 mcqs/mrqs/fibs. scope was uninformed/informed/local/adversarial search and decision trees. time was quite tight, and so most people committed to the optimal strategy of starting from the back to secure free marks from minimax/ab-pruning/decision trees because they involved 1 straight way of answering while search/heuristics has historically always been a fickle subject with many questions basically amounting to guesses. i hope they fix this eventually because they can't seem to find a good way to test search/heuristics in a nontrivial manner, but i suppose it is what it is.5-number summary (%/30): 5.85/13.8/15.975/18/26.55 final (30%)2 hr examplify paper worth 90 marks comprising 39 mcq/mrq/fibs (the instructors clearly accepted the time-issues from midterm which was nice). there were 2 questions from the 1 st half (a* search, ab-pruning), and the rest from the 2 nd half. since this was the first semester for this final format, no-one including the tas had any idea what was expected. the general sentiment was that unlike previous semesters, all the linear algebra and calculus for ml would actually be relevant. however, the final ended up being more of a "did you pay attention for lecture/tutorial/coursework"-check, and had mostly conceptual questions with pre-u algebra at best. however, there were challenges of ambiguity for several questions (for both midterm and final) of which some were conceded by the instructors, and some not. since the exam was closed-book, it would be to your disadvantage if you left out some useful facts from the course that featured in the exam. moreover, as with most mcq/mrq/fib papers, careless mistakes were more expensive (which partially explains my overall % below), since in the absence of working there is almost no room for benefit-of-doubt other than the goodwill of examiners.i still prefer this to the 28-hour final of previous semesters, though. the 28-hour final demanded close to 1.5 days in the weekend before finals week (especially since it releases at 8 pm saturday, so good luck to any remaining energy you may have on sunday to study for your other finals). moreover, competition was quite insane (read reviews below), and i felt its more likely for average students doing the course alone (i.e. no friends or chatgpt-4 o to collude with) to end-up on the bad side of the curve.5-number summary (%/30): 7.5/17.364/19.8/22.05/27.6 overall thoughtsi honestly did not expect much from this course because of its reputation (tedious psets, annoying midterm, stressful final, etc). in the end i think this was quite a decent introduction to the basics of ai/ml to those like me who knew nothing about it before. i found ml to be especially interesting and cool; finally gaining some understanding of how artificial agents are trained to output the right answers to complicated questions. plus, the underlying calculus and algebra was quite cool to me - my favorite example is the picture below of support vector machines). in fact, i gained the curiosity to check out cs 3264 and cs 4248 (which i had no intention of taking before).viewhidei'm sure they will continue improving this course in the future!expected grade: b/b- (for my ~68% vs overall median of ~73%)actual grade: tbcsee more 00 replyshare description: This course introduces different techniques of designing and analysing algorithms. Students will learn about the framework for algorithm analysis, for example, lower bound arguments, average case analysis, and the theory of NP-completeness. In addition, students are exposed to various algorithm design paradigms. The course serves two purposes: to improve the students' ability to design algorithms in different areas, and to prepare students for the study of more advanced algorithms. The course covers lower and upper bounds, recurrences, basic algorithm paradigms (such as prune-and-search, dynamic programming, branch-and-bound, graph traversal, and randomised approaches), amortized analysis, NP-completeness, and some selected advanced topics.

min cutintractibilitynp completenessapproximationlocal searchrandomizedpersonal thoughts:one of the worst cs courses i've ever taken, not even because of the content.the content is really fine, it will be the most mathematical rigour you will see if you don't plan to take anything too rigorous as a graduation requirement.this course doesn't even have as much mathematical rigour as you think anyway. it's just an example dump of algorithms, more like a primer of what exists in the world.it is hard to understate how bad this course is, to summarise in a single statement, this is essentially a self-studying course.the professor is unresponsive to e-mails, making the head ta release their own solutions "unofficially" through telegram, so we have feedback.the lecture slides are ripped directly from a website online, and are completely untailored to the teaching. the slides are often too long compared to the timeslot, and are handwaved away to "read in your own free time". most of the lecture is examples after examples.here are the said lecture slides:https://www.cs.princeton.ed...the lecture slides often do not have any value added. not much is gained from watching the lecture.the lecture recordings are haphazard. during the first few weeks, recordings were lost unapologetically. if not for a student's unofficial recording, they would be lost.there is little mathematical rigour. we did not learn master's theorem, not small-o and small-omega notation, just examples of applications of the algorithm of the week.the sample exam papers are asking for the mass of the sun. given the lack of rigour, the sample exam papers often feel completely impossible and shouldn't even be given to us.the weekly assignments, to be gone through in tutorial, are not marked timely. for example, as of week 11, only problem sets 1 and 2 are marked and released. there is no feedback for our answers and proof methods.the exam marking style is not great. by enforcing an all-or-nothing system, no differentiation is made. a student that is a little bit off from the real answer (but nonetheless wrong) is awarded exactly equal marks to a student who has no clue what is going on in the question. this is evident from the extremely close marks of the median and upper quartile. (27 and 31)in summary, i don't know what they want from me.without any intervention from the head ta, this course is in shambles. i don't feel my time as a student being respected, throwing all of my submissions into a black hole. i am not getting any feedback.message to others:if you're strong in algorithms or learning is not a concern, by all means, take this course. if you rely on the course chang ee chien.this module is a largely mathematical and theoretical module that covers topics such as big-o notation, sorting/searching, graphs, np-completeness, and associated algorithms in those areas.  proofs of the various algorithms discussed are covered, and students are expected to devise algorithms and write some proofs in the exam.content is relatively light compared to many of the cs 210 x modules, so little memory work is required.  while there are a number of algorithms covered in this module, the exams place significant focus on the ability to devise new algorithms and prove various properties about them.  it is more important to learn the proving techniques and algorithm design techniques rather than memorising the algorithms covered.there are some homework assignments in which students are required to devise and implement a solution to a well-defined problem (similar to the style of many competitive programming questions).  students can complete these assignments in either c++ or java.  these assignments are graded solely on correctness; no marks are awarded/deducted for coding style.  prior knowledge in at least one of those two programming languages is assumed - there is absolutely no c++ or java refresher provided.there are weekly tutorials, where the tutor goes through some tutorial questions.  i suggest that students try out the tutorial questions before the tutorial, so as to get some practice on devising and proving algorithms (which is really important for the exam), and to make it easier to follow the tutor's line of thought.prof chang did not teach this module very rigorously (in the sense that there was less focus onprovingthe correctness and efficiency of algorithms) - he skipped over some algebraic manipulation and placed more focus on intuition instead.  (for a more rigorous cs 3230, i recommend taking the module under a different module coordinator.)  however, his exams were well-designed - all the questions were clear, precise, and mathematically sound - so during the exam, it is generally easy to tell if the answers you have written are likely to be correct.midterms and finals are open-book.  there are no group projects for this module.see description: This course introduces mathematical tools required in the study of computer science. Topics include: (1) Logic and proof techniques: propositions, conditionals, quantifications. (2) Relations and Functions: Equivalence relations and partitions. Partially ordered sets. Well-Ordering Principle. Function equality. Boolean/identity/inverse functions. Bijection. (3) Mathematical formulation of data models (linear model, trees, graphs). (4) Counting and Combinatoric: Pigeonhole Principle. Inclusion-Exclusion Principle. Number of relations on a set, number of injections from one finite set to another, Diagonalization proof: An infinite countable set has an uncountable power set; Algorithmic proof: An infinite set has a countably infinite subset. Subsets of countable sets are countable.

been in good hands with ahighlyexperienced lecturer such as aaron. i was wrong.purportedly, the objectives of the course were to "attain mathematical maturity" (or whatever the answer to q 1 was in the cs 1231 s finals) and to "inculcate mathematical literacy".considering how i was still hearing basic questions in tutorial like "how do i read <a quantified statement>?" in the weeks leading up to the finals, and how the first person to provide any value beyond reading off some slides didn't appear until the very last week of the semester... it's really hard to see how the module achieved its objectives in any way.aaron himself does not help in this respect either. when all else failed, i hoped that an outwardly details-oriented person like aaron would give solutions that could hint me at how i was to "improve".that was not the case (especiallyin the first half of the semester), as his "suggested solutions" are often either erroneous, skip steps, or floutthe very ruleswhich he imposes on us.with that in mind, i would summarise my personal experience with cs 1231 s was dominated by two overarching themes: "pedantry" and "tedium". i actually enjoy discrete mathematics and look upon its use in computer science rather favorably; which leaves me utterly gobsmacked that it was at all possible to engage people with the subject in such a paternalistic and boring manner.rather than focus on the cool and interesting stuff that you can do with discrete mathematics and contextualizing it for computer science students (shoutout to cs 1231 r), aaron appearsmuchmore concerned with whether students can followexcruciatingproof formats andrememberresults to the letter, even if it comes at the expense of their mathematical faculties. this is probably the only math module in which you can get a significant amount of marks just by writing out theformatof an induction proof (without any part of the actual proof, imagine that!)...all in all, the mistaken focus, and manifold poorly-made course conduct decisions, along with aaron's personal charisma (which i guess i don't doubt), contributes to many students' impression of 1231 s as a "wonderful" course that isunfortunatelylike an iq test. in reality, the module is anabject dumpster fireof a 13-week exercise in "how ready are you to jump at every tiny little detail like your life depends on it", offering less than scraps in the way of enrichment and cultivation of interest in proof-based mathematics. (i will say with a completely straight face that i learnt more about proofs and mathematics in ma 1522 than in cs 1231 s...)(i also happen to agree with the person masquerading as "jonathon teo" in this thread... the lectures were taught by professor aaron tan tuck choy, with functions & mathematical induction taught by professor chin wei ngan, and counting taught by dr. ashish deepak dandekar. they are recorded & taught in a hybrid setting through zoom, with a 2-hour and a 1-hour session every week. the portions done by prof aaron comes with ample quirks, quotable quotes (e.g. aiken dueet), stories from past cohorts, that are probably memorable long after you finish this course. the content that is taught in the lecture is generally presented in a pretty structured manner and at a pretty rapid pace, particularly since we miss a few lecture slots due to public holidays, so you should keep pace with the content covered, particularly in topics like relations, functions, cardinality, graphs, and trees.tutorialeach tutorial consists of a couple of questions, mostly proving ones, which are not very intuitive, and it is not obvious on how you should start on those. i often require the end of the week, are not really helping either. it is very wordy, and attempts tov explain how you should prove in this manner, but not the why. given the volume of content involved, youâ€™ll just accept it and move on.assessmenttutorial attendance: 5%2 assignments (week 6 & 12): 20%midterm test (week 8): 25%final exam: 50%both written examinations are open-book with an unlimited amount of pages, and i recommend that you bring your own reference booklet since the course requires elaborate citations of definitions and theorems for the most basic of ideas, sometimes painstakingly so. these documents should also include results you have proven thus far in your tutorials and assignments. there is little point in practising for your examinations using your tutorials, since proving questions are uncommon in our examinations â€“ thereâ€™s 1 of them for midterms and 0 of them during the finals â€“ for the ease of marking the scripts of the 898 students in my cohort. you are better off referencing past year papers.the assignments are generally where you find the proving questions, but even then they arenâ€™t really meant to be very difficult. the examinations however, are extremely tricky. i find myself struggling with accuracy in the mcq sections in particular as i decipher mathematical notations, which pulled my overall grade down significantly, since it comprises 30/50 of the midterms and 46/100 of the finals.conclusionas a former h 3 mathematics student who had some experience with proving using basic formal mathematical statements, i would say that thereâ€™s functions, and the bizarre topic about infinities called cardinality. knowledge from h 2 computing helped in binary tree traversal, thatâ€™s about it. polytechnic students who took diploma plus replies âˆ’+aaikendueet 2 years agoediteday 23/24 sem 1 lecturers: aaron tan, chin wei nganassessment componentstutorial attendance: 5%assignments: 20% (10% each)midterm assessment: 25%final assessment: 50%overviewbefore starting this module, i have been told by many seniors that this is the infamous s/u mod. in fact, in his first lecture, prof aaron did mention some of these rumours too. however, since it was my first semester in nus, i decided to try putting in effort to see if it was as bad as what my seniors have said.the course is generally a comprehensive one on discrete mathematics. it starts off with logic, proving, set theory and relations. after the midterms, we move on to slightly more cancerous stuff like functions and cardinality. the final topics, probability and graphs, are far more manageable, however we did not go into much detail.workloadlow. there is lesser content compared to the other soc modules. however, due to the nature of this course, effort is definitely required to have a strong understanding of the concepts involved. furthermore, assignments and examinations can be insanely difficult, testing content never taught before in lectures/tutorials, so it can be beneficial to practise more in your free time. personally, i sped through lectures at 1.5 x speed and attended tutorials, re-reading lecture notes a week before the examinations alongside spamming past year papers.lectures are 3 hours in total, twice a week, with the second lecture being only 1 hour instead of 2. this year, the profs went hybrid mode, so you can attend physically or on zoom. attendance was not taken. lecture were conducted mostly by prof aaron, while prof chin took one or two topics. i enjoyed prof aaron's lectures as he will attempt to spice things up through live qnas or some interactive components such as playing the monty hall game on stage. in my opinion, the lecture slides are very comprehensive and you can read them without watching the lectures. however, not watching his lectures is generally a bad idea, and you will know why after viewing the first question of the past year papers.tutorials are 2 hours per week. attendance is taken, and the best 10 of 11 sessions are counted in your 5% component. tutorials have both simple and challenging questions, so do not be discouraged if you cannot do some of the lengthy proofs or difficult computation questions! my ta, dr ashish, is extremely knowledgeable and competent. at the start of every lesson, he will give a summary and recap of the key concepts taught in the previous lecture. thereafter, he goes through the tutorial questions. for easier questions, he will call on random students to share their answers, or to write their proofs on the whiteboard. for harder questions, he will simply write out his solution and explain his thought process behind the steps.for every chapter, there will be ungraded canvas quizzes for you to attempt at your own pace. even though they are optional, i highly recommend you to attempt the questions as they are rather challenging and provide a good indication of your level of understanding of the chapter.there are 2 homework assignments given out throughout the semester, and we are given a week to work on them. some of the questions are definitely harder and/or more tedious than the examination questions, so i would advise you to devote a few hours to completing it. the median for each assignment is pretty high too (which makes sense given that this is a take-home assignment). if you are aiming for a high grade, do take this component seriously and try to score full marks, since 20% is quite a lot of marks.i am aware that there is a textbook for the course, however i did not touch it at all. in my opinion, the slides are good enough.examinationsexaminations were fully open book. only printed materials were allowed. calculators were allowed too, though they were only useful for the finals paper (mostly for questions on counting and probability/graphs).midterms was a 1 hour 30 min paper with 15 mcqs (2 marks each) and 4 structured questions. many of the questions do not require working. my cohort did better compared to previous batches and the average was 60.4%. i found the paper to be relatively easy, and was able to complete it well within the stipulated time.finals was a 2 hour paper with 22 mcqs (2 marks each) and 5 structured questions. mcqs tested content taught throughout the semester, however the entire section b was on topics taught after midterms. the paper was much harder than the midterms, and i could not do about 10 marks worth of questions. once again, the test was open book, and many questions (including the entire probability section) did not require working at all.one thing i found respectable was that the teaching team is highly responsive to feedback. a few of our mcqs in finals were re-marked after appeals were made by students.tipsin my opinion, this course is somewhat of an iq test. during examinations, new definitions and concepts may be introduced, and students will have to complete a few questions based on the new information provided. moreover, some of the proofs are really difficult and it takes some degree of brain power to think of the solution under time pressure. hence, i advise incoming students to do more past year papers and ensure you have full content mastery before moving onto the next topic.furthermore, the tutorial solutions can be rather lengthy at times, and it may be tempting to skip them. if you need help, there is an online qna forum called "sets" for you to post your question anonymously. one of the lecturers will reply within a day or two. the professors are extremely helpful and approachable. some students (including me) booked additional consultation slots with prof aaron during the recess/reading week. however, i must warn you that they fill up fast, so do book early to avoid disappointment. prof aaron himself said that his slots were full some time during the reading week.lastly, in this course, you must substantiate all proofs with theorems taught in lecture. the good news is that you are also allowed to reference results/theorems derived in tutorials or assignments. this means that it would be extremely helpful to prepare a cheat sheet with the different theorem names and lecture + slide number / tutorial question number for easy reference during the examinations.final wordshonestly, the curve for this course isn't too bad. it may be discouraging at first, when you are still not very used to mathematical notation, or some time during midterms when you learn relations and functions, followed by cardinality. i strongly urge you to push through. it gets easier over time once you are more familiar with the concepts.till this day, i still don't understand cardinality fully. prof aaron shares similar sentiments, saying that it is one of his weaker topics in the course i believe the weightage for cardinality is low in the final paper, so if you want to ditch a topic, it would be this.overall, for prospective students, this course is rather well-designed, though being an introductory module in discrete mathematics, you do not get to approach certain topics (e.g. graphs) in greater depth. that being said, the highlight of the course is definitely the cute names like aiken, dueet and noasu. you also learn that a knight always tells the truth but a knave always lies. if you are a cs major, you will have to take this course anyway, so i don't think my words have much impact on your decision.for those who want to study beforehand, here's thecs 1231 s website(available to public).overall gradestutorial attendance: 10/10 (median: 10/10)assignment 1: 39/40 (median: 31.5/40)assignment 2: 40/40 (median: 37.5/40)midterms: 47/50 (median: 30/50)finals: 85.5/100 (median: 52/100)expected grade: a+ (91%)actual grade: ???see more 00 replyshare chin wei nganaiken sueetcontent difficultyfor content and slides refer to the cs 1231 s website.some topics might seem counterintuitive at first, such as quantified statements, but i eventually got used to them. notably, prof aaron does reference the textbook a lot in his slides, but he does take out a lot of content from the textbook (for instance, skipping binary and logic gates). some other topics might come naturally if you have done h 2/hl math in jc, since topics like relations and functions are covered then just in less depth. counting and probability and mathematical induction are similar to jc math, so once again that was not much of a challenge. however, there are other topics that took me a long time to wrap my mind around. many of the proofs in functions were not easy, as were concepts like equivalence classes and the abundance and overloading (reuse) of notation sometimes made it confusing. cardinality was an awfully confusing topic that to the day of finals i didnâ€™t really understand, and i believe much of the cohort was in a similar boat - some in the module telegram group suggested just skipping the cardinalty open-ended questions in the exam. overall, the content ranged from understandable to very difficult.workloadnot particularly high if you do the minimum, but if you want to be ahead, expect to spend a lot of time. 3 h of lectures (also broadcasted on zoom and recorded) per week, 2 h of tutorial. attendance is graded in tutorials so to get the 5% you cannot skip more than 1. i spent about 1-4 h (depending on how much time i had) a week trying the tutorial questions before the tutorial, but still couldnâ€™t do many of them. likewise, if you want to read the textbook to be ahead of the content that prof aaron covers (he moves very quickly), expect to spend an additional 2-4 h per week.teachingprof aaron tries to be humorous and engaging, and props to him for putting in the effort. with some topics, he is very good at explaining and breaking down concepts to help the uninitiated understand them. however, with others like cardinality, even after rewatching his lecture i was unable to understand much. the textbook was slightly better but not by a whole lot. he is clearly passionate about the content and teaching it. prof chin seems to target a â€˜higher levelâ€™ of student, perhaps one who already has some groundwork done, some basics understood and has read ahead a little. he is not as engaging and i was at times better served by reading the slides or textbook in my own time, but to each their own. my ta was also great and happy to answer questions, and provided many helpful tips.assessment 5% was from tutorials - just attend them to get 0.5% each time, best 10 of 11 are taken.10% each from assignments 1 and 2 - slightly harder than tutorial questions, but the level mean is extremely high so it was imperative that i got as much as i could correct. presentation, supporting proofs and sufficient explanation were also required.25% from midterms - a bloodbath yet somehow the level did decently well with an average of 60%. i did far worse than the mean, and felt that the mcq questions were more of a test of intelligence and adaptability than understanding of the concept. many of the questions were testing if you could find extreme cases and whether they would fit into the definition of the concept or symbol or terminology being used, rather than an understanding of the concept that might be sufficient for application, which was both pointless and painful. scoring far below average killed my motivation for the rest of the module.50% from finals - just as terrible as midterms, though not particularly weirder or significantly more difficult than previous yearsâ€™ finals. once again, just like midterms, it felt like a test of intelligence because there were instances where terms were redefined or new terms were introduced, just to test if you can understand the new definition and apply it instead of testing your understanding of the concept that was taught in class. the usual testing of definitions by looking for extremes showed up. while the usual long open-ended graphs/trees and counting/probability questions showed up, the difficulty was increased, as was that of mathematical induction. many of my peers felt that given all these quirks, there was little to no point studying and practicing for finals, and i canâ€™t really debate that given that preparation for finals didnâ€™t get me all that many questions correct. for the matter, it might be more worthwhile to retry tutorial questions instead of past year papersâ€¦concluding wordsprof aaron does try to make the module interesting and enjoyable, and if not for the assessments i might actually enjoy the challenge. but both midterms and finals were hugely discouraging, and the assessment structure seems to remain - very difficult for not much of a tangible reason (at least not at âˆ’+llog 2 years agoediteday 22/23 sem 1: professor aaron tan tuck choy and leong hon waii would like to give a different take on this module.even though this module is notorious for being difficult, at the end of the day, it really boils down to your math inclination (doing well in high school math does not really count if it is due to sheer practice, instead of understanding of the concepts) and logic and reasoning. it may even be the easiest cs module youâ€™ve taken, since this is basically a math mod (albeit a unique one as it feels puzzle-like). unlike the other math mods cs majors have to take, in which you can get away with just by grinding and practising questions, this mod requires thinking and understanding the concepts, which may have contributed to its notoriety.this mod has a rather low workload among the cs mods in terms of assignments. the main workload probably comes from understanding the content and doing the tutorials (you can get away with not doing some of the tutorial questions, though not advised if you need more practice), which heavily depends on your math ability.there are only 2 assignments throughout the semester, and each of them can be done in a single day or over the weekend (though you should start early if you are struggling with the content). a few questions may be challenging, and most proving questions are tedious (could just be me who makes proofs overly thorough). one tip for assignments is to be as thorough as possible in your proofs, i.e. every line of proof should have justification.lectures: prof aaron is friendly and is always enthusiastic to meet us every lecture. the lecture slides are well-designed and quite unique; it often has real life scenarios and pictures which made it more visually appealing to look at and made the concepts easier to visualise. prof aaron often asks questions and lecture polls to engage with the students and find out which areas the students are weak in. the 1-hour lectures are sometimes used to go through questions that students may struggle on. thus, the lectures probably made this mod more bearable for most people.one concern i have is that the teaching style is different from most ma proving mods (not necessarily a bad thing, but something worth noting for those taking higher level ma mods; in fact, i do prefer this mod's teaching style as it is less dry). while the lectures here focus more on testing our understanding of the concepts taught and some common traps that students may fall into (not that it does not go through proofs of results), ma proving mods focus more on the proofs of relevant results and more theorems to use. this also means that this mod is more â€œfrom first principlesâ€ rather than applying theorems to get the result. as a result, i experienced a bit of a culture shock when i took ma 2108.tutorial questions were difficult, more so than the assessments. there were a lot more proving questions, with some being too difficult to actually be tested in assessments (as remarked by my tutor). they were just there to reinforce understanding, so do not be disheartened if you struggle to do some of them.my tutor, dr ashish, is experienced in teaching this module. before going through the tutorial, he would briefly explain the applications of the concepts in cs and recall the definitions of important terms. afterwards, he may pick students to answer some basic questions and some of the easier tutorial questions. for the harder questions, he would write the proof on the board and explain his reasoning. he teaches it this way as it allows us to see how the proof is created from scratch and process it better (which did work for me). his experience really shows as he can explain things and write down proofs without much hesitation.midterms and finals actually do not have many proving questions, around <= 20% of marks are on proving. this was a lot less proofs than i have been led to believe, in fact, most of the proving that you do probably comes from tutorials and assignments. instead, the assessments tests more on quick thinking and how comfortable you are with applying the concepts/definitions under time constraints, kind of like solving puzzles (although solving the proving questions would still put you at a significant advantage). tutorial questions may be helpful here. unconventional tip, but before spending time double checking other questions, try not to be afraid of proving questions and attempt some of them, as your marks are more or less secured if you can do them.one advice for this module in general is to follow the definitions closely and fix any wrong intuition that you may have before, as some things can be quite counterintuitive for most people.see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow teach you. simply put, it covers mathematical structures and the interactions between them, such as logic, sets, graphs, and trees. the topics in the first 2-3 weeks will have you wondering "hmm, maybe the seniors exaggerated this module's difficulty?". be warned, for the topics ramp up very quickly, both in terms of content as well as difficulty. on many days, you'll think you understand a topic until you see the tutorial questions and realise that you were deceived. it's like that pretty much every week from week 5 onwards.this topic is definitely as challenging as everyone says it is. while enjoyable as a topic itself, the prospect of studying for the midterm and finals made me feel sick to my stomach. the questions are challenging and push you to the limit in terms of being creative and finding a solution. simply put, it is not for the faint-hearted.however, i would urge you to not go into this module with an s/u mindset. you can learn many mind-blowing and interesting concepts when you study this module, and you should, at the very least, try hard for your first assignment and your midterm. tutorial attendance is a free 5%, please bag that as well. it is very useful.on a more practical note, if you get destroyed by the midterm (by destroyed, i would say well below median) then i'd suggest that you hedge your bets and focus on modules that you have a better chance of scoring at. even if you're at the median, don't be worried as the final exam has a 50% weightage and is a great way for you to make a comeback.the assignments are definitely challenging. attempt them yourselves, and then discuss with your friends to poke holes in your solutions. discrete maths is a very precise subject, and flimsy proofs will not fly.the professors are friendly, and prof aaron always has jokes and anecdotes on hand to lighten the mood and ease some of the stress. he is also compassionate and understands the pressure that students undergo. he loves to remind the each, tutorial attendance 5%, mid-terms 25%, finals 50%description: this module introduces mathematical tools required in the study of computer science. topics include: (1) logic and proof techniques: propositions, conditionals, quantifications. (2) relations and functions: equivalence relations and partitions. partially ordered sets. well-ordering principle. function equality. boolean/identity/inverse functions. bijection. (3) mathematical formulation of data models (linear model, trees, graphs). (4) counting and combinatoric: pigeonhole principle. inclusion-exclusion principle. number of relations on a set, number of injections from one finite set to another, diagonalization proof: an description: This course provides a basic foundation for calculus and its related subjects required by computing students. The objective is to train the students to be able to handle calculus techniques arising in their courses of specialisation. In addition to the standard calculus material, the course also covers simple mathematical modeling techniques and numerical methods in connection with ordinary differential equations. Major topics: Preliminaries on sets and number systems. Calculus of functions of one variable and applications. Sequences, series and power series. Functions of several variables. Extrema. First and second order differential equations. Basic numerical methods for ordinary differential equations.

dong xiaoyu. in the first lecture, as the professor taught, we quickly realised that we cannot really hear him at all, and people started walking out of his lectures midway. from then on, the number of students attending his live lectures can be counted with a single hand. if the professor actually remembers to turn on his mic, it would have been much more interesting as his lecture content actually is extended upon what is taught by the l 1 slot's prof wong, with applications in computer science. however, a bad first impression sets the tone for the rest of the semester. also, prof dong has a habit of teaching about half a lecture faster than prof wong.i started attending prof wong yan loi's l 1 live lectures for the rest of the semester, so that i can attend prof eldon's lectures for cs 2040 s. the situation is slightly better here, the number of students attending his live lectures can be counted with two hands. he teaches like a typical professor, do not expect any of that ma 1522 prof jonathon magic.tutorialmy tutorial sessions are conducted by mr. cheng jingpu. as tutorial attendance is not mandatory, by the end of the tutorials there were only 2 students left in the classroom, me being one of them. i have to say i am impressed that he does all the workings by hand, live in front of us, since that greatly increased the odds of making mistakes. unfortunately that means he often almost overshoot in the time taken.assessmentquizzes: 35%finals: 65%there are 5 quizzes in total, 7% each, released on mondays and due on the same week's fridays, due in weeks 5, 7, 9, 11, and 13. you have 2 attempts in each quiz, and they take the higher score. integer solutions are expected. since no workings are required, the earlier quizzes can be solve trivially with the use of desmos. the quizzes towards the end, involving vector calculus, partial derivatives, double integrals, and differential equations, would have to be done manually.the finals was a 2 hour, 100 marks paper with 10 questions, each being 10 marks. topics tested are chapters 1 to 10, so chapter 11 about second order ordinary differential equations and numerical methods are not tested. for our cohort, the questions are distributed more evenly across the chapters. the paper was tough but not the toughest, and i estimate that i could only do about 70% of the paper, and probably made some mistakes. graphing calculators like the ti-84 plus ce are allowed.conclusioni am taking this as a computer science major, and i would say that ma 1521 is like the less glamorous brother of ma 1522. the way the content is taught felt a little arbitrary. as a former h 2 mathematics student, chapters 2 to 5 would be basically a revision, and you should focus on chapters 1, and 6 to 10. h 2 further mathematics students may have a slight advantage as they have learnt things like polar coordinates, volume of revolution using the shell method, and first-order differential equations using an integrating factor. and for h 2 f math students from jc starting in 2025, even more so, as they now cover function of several variables. meanwhile, i expect polytechnic students to struggle very much with this course.many would not be able to appreciate how they can learn the taught content in their every day lives, since prof wong does not really touch on that. there was an attempt by prof dong to pull in the applications in computing, but it is a little hard to understand as a year 1 computing student. but i am sure it will be useful somehow, later on.resultsquizzes: 34/35 (median: 35)finals: ??/100 ubottoma day agoactual grade: asee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+sstudentonfirea month agoeditedtaken in ay 24/25 sem 1 lecturers: wong yan loi, dong xiaoyuassessments:5 quizzes - 35%finals - 65%ma 1521 introduces a broad range of topics about calculus, building on topics taught in h 2 math. we start with limits and continuity, the move on to single variable and eventually multivariate calculus. the first 7 chapters (aside from chapter 1 and 6) are pretty much jc math but taught more in depth and overall are quite straightforward. chapters 8-9 cover multivariate calculus like partial differentiation and double integration which is slightly more challenging due to the geometric intuition needed for visualizing 3 d surfaces. lastly, we learn about differential equations, which is the easiest of the new topics, though the computations are quite tedious.chapters 0. real numbers and functions 1. limits and continuity (new)2. derivatives 3. applications of differentiation 4. integrals 5. applications of integration 6. sequences and series (new)7. vectors and geometry of space 8. functions of several variables (new)9. double integrals (new)10. ordinary differential equations (new)11. more on ode (not tested)lectureseach week has two 2-hour lectures. most of the cohort skipped lectures, either referring to the online recordings or the lecture notes. i initially attended the afternoon lecture by dr dong xiaoyu. within the first lecture, dr dong showed a lot of weird quirks, like leaving to go to the toilet midway while going through a question and using a marker with no ink.  even when some students shouted at him to re-explain or get a new marker, he remained indifferent. you can see why i didn't attend any of dr dong's following lectures. subsequently i did hear from some peers that dr dong teaches at a more rigorous level (such as discussing the precise meaning of limits and actual application of calculus in neural networks) so it may appeal to students who are more mathematically inclined and able to understand his thick accent.i switched to prof wong yan loi's morning lectures from 8-10 am from the second lecture onwards. prof wong also has hong-kong? kinda accent but i was able to understand him better than dr dong. prof wong teaches quite clearly and gave many examples to explain the concepts. prof wong does mumble slightly and his teaching pace was a tad slow during the sections which recapped jc math content. while the lectures aren't particularly interesting, prof wong overall teaches well and in particular is effective in explaining the geometric intuition needed for the more difficult topics. he is also quite patient and friendly should you approach him after lectures for further questions. lastly, kudos to prof wong for coming back early from his medical leave mid-semester to lecture the 10-15 of us who showed up lol.tutorialsi attended the first few tutorials and some of the later ones on the more difficult topics. tutorials aren't really worth the time if you can do the questions already. for the more difficult topics like chapters 6,8,9, it may be useful to attend if you can't do the questions. the tas are phd students unlike ma 1522 and they can generally explain the questions well, though mine had a thick accent. on a tangent, syu jhan-cyuan wasn't my tutor but when i walked into his first tutorial, he seemed really energetic and prepared a lot of extra materials.assessmentsquizzes: 35% (5 quizzes, 7% each)there are 5 fortnightly quizzes starting from week 5. each quiz has 7 questions and we are given 5 days to complete. unlimited time is given and 2 attempts are allowed (best score is taken). each question expects an integer answer. the quizzes were fairly do-able but beware of tricky/tedious computations. check your calculations and compare answers with other students and deepseek (higher accuracy than chatgpt). there are different versions of each question so do be careful when comparing answers with others. there were also annoyingly marking errors and major typos (incorrect numbers)in some of the quiz questions.finals: 65%most likely 10 questions, with most questions having 2 parts. we are allowed to use any non-programmable calculators including the jc graphing calculator. grinding past year papers is useful as the format is the same across the years and some questions are repeated (like the fly, amount of chemicals etc). this semester's finals was fairly challenging, with a similar level of difficulty as the previous 2 semesters. i unfortunately made a lot of careless mistakes and the answers for my last 2 questions had really weird values. if taking in semester 2, everything is riding on finals so expect a tough bellcurve and try your darndest to avoid making careless mistakes.overall thoughtspersonally, i did enjoy the course more than most of my peers as you can probably tell haha and the content like multivariate calculus was pretty interesting. i do feel this course can use a ma 1522 style revamp so that tools like matlab can be used and that the course can be more mathematically rigorous. ma 1521 at present just plugging in formulas and doing the following computations which can be quite tedious at times and honestly really repetitive after a while. i think i have a headache after solving bernoulli and first order differential equations god knows how many times in the past few weeks lol. prof wong is a solid lecturer but i feel lectures could be more interactive like dr jonathon teo's math cafe in ma 1522. this is by no means a bad course, but it is easy to see why others would prioritize their other  courses.workload: 3/10 (for the average student probably 1/2)enjoyability: 7/10 difficulty: bellcurve)see more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+nn 00 bcaka month agotaken in ay 24/25 sem 2 lecturers: wong yan loi, dong xiaoyucontext: reviewer took 2021 a levels h 2 math where integration by substitution (with substitutions that you thought of yourself) did not exist,  riemannian sums were not taught properly, but where sequences and series still did. reviewer has further calculus background from self-study.tl;dr not very difficult, just practice your numerical computation and you should do well. worst case, ask anyone from jc you know, or dig up your old h 2 math notes. depending on how adventurous you're feeling, can even be a 0 workload module.things you learn:most of this stuff is quite basic computation (esp. if you have a goodnon-programmablecalculator), so don't be intimidated.if you are a jc kid / know jc kids, this is standard jc fare:- standard derivatives, monotonicity (increasing/decreasing), concavity, tangents, normals, related rates of change, implicit differentiation, parametric differentiation- standard integrals & techniques (fundamental theorems of calculus, partial fraction decomposition, integration by parts), volume of solid of revolution (disk method)- sequences and series (taylor & maclaurin series, geometric series)- vectors in euclidean space (3 d)- separable differential equations, logistic curves.and new stuff everyone will be learning together (hooray!)- limits, continuity and derivatives from first principles (note: no epsilon-delta)- derivatives: l'hÃ´pital's rule, rolle's theorem, mean value theorem- integrals: riemann integrals, integration by substitution, improper integrals, volume of solid of revolution (cylindrical shell method), arc length- sequences & series: (absolute) convergence, convergence tests (integral, comparison, d'alembert's ratio, root, alternating series), power series- vector calculus: parameterized vector functions, implicit functions, gradient vector, directional derivatives- multivariable calculus (differentiation): 3 d curves, surfaces, conics, tangent planes,- multivariable calculus (integration): double/integrated integrals, volume, surface area integrals, polar coordinate systems- ordinary differential equations: 1 st order linear odes, 1 st order inhomogeneous odes, bernoulli equation- (extra: 2 nd order linear ode with constant coefficients, method of undetermined coefficients, euler's method)subjective review:workload: 1/10 (throughout the semester you can do nothing. so long as you practice a bit towards the end and don't make basic arithmetic mistakes, you should be fine)enjoyability: -/10 (didn't engage a lot with the mod, can't tell. heard prof wong is really passionate about math and likes to teach more to curious students, which makes him sound like someone i'd want to meet.)difficulty: 2/10 (beware arithmetic mistakes. otherwise most problems you see in the mod are quite cookie-cutter.)comments:very relaxed and asynchronous module that unfortunately barely scratches the surface of calculus. (iseriouslydoubtthis is because the profs don't want to teach it...)for how bad of a hand the profs appear to have been dealt, the materials look quite polished. i appreciate whatever care went into creating the materials, because there were a few things i forgot how to compute...i've heard loads of people say that the math here (and in ma 1522, st 2334) is utterly useless for jobs, but i guess
