sem 1 lecturers: to wing keung, liu chunchunassessment componentshomework: 11%quiz: 24% (8% each)final assessment: 65%overviewthis module is an extension of h 2 calculus, so some of the content (about 50%) should be pretty standard to most soc students. we start off with single-variable calculus, limits, sequences and series, before touching on a bit of vector calculus, followed by multivariable functions and double integrals, before concluding with a basic coverage of odes.workloadlow. there is not much content, especially if you come from jc. perhaps some concepts like limits, series and multivariable calculus may require extra attention to develop strong mathematical intuition for, so it would be wise to approach these topics with patience.lectures were 2 hours each, twice a week. attendance was not taken, and all lectures are recorded online. as such, i did not attend any physical lectures, often watching them at home at 2 x speed. personally, i preferred prof liu's lectures as she was clear in demonstrating the applications of theorems covered in class. being an introductory computing course, she briefly covered proofs, but reminded us that it was okay to not understand them as proving was not a requirement in this course.tutorials were 1 hour per week. before every tutorial, we had to submit our completed questions on canvas by the previous sunday. this constituted 11% of our final grade. however, the good news is that we were graded not based on correctness of our answers, but by completion. as long as you complete 70% of the tutorial, you will get full marks for that week. it goes without saying that almost all students will obtain this 11%. during the tutorial, your ta will go through the questions with you. he will also answer any queries you might have. like many others, i found the tutorials quite useless, since the tutorial questions were often extremely easy and straightforward. since attendance was not taken, you may skip it if you are relatively confident of your ability in this course.there were 3 quizzes spread out throughout the semesters. each quiz was 8% of the final score and had 8 questions, so the weightage per question was pretty high. the quiz questions were extremely difficult and i spent half a day on each of them. however, since it is a take-home assignment, you are expected to get full marks in them. in fact, the median for all 3 quizzes was 8/8. for calculus or limit questions, you can even check your answer online. one thing to note is that there are 2 versions of the same question, differing in numerical values, so you may get slightly different questions from your friend. nevertheless, the steps to solving each question remain the same.there are lecture notes for the course, provided at the start of the semester in one large pdf file. personally, i found the lecture slides more than sufficient, so i did not touch the lecture notes at all. however, i am aware that the lecture notes have extra questions for practice if you so desire. furthermore, there are extra practice questions at the back of every tutorial. unlike the extra practice in other mathematics modules, most of these extra questions are well within the syllabus, and may be tested in the examinations, so i would advise you not to skip these useful questions.examinationsthere is only one examination, which is the 65% closed-book finals held at the end of the course. one a 4 double-sided help sheet was allowed. the questions were extremely difficult (not as difficult as the legendary ay 19/20 s 2 paper, but still quite challenging) and 2 hours was definitely not enough. even though there were only 9 questions, many of the questions had subsequent parts, and those parts were sometimes not related (e.g. part (a) and part (b) were to find the value of 2 different limits, and part (c) was to solve a totally unrelated double integral), so the actual number of questions was far higher. most questions asked for an exact answer, or utilised variables in the expressions, making a gc not very useful. i ended up barely using my scientific calculator and not using my gc at all. even though i managed to complete all questions, i realised i had made a few careless mistakes after review with my friends.tipsgiven the assessment structure, it goes without saying that the finals will mostly decide if you get a good grade or not. for those aiming a high grade, do ensure that you get the full 35% before the finals. furthermore, the examination questions are often very challenging and/or do not test concepts directly, so it would be wise to practise more by doing past year papers or the exercises in the textbook. do attempt to simulate examination conditions by doing the papers under timed conditions too.nearing the examinations, the professors will open up mass consultation slots. prof to conducts it in-person while prof liu conducts it on zoom. it is an open consultation, meaning that students can join as and when they wish to ask questions. however, you may also book consultation slots with the professors or your ta individually if you require more attention and help.final wordsall in all, this module was pretty manageable. the lack of midterms, coupled with the easy tutorial question may potentially promote complacency. however, as long as you keep on practising, it isn't too difficult to get a good grade for this module.one thing i did not like was that in many lectures, we would be thrown theorem after theorem, with little to no explanation behind the derivation and motivation of the results. however, this is understandable as this is simply an introductory module in calculus, where mathematical rigour is low.overall gradeshomework: full marksquiz: 8/8, 8/8, 8/8 finals: unreleased as per mathematics department policyexpected grade: aactual grade: ???see more 00 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+aaikendueetaikendueeta year agoactual grade: asee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more repliesshow more replies âˆ’+aaikendueetaikendueeta year agoactual grade: asee more 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+ffailingcsstudent 2 years agotaken in ay 23/24 sem 1 lecturers: liu chunchun, to wing keungcontentlimits, differentiation and integration with applications, series/sequences, vectors, multivariate calculus, double integration, ordinary differential equations. limits was an extension of jc h 2/hl math content, while differentiation and integration and vectors were pretty much the same as that of jc. those were not too difficult, all things considered. however, limits took a while to understand, especially with the squeeze theorem. series introduced a whole lot of tests that i never completely understood, but application and doing questions with them was manageable except for the taylor/maclaurin series. if i could remove one thing from the syllabus, it would definitely be the taylor/maclaurin series. multivariate calculus was rather confusing, introducing in fairly quick succession concepts like implicit differentiation, partial differentiation (which were not too hard to understand) and then their applications on surfaces and planes in r 3 space (that was very difficult to wrap my head around) with all sorts of visualisations that would be interesting but ultimately not tested. there were many seemingly similar though ultimately different questions in that chapter, which worsened confusion. double integrals were something that i felt i could either see (for the regions and limits) or not, and thus could either do easily or not bother trying. odes were not well explained in the notes, but once i eventually understood them, i felt that it was possibly the easiest of topics that i had no background in (so excluding simple integration and differentiation).workloadminimum of 2-3 h a week. if you are able to read notes and understand the weekâ€™s content in 1-2 h, and then spend another 1 h on the weekâ€™s homework, you could probably keep up with just that. otherwise, lectures are a total of 4 h per week, and tutorials another 1. homework is compulsory (and is 11% of the total grade, though one just needs to attempt 70% of the questions to get full credit for each homework), and worth doing to be sure of your understanding of the concepts. tutorials are for going through the homework.teachingdr liu is, from what iâ€™ve heard, the better lecturer. she explains concepts and tries to break them down, and explains whatâ€™s necessary to know and whatâ€™s just good to know, such as whether the understanding of proofs and derivations of various theorems was necessary (thankfully not), and various methods of applying the laws and theorems provided to different styles of questions. her teaching seemed mostly aimed at helping students understand questions in a way that they could apply concepts and doing, rather than understanding how the concept came about, which given the limited time and difficulty of the questions, seemed fair. my ta, in the few tutorials i attended, was very clear in breaking down concepts and questions for the tutorial in a way that was rather helpful, but ultimately i could figure out most of the homework by myself, by referring to the notes or asking peers so i felt little need to attend most of the tutorials.assessment 11% from tutorial homework (discussed above)8% x 3 from quizzes. they were about the difficulty of some exam questions, but are open book with 2 attempts and no time limit, testing a few previous chapters. everyone gets these correct, so just be sure to description: This course is targeted at students from School of Computing. It introduces basic concepts in linear algebra that are routinely applied in computer science, in the context of the Euclidean spaces, and will develop basic skills in computing with vectors and matrices with and without using computational software (MATLAB). Students are expected to acquire computational facilities and geometric intuition about vectors and matrices. Major topics: Systems of linear equations, matrices, determinants, Euclidean spaces, linear combinations and linear span, subspaces, linear independence, bases and dimension, rank of a matrix, inner products, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalisation, linear transformations between Euclidean spaces, applications.

replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+mmugen 5 months agotaken in ay 24/25 sem 1 prof: jonathon teoassessment componenets 3 x homework: 20%quizzes: 20% (only 92% is needed to get full marks)midterms: 20%finals: 40%lectureslectures (math cafe) are optional and recorded. prof jonathon goes over common misconceptions and shares some cool matlab tricks during cafe. there are also quizzes during the cafe with tricky problems that really helped me prepare for the midterms and finals. i would definitely recommend either going to cafe or watching the recordings. i personally only went to the first cafe but watched the recordings from week 4 onwards.tutorialsa tutorial sheet is released every week and you are expected to complete it before the tutorial session. each sheet also has extra problems for those who want extra practice. your tutorial experience can vary a lot depending on your ta. my ta (luca) was really good at teaching and manages to explain concepts that i found difficult within the 45 minutes.syllabusrefer to the other comments for more details on the syllabus. essentially, all the topics in ma 1522 are interlinked. as you progress through the semester, you will link the concepts that you learn back to chapters 1-4, so having good fundamentals in these topics is important.homeworkyou can discuss with your friends for homework. however, i recommend doing it yourself before checking your answers with friends. you are given an ample amount of time for each homework, so use this opportunity to test your understanding.homework 1 tests your basics, linear systems and matrix algebra. this should be doable for most people. however, i would say the homework was quite tedious as we were required to find the rref by hand for a matrix that had unknowns in it.homework 2 was the hardest in my opinion. there was a question about the intersection of subspaces that i still donâ€™t fully understand even now.homework 3 was the coolest. there was a question that had us derive the formula to find the n-th fibonacci number and honestly, i didn't even know this formula existed before taking ma 1522.the homework for future semesters might vary, but it is very likely that they will be in increasing order of difficulty, so don't get complacent with homework 1.quizzesthe quizzes are due every friday, but the ones assigned for a particular week are only due the following week. this gives you plenty of time to learn the material and review your mistakes. you also get unlimited attempts for the quizzes, with your final score being the average of all your attempts.midtermsmidterms was on examplify. we had 1.5 hours to do 20 mcqs. and the exam was at 8 pm. the questions were very difficult (even harder than the pyp). but there were less theoretical questions and more computational questions than the pyp.finalsfinals are 15 mcqs (45 marks) with 4 structured questions (35 marks) and we were given 2 hours. i found finals to be more manageable than midterms, especially the mcqs. however, some of the structured questions were more challenging than what you would see in the homework. i also noticed a strong emphasis on lu, qr, and svd factorizations in the structured section, so itâ€™s worth diving deep into these topics to prepare.examplify tipsthere are a ton of mrqs for both midterms and finals. just know that examplify only allows you to choose up to the maximum amount of answers. so if the question was meant to have 3 answers, you can only choose a maximum of 3 answers before the other options gray out.also if your matlab crashed during the exam and you are not able to reopen it, restart your computer and raise your hand. when your computer restarts, reopen all your programs and then finally, reopen examplify. examplify will ask you to resume, and if you took too long to resume, it will require a resume code which you need to get from the invigilator. my matlab crashed during finals and i wasn't able to reopen it so i wasted quite a bit of time, but prof jonathon assisted me in resuming with the exam (thanks prof!).ratingdifficulty: 6/10 workload: 4/10 enjoyment: 11/10 usefulness: 10/10 gradesquizzes: 100% (median: 100%)homework 1: 39/40 (median: 39/40)homework 2: 40/40 (median: 40/40)homework 3: 40/40 (median: 40/40)midterms: 20/20 (median: 12.5/20)estimated score for finals: 72/80 (45/45 for mcq + 27/35 for structured)estimated overall: 96%actual grade: a+see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+bruhmius 6 months agoediteday 24/25 prof: jonathan teo (the goatðŸ”¥)rather tough, definitely harder than ma 2001 for ay 24/25.to score well, you need both intuition and speed when it comes to solving questions. unfortunately, i'm a slow typer and my brain went a little haywire after looking at all the floating numbers on examplify. not expecting a good grade (a- and below)what is good about the course:active community, great place to clarify doubts and agotaken in: ay 24/25 sem 1 conducted by: prof jonathon teotl;dr- one of the few course runs in which you could fail (please don't!), but still learn much more than you ever would in other modules.- quite popular, i would assume, given that lecture/tutorial engagement does not drop off as hard as other modules.disclaimer- reviewer kind of likes mathematics. enjoyment differs based on this variable.- reviewer makes mentions of sem 2 conducts of ma 1522/ma 2001 based on second-hand, possibly biased accounts.take this mod in sem 1 pleaseexactly as it says in the heading.specific to prof jonathon's conduct of the module, there are many advantages of doing so:- matlab removes the tedium of computation.- as someone who struggles with number pushing, this is a literal godsend.- questions asked are consequently very conceptual and, imo, can testtrue understanding. (though, you still can't run away from the "gotcha" type questions...)subjective remarksratingsworkload: 4/10 (takes conscious effort to attain mastery. otherwise, learning/assignment deadlines, while strict, are quite embracing of students' other commitments!)enjoyment: 9.5/10 (course material could lean more into the abstract. thatismy sole gripe with the module though.)difficulty: 7.5/10 (assessments are rough and tricky. gets appreciably easier with mastery.)commentsfor all the grievances i have about computational modules in a vacuum (i only got median for midterms x_x), i think this module has a real sense of progression in the sense that with increasing subject mastery comes broadened horizons ("think geometrically") and lower topic difficulty (so many more solutions come to your head instantly!). in that sense, it was extremely rewarding to track my own improvement over the semester as i went from someone with  only passing familiarity with linear algebra to someone with a high(-ish) level of computational proficiency. (proud to say i think i cooked, sautÃ©ed and deep-fried the finals!)additionally, had a real blast in the telegram chat discussing linear algebra results and challenges, although some other people don't seem to share the same opinion... (got asked by a nameless faceless one to stfu, most curiously, through a third person acting as a messenger...)the entire experience is capped off with the phenomenal teaching team! all the utops and prof jonathon really put in the effort to make sure students extract maximum value from the course, from explaining concepts on telegram round-the-clock to crafting masterful lecture quizzes and homeworks that put cs 1231 s to abject shame.overall, this will probably go down in my university life as one of the most enriching modules i have ever taken. i will miss it ;(syllabus(with math, putting everything in any order is already a mistake imo, so we'll roll with what the syllabus says...)- real-valued linear systems and gaussian elimination- real-valued matrices (incl. determinants, adjoints/adjugates, lu factorization)- euclidean vector spaces (briefly touched on general vector spaces though...) (independence, (finite) bases, transition matrices)- vector spaces associated with matrices (row/column spaces, nullspace, rank and nullity.)- orthogonality (dot product, orthogonal bases, least-squares solutions, orthogonal matrices, qr factorization)- eigenanalysis (eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalization, orthogonal diagonalization, singular value decomposition (svd), introduction to stochastic matrices and markov chain)-  linear transformations (lts) (lts on euclidean spaces, ranges, and kernels)assessmentcomponentscontinual assessment:lecture quizzes - 20%- an average of >=92% across all quizzes isautomaticallyrounded up to 100%3 homeworks (week 5, 9, & 13) - 20%examinations:midterm exam - 20%finals - 40%see more 10 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+mma 1522 ubottom 6 months agoeditedtaken in ay 24/25 semester 1 lecturer: dr jonathon teotutor: dr jonathon teo (i don't know who is my original one because i just attended prof's one instead)this is a very very tough module, especially for freshmen without any linear algebra knowledge. although the emphasis here for this module is on computation, one is still expected to at least know how certain theorems are derived. i would encourage one taking this module to try to understand how theorems are derived to make it easier to understand this entire module in general. matlab is allowed for this semester, so it's easier to compute stuff, but expect the standard of assessments to be higher too.lectureslectures are done in a hybrid mode. you watch online lectures on canvas and then you attend a math cafe (basically just a weekly live lecture to recap all the things you have learnt online) in real life. i did not attend any of the math cafes because it starts at 4 pm, but i would encourage one to watch the recorded one. math cafe is not just a recap of the concepts, but you are stretched to understand the concepts further. also, prof jonathon conducts an informal live quiz session before the start of each math cafe, top 3 winners will get toblerones (i think it's prof's favourite snack) as prize.tutorialstutorials are weekly. if you are lucky, you get prof jonathon as your tutor. i did not get him as my tutor, but i went to his tutorial anyway. no attendance is taken so i doubt he can tell who actually belongs to his tutorial group. also, i see different faces every week for tutorial, so i guess it's common to just attend prof jonathon's tutorial anyway. he is very good at explaining the concepts, although at times he may get too over-enthusiastic about it and talk about some concepts that are not in the syllabus. i learn new things every single tutorial. to be honest, i rarely read in details the lecture notes, so i tend to miss out some concepts. his tutorials helped me to fill up the information gaps.telegram helpthere is also a telegram chat for ma 1522, as mentioned by another student below, you can read more details about it.assessments-lecture quizzes 20% (>92% average for all quizzes to get full 100% credit) (lower quartile: 100, median:100, upper quartile:100)-3 x homework 20% (median and upper quartile for all 3 homeworks are 40/40, except for the first homework)-midterm exam 20% (20 mcqs) (out of 20, mean: 12.43, median: 12.5, upper quartile: 14.67, lower quartile: 10.17)-finals 40%prof jonathon's papers are notoriously hard for some reason. i think he mentioned he wanted to have a bellcurve for the papers. midterm paper was very difficult, because it's mostly multiple response questions, and the time given was very little (1.5 hours for 20 questions). it is doable but you need to be fast at thinking and typing out the matlab commands. homeworks are quite difficult as well, i spent quite a lot of time on each, but try your best to get full marks for it because almost everyone does (cough cough, you can compare answers with your friends). lecture quizzes are to test basic concepts, but expect to spend some time on it if you plan to max out your scores for lecture quizzes. will update more about finals in due time. special note: ma 1101 r and ma 2001 papers are totally deceptive as they are mostly testing on manual computations and some proofs (irrelevant to ma 1522), rather than testing on concepts. look at past ma 1522 papers for better representation.finalsi found finals to be significantly tougher than the one from ay replies âˆ’+sstudentonfire 5 months agoediteday 24/25 sem 1 prof: jonathon teo yi hantldr:enjoy the rollercoaster and don't give up.as a bza major, this was the most challenging topic and yet most enjoyable for me this sem. topics are very interlinked so you need to make sure you understand every concept. prof jonathon is a passionate lecturer and provides many avenues for you to clarify your doubts such as lectures (called math cafe) and even a telegram channel. i recommend taking this in sem 1 just to meet prof jonathon haha, who has the superpower to flip su mindset towards this module.chapters:1) linear systems 2) matrix algebra 3) euclidean vector spaces 4) subspaces associated to a matrix 5) orthogonality & least squares solution 6) eigenvectors 7) linear transformationsummary:ma 1522 focuses on computational applications of linear algebra concepts for computing students. even as a year 1 student, you see linear algebra concepts pop up in other modules as well (eg. bt 1101) so this course nicely ties in. conceptually, this was a very challenging module as it is far more abstract than the maths i encountered previously in junior college. even after taking this module, i'm not quite sure if i am able to "think geometrically" about some of the concepts covered in my head.the course has online videos on canvas, which are the most important content. they are narrated by prof jonathon who explains through the concepts concisely and clearly. it is quite normal to rewatch the videos or consult youtube sources for further clarification on the topics, due to the difficulty of linear algebra. there is also the optional math cafe/lecture with prof jonathon every thursday which further clarify and expand on the online learning content. i found it quite useful to attend math cafe, as it allowed me to test whether i truly understood the content, many times after attending the cafe, i realized i did not lol. the math cafe provided some useful elaborations on the content taught and has some nice revision quiz at the start (you can even win tolberones/feastables if you are in the top 3). besides that, i really enjoyed prof jonathon's enthusiasm and humor.starting from week 3, there are also optional tutorial sessions which go through the tutorial assignment focusing on the previous week's topics. attendance is not taken and teaching quality varies. prof jonathon also teaches some classes, so many students choose to attend his.graded components:homework assignments (20%)- 3 homework assignments over the semester with 2.5-3 week deadlines- consists of 3 questions, generally harder than tutorials, but discussion is allowed with smart friends/telegram- relatively easy to get full marks but marking may vary among gradersonline learning quizzes (20%)- 1 5 question quiz for each subtopic of the course- score is taken from average of all your attempts- get above 4.6 for all your quizzes to get full marks for this componentmidterms mcq (20%)- 20 mcq questions, quite challenging as i recall- prepare some matlab scripts so that you don't have to type out every line of code or recall what functions to use.- practice typing skills as you may have to type some large matricesfinals (40%)- has 20 mcq questions and 3 open ended questions- easier than midterms and mainly on matlab computation rather than on thorough understanding of contentconclusion:ma 1522 is a very well put together module and is ultimately challenging but rewarding. prof jonathon is one of the best lecturers i have encountered so far and encourages you to explore and question the concepts taught. there are many avenues for you to seek help, so do not feel daunted. enjoy the experience and don't give up. this is a course, where the journey is equally or even more memorable and  rewarding than the end result.overall grades:1. lecture quizzes: 20/202. homework assignments: 20/203. midterm exam: 14.5/204. final exam: ???actual spaces 4) subspaces associated to a matrix 5) orthogonality & least squares solution 6) eigenanalysis 7) linear transformationbased on my understanding ma 1522 is taught very differently in semester 2, without matlab.lecturethere is technically no lectures, with course content taught asynchronously through canvas. however, there is a weekly math cafe at the l 2 timeslot (thursdays 4-6 pm), where professor jonathon teo covers the content meant for that week. each math cafe starts with a pollev quiz where the top 3 or so students gets feastable / toblerone. it is then followed by a rehashing of the concepts taught in the lecture though with a bit more extras. prof teo is very passionate in whatever he is teaching, and it shows. i consider him amongst the best of the lecturers you can find across nus. he explains things in a clear and animated manner, sometimes using his fingers to get us to "think geometrically", which is absolutely necessary for such an abstract topic for a freshman.tutorialit so happens that my tutorial is also taught under prof teo, and he brings the same energy in math cafe to tutorials as well. these tutorials are 1-2 weeks behind the math cafe. there are 11 of them in total, and they do a good job at teaching the concepts, and then also getting you to use matlab to automate the computations.assessmentlecture quizzes: 20%midterm exam (week 8): 20%3 homeworks (week 5, 9, & 13): 20%finals: 40%lecture quizzes are due on fridays 2359, 1-2 weeks behind the math cafe, with each subtopic having 5 questions, with unlimited attempts allowed. the final grade of the quiz is the average of all attempts, so it is important that you do not screw up your first few attempts or you will find yourself attempting the same quiz >20 times just to salvage your grade. that's because scoring >92% in the quiz will result in you attaining 100% of the grade, which means that on average your eventual grade for each quiz should be at least 4.61/5. meanwhile, the 3 homeworks can be done on paper or digitally, and are submitted digitally on canvas, and you can discuss the solutions on the cohort-wide telegram chat with 850 people in it.the mid-term exam was done on examplify, with 20 mcq/mrq questions, open book closed internet, over 1.5 hours on a friday night. there was a time crunch and it is practically a competition on who can type matlab commands the fastest. some people even wrote programs to speed up their computation! but it's worth noting that many of these questions aren't merely computational, but are very tricky in concept as well. this is similar to the finals, except that it was 2 hours long, with 15 3-mark mcq questions and 35 marks of written questions.conclusioni am part of the 2 nd cohort of soc students taking ma 1522 in this form, so there is only 1 past year paper that we can work with. previously, soc students would take ma 1101 r or ma 2001, but those people had to do their exams without matlab, so the questions were much more computational or proof-based in nature. these computational questions that would take minutes to do by hand, can be solved in seconds by matlab, a tool that is much more powerful than graphing calculators.holding the entire course together is the 16 equivalent statements of invertibility. the main additional content covered over ma 1101 r or ma 2001, used by the math majors, are the lu, qr, and svd factorisation. looking back as someone whoâ€™s formerly a h 2 math student, i appreciate how linear algebra can be used as an abstraction for solving a system of linear equations (rref), dot product (orthogonality), and a generalisation of lines and planes (linear spaces) in the topic of vectors. h 2 further math students may find much of the course a revision of what they have learnt, but there are new concepts that are covered, such as the aforementioned factorisations, adjoint, elementary & transition matrices, least squares solution, orthogonality, the gram-schmidt process, & orthogonal diagonalisation.resultshomework 1: 40/40 (median: 39)homework 2: 40/40 (median: 40)homework 3: 40/40 (median: 40)midterm exam: 14.67/20 (median: 12.5)see more 00 replyshare 00 replyshare â€ºshow more replies âˆ’+aaikendueet 2 years agoediteday 23/24 sem 1 lecturers: loke hung yean, jonathon teoassessment componentslecture quiz: 10%homework: 15% (5% each)midterm assessment: 25%final assessment: 50%overviewthis is the first iteration of the introductory linear algebra course for soc students, which seeks to replace ma 2001 (with the exception of math ddp students). we start off with learning about linear systems, matrices, determinants, subspaces, linear independence, bases and dimension. after the midterms, we move on to rank, orthogonality, least squares, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalisation, and finally linear transformations.key differences from ma 2001 are that exams are fully open book, and we are allowed to use any offline calculator to compute our answers. we are also taught how to use matlab to compute problems, however some students prefer to use python, which is also fine. there are little to no proving questions in the examinations. we also learn svd, lu and qr factorisation, which are not taught in ma 2001.workloadlow to medium. there is lesser content compared to the other soc modules / ma 1521, however some effort is definitely required to have a strong understanding of the concepts involved.lectures are 2 x 2 h per week, fully recorded. attendance is not taken. i enjoyed prof jonathon's lectures a lot. before starting the lecture, he will host a quiz, which is filled with many tricky questions to test our conceptual understanding from the previous lecture. he is also particularly excited about anything related to "eigen", even going so far as to set it as the password for our finals. he is very passionate and knowledgeable and even uploads his own tutorial slides for everyone to read (on top of the suggested solutions). sadly, i did not attend live lectures after the first few weeks as they were both at 8 am.tutorials are 1 h a week, conducted by a ta or one of the profs. all tutorial worksheets are released at the start of the semester. since attendance is also not taken, many students (myself included) chose to attend prof jonathon's tutorial instead, sometimes leading to overcrowding in the classroom. what is unique about his tutorials is that he begins with a summary of the past week's lectures, which is extremely useful for revision. on top of going through the suggested solutions, he also demonstrates the matlab code for solving the questions, so that we will be able to compute it efficiently during the examinations. finally, he shares alternate approaches to help us develop geometric intuition for solving certain problem sets.once a week, there will be graded weekly canvas quizzes which consist of mcqs or short answer questions. you are given unlimited attempts and there are even comments to explain the answer after submission, hence you should be doing it a maximum of twice to get full marks. do take note of the deadline since some students (including me) are forgetful. nonetheless, the profs will always send out a reminder for you to complete the quizzes. almost everyone will get the full 10%.there are 3 homework assignments given out throughout the semester, and we are given 2-3 weeks to work on them. they are relatively easy so the median is always full marks. they hold a pretty hefty weightage (15%) so do check your answers thoroughly before submitting. it will be wise to check with your friends too.lastly, if you have extra free time, you may attempt the exercises in the recommended textbook, or try out the extra questions at the back of the weekly tutorial worksheets.examinationsmidterms was a 1 hour 30 minute paper with 20 mcqs (80 m) and 2 open-ended questions in section b (20 m). the median was 48/80 for mcq and 8/20 for section b. the questions were not thenormand most students i spoke to did not finish the paper. prepare yourself for tricky and difficult problems to solve under extreme time pressure.finals was a 2 hour paper with 15 mcqs (45 m) and 5 open-ended questions in section b (55 m). there was a greater emphasis on content taught in the later half of the semester. there were many questions on lu, qr and svd in section b. rather frustratingly, the matrices given were often partially masked, or contained variables in them, which means we were unable to compute them with matlab. the questions were notelementaryat all - strong conceptual and intuitive understanding was required to solve some of the harder questions in the paper. nevertheless, i found this paper easier than the midterms, probably because i actually started to put in effort for the second half of the semester.examinations were all conducted on examplify. mcq answers were submitted online (directly through examplify) while the written answers were scanned and uploaded onto canvas with our phones after the exam (for midterms), or submitted physically (for finals).tipsthe key to doing well in ma 1522 is to understand things geometrically. prof jonathon always emphasises this in his lectures. rather than memorising content, we should understand key ideas well to solve problems. as he says, "bring a basis to the exam, not a subspace"! i also recommend 3 b 1 b's youtube series on linear algebrato solidify your understanding of the subject intuitively.linear algebra will probably seem more abstract than the typical arithmetic you are used to, especially if you come from a jc background. hence, you may often face struggles during the course. i found it very difficult to keep up with the proofs taught during lectures, often having to re-read the lecture notes multiple times to fully understand the derivation of certain theorems. in my opinion, thedeterminantof your success in ma 1522 is to remainconsistent, persevere, and really sit down to question every concept taught to you and why things seem to be the way they are. prof jonathon calls this "meditating" and it was actually one of the most empowering things he said to me to inspire me to press on for this module (i was intending to s/u the module beforehand).nearer to the examinations, prof loke and prof jonathon will open consultation slots on canvas.spanningthe reading week, they are highly popular and are often fully booked. thus, i recommend that you clarify any doubts with your ta or the professors on a regularbasis. for me, i found out that prof jonathon was open to consultations after his tutorial slot, so i stayed back on a few occasions to clarify my doubts privately with him.lastly, i must say that some of the past year papers for ma 2001 were difficult, especially the proving questions. if it helps, not a single one of those proving questions came out during our finals. it seems that the professors are focusing a lot more on applications rather than theinverse(mathematical proving), which makes sense, given that this module is geared towards computing students.(p.s. matlab has many cool functions which will make your life much easier in the exams. spend some time playing with it.)final wordsthe difficulty of this module really discouraged me at the start, but the support and encouragement given by the professors helped me to tide through difficult times. since the concepts are all related to each other, ensure you have a solid foundation of the techniques taught in the earlier weeks (e.g. rref, invertible matrix theorem), as you will continue to use them to solve problems up to the final chapter.for those interested, prof jonathon runsutopfor ma 1522 if you are keen to assist him in the pedagogical aspects of the course. nus also offersma 2101/ma 2101 sif you are interested to learn more about linear algebra.overall gradeslecture quiz: full markshomework: 40/40, 40/40, 30/30 midterms: 68/80 + 13/20 = 81%finals: unreleased as per mathematics department policyexpected grade: a+actual grade: ???see more 00 replyshare â€ºâˆ’+aaikendueetaikendueeta year agoactual description: This course introduces students to basic probability theory and statistical inference. Topics include basic concepts of probability, conditional probability, independence, random variables, joint and marginal distributions, mean and variance, some common probability distributions, sampling distributions, estimation and hypothesis testing based on a normal population.

replies âˆ’+wwytsmf 2 years agoeditedtaken in ay 22/23 lecturer: prof yu tao------------------ content ----------------------we begun the module with event operations, properties and relations and then moved onto pnc, which i have never been good at, axioms and properties of probability, independence theorem, law of total probability and bayes theorem. after this was the computation of expectation and variance of discrete and continuous variables, as well as the probabality function and graphs and cumulative probability function and graphs of discrete and continous variables.midterms covered only 2 of the 7 chapters and was quite challenging, because i was very confused with almost every pnc question and misunderstood the functions of a discrete variable.then there was joint probability, marginal probability and conditional probability in chapter 3, which you may have encountered during gea 1000, but with more depth and mathematical concepts. a good grasp of double integrals is preferred for understanding, but it don't think it is necessary for the exams (the exam was on examplify and you can use a computer). chapter 4 went into the different types of distributions, which i think covered the bulk of the content for this module. most of the questions dealt with some type of distribution from this chapter, making this chapter the most important one in my opinion. after this was sampling distributions consisting of central limit theorem, chi-squared, f-distributions. the bulk of chapter 6 was on calculation of confidence intervals and error estimates and the last chapter, 7, was on hypothesis testing, which is almost the same content as a-level statistics.---------------- review --------------------this module was the dryest thing i've ever taken and nothing short of a formula spam for the most part. we were just taught to accept the formula as is, and proofs were sparse, if any at all. i seldom understood the intuition behind the formulation of the theorem we were taught during the lecture. most of the time i had to search on the internet myself for the relevant proof in my own time, as sometimes they are also not provided on the notes.after the lecturer, prof would post a quiz (marked as lecture attendence), but sometimes with incorrect options that would confuse us a lot. i emailed him once, asking if an option was written in error, and he replied that it wasn't, only for my friend to email the same question with more details, for him to reply that there was indeed a typo. if i hadn't asked my friend for prof's reply, i would have continued believing there was no typo.the lecturer speaks in a very loud (as he is lecturing to the entire auditorium) but monotone voice with little variation, reading almost the same content from the slides and notes and, coupled with an 8 am class, made the lecture so much more difficult to pay attention to.at the last lecture, right before finals, it was entirely remote and prof went through the past year papers at his office over zoom. surprising, this is the first time his lecture sounded tolerable. as he was not straining his voice, his speech pattern was easier to grasp and made the lecture easier to pay attention to.midterms (mcq and mrq) was challenging enough for me whenever pnc were involved, but i knew my probability and event properties fairly well, which consisted of majority of the tricky questions, so it wasn't too bad.despite the dryness of the content, i prepared and practiced really hard for finals by doing all the tutorial questions, the practice exam and writing my own notes for the module.finals was much longer and more difficult, with the addition of fill in black questions. it was trickier as sometimes you need to apply some concepts as a shortcut to get the answer, as opposed to direct computation which is meant to be impossible to do. this requires a good understanding of the mechanics behind the theorems taught.for example, there was an question asking for the covariance of two variables involving the computation of the gauss error function (an integral, if evaluated by hand, is nearly impossible to express in familiar terms) and it is impossible to directly solve it, but if you know about the independence of two variables and see that the question satisfies this condition, you may deduce the covariance to be zero without doing a single step of integration. a lot of the questions were relevant to chapter 4 and the types of distributions.like one comment pointed out, a good excel spreadsheet to help you compute the probability of distributions, sampling tests, variance and expection is very useful, and you can use this in the exam.---------------- grade breakdown --------------------the grade breakdown consists of almost only midterm and final results, plus 6 of the best of 11 in-lecture quizzes. finals takes up a massive percentage and made the preparation for the exam very
